definition: to renounce a throne, high office, dignity, or function
sentence: The king decided to abdicate his throne so his daughter could become the new queen.
origin: borrowed from Latin abdicātus, past participle of abdicāre, "to resign, renounce, withdraw," from ab-  + -dicāre, ablaut derivative of dīc- (going back to *deik-) in dīcere "to speak, state"

definition: the fact or an instance of deviating or being aberrant especially from a moral standard or normal state
sentence: The snowy day in the middle of summer was a strange weather aberration.
origin: borrowed from Latin aberrātiōn-, aberrātiō "diversion, relief," from aberrāre "to wander away" + -tiōn-, -tiō, suffix of action nouns

definition: the process of ablating: such as
sentence: The scientist explained that the melting of the glacier is a form of ice ablation.
origin: Middle English ablacioun "removal," borrowed from Late Latin ablātiōn-, ablātiō, from Latin ablā-, suppletive stem of auferre "to carry away, remove" + -tiōn-, tiō, suffix of action nouns

definition: a systematic variation of vowels in the same root or affix or in related roots or affixes especially in the Indo-European languages that is usually paralleled by differences in use or meaning (as in sing, sang, sung, song)
sentence: Our teacher showed us how the vowel change in 'sing' and 'sang' is called an ablaut.
origin: borrowed from German Ablaut, from ab "down, from" (going back to Old High German ab, aba, preposition) + Laut "sound," going back to Middle High German lūt, going back to Old High German hlūtī, lūtī, liutī, derivative from the base of hlūt "loud, strident"; akin to Old English hlūd "loud" ,

definition: denial; especially : self-denial
sentence: By giving up her dessert to her little brother, Sarah showed great abnegation.
origin: Middle English abnegacioun, borrowed from Late Latin abnegātiōn-, abnegātiō, from Latin abnegāre "to refute, decline, deny" + -tiōn-, -tiō, suffix of action nouns

definition: worthy of or causing disgust or hatred : detestable
sentence: The hikers searched for clues of the Abominable Snowman high up in the mountains.
origin: Middle English abhomynable, abomynable, borrowed from Anglo-French abhominable, abominable, borrowed from Late Latin abōminābilis, abhominābilis (spelling influenced by Latin ab homine "from the man"), from abōminārī "to detest, " + -ābilis

definition: to abolish by authoritative action : annul
sentence: The principal decided to abrogate the old rule that students couldn't wear hats in class.
origin: borrowed from Latin abrogātus, past participle of abrogāre, "to repeal (a law), repudiate, cancel," from ab-  + rogāre "to ask, ask an assembly for approval of"

definition: a localized collection of pus surrounded by inflamed tissue
sentence: The dentist had to treat a small abscess on the boy's gum to stop the toothache.
origin: borrowed from Latin abscessus "departure, withdrawal, congestion, abscess," from abscēdere "to go away, withdraw, form an abscess" (from abs-, variant of ab-  before c- and t- + cēdere "to go, withdraw, move away") + -tus, suffix of verbal nouns

definition: to depart secretly and hide oneself
sentence: The sneaky raccoon tried to abscond with the campers' bag of marshmallows.
origin: borrowed from Latin abscondere "to conceal, hide," from abs- (variant of ab-  before c- and t-) + condere "to put, store up, put away, conceal"

definition: the act of forgiving someone for having done something wrong or sinful : the act of absolving someone or the state of being absolved; specifically : a remission of sins pronounced by a priest (as in the sacrament of reconciliation)
sentence: After he accidentally broke the vase, Leo felt better when his mom gave him absolution.
origin: Middle English absoluciun, borrowed from Anglo-French, borrowed from Latin absolūtiōn-, absolūtiō "completion, acquittal, release," from absolū- (stem, before consonants, of absolvere "to set free, acquit, finish") + -tiōn-, -tiō suffix of action nouns

definition: marked by restraint especially in the eating of food or drinking of alcohol; also : reflecting such restraint
sentence: The athlete was very abstemious and only ate healthy foods like fruit and nuts.
origin: borrowed from Latin abstēmius "refraining from wine, careful with one's means," from abs- (variant of ab-  before c- and t-) + -tēmius, from a base tēm- "intoxicating" (also in tēmētum "intoxicating beverage," tēmulentus "drunken"); if going back to an Indo-European root *temH-, akin to Sanskrit tāmyati "(he/she) is stunned, loses consciousness, is exhausted," tamayati "(he/she) chokes (someone)," Armenian tʿmrim "(he/she) is stunned" (perhaps going back to *tēmiro-)

definition: a native or inhabitant of Acadia
sentence: We read a history book about the Acadians who moved from Canada down to Louisiana.

definition: to make (something) more prominent or noticeable : accent, emphasize; also : intensify
sentence: The bright yellow flowers really help to accentuate the green colors in the garden.
origin: borrowed from Medieval Latin accentuātus, past participle of accentuāre "to accent, stress," derivative of Latin accentus

definition: the action or process of accruing something
sentence: The accrual of dust on the old bookshelves showed that nobody had cleaned them in years.

definition: the quality of being acerbic
sentence: There was a bit of acerbity in her voice when she told her brother to stop poking her.
origin: borrowed from Middle French acerbité, borrowed from Latin acerbitāt-, acerbitās, from acerbus "sour, bitter" + -itāt-, -itās

definition: refracting light without dispersing it into its constituent colors : giving images practically free from extraneous colors
sentence: The old photograph was achromatic, showing only different shades of black, white, and gray.
origin: + Greek chrōmat-, chrôma "color" +  (or borrowed directly from Greek chrōmatikós , formed with the same elements)

definition: of or relating to the sense or organs of hearing, to sound, or to the science of sounds : such as
sentence: Instead of using an electric guitar, the musician played a beautiful song on his acoustic guitar.
origin: acoustic borrowed from Medieval Latin acousticus, acūsticus, borrowed from Greek akoustikós, from akoustós "heard, audible" (verbal adjective of akoúein "to hear," going back to Indo-European *h2kou̯s-) + -ikos ; acoustical from acoustic +

definition: to accept, agree, or comply usually by staying silent or by not arguing —often used with to or in
sentence: Even though he wanted to play tag, Tim decided to acquiesce and play hide-and-seek with his friends.
origin: borrowed from French acquiescer, going back to Middle French, borrowed from Latin acquiēscere "to rest, find peace, be satisfied (with)," from ad-  + quiēscere "to repose, be quiet"

definition: the act of acquiring something
sentence: The museum’s newest acquisition is a giant skeleton of a dinosaur found in the desert.
origin: Middle English adquysicyoun, borrowed from Anglo-French & Latin; Anglo-French acquisition, borrowed from Latin acquīsītiōn-, acquīsītiō, from acquīsī- (variant stem of acquīrere "to ") + -tiōn-, -tiō, suffix of action nouns

definition: relating to or affecting the peripheral parts of the body, such as limbs, fingers, or ears.
sentence: The doctor checked the patient's acral areas, like the fingers and toes, for any signs of frostbite.

definition: keenness of perception
sentence: An eagle has amazing visual acuity, which allows it to see a tiny rabbit from high in the sky.
origin: Middle English acuite "sharpness, acridity," borrowed from Middle French acuité, borrowed from Medieval Latin acuitāt-, acuitās, from Latin acu-, stem of acuere "to sharpen" + -itāt-, -itās

definition: clarity of mind and depth of perception, discernment, or discrimination especially in practical decision-making
sentence: The young girl showed great business acumen by selling the most lemonade in the neighborhood.
origin: borrowed from Latin acūmen "sharp point, stinger, acuteness of mind," from acū-, stem of acuere "to sharpen" + -men, resultative noun suffix

definition: an originally Chinese practice of inserting fine needles through the skin at specific points especially to cure disease or relieve pain (as in surgery)
sentence: My aunt went to an acupuncture clinic to see if the tiny needles would help her back feel better.
origin: Latin acū- (stem—or ablative—of acus "needle") +

definition: the belief that certain religious practices or doctrines are indifferent or not essential to salvation.
sentence: In some religions, wearing a certain color is seen as an adiaphorism because it doesn't affect one's faith.

definition: a wooden lawn chair with a high slatted back, broad arms, and a seat that is lower in the back than the front
sentence: We spent our summer vacation sitting in big wooden Adirondack chairs by the lake.
origin: after the , New York

definition: a wild dog of Java and Sumatra.
sentence: The adjag, also known as a wild dog, was spotted running through the tall grass in the forest.

definition: the transpose of the cofactor matrix of a given square matrix.
sentence: In her advanced math homework, the student had to find the adjugate of a square matrix.

definition: to command solemnly under or as if under oath or penalty of a curse
sentence: The teacher had to adjure the students to be quiet and listen to the safety instructions.
origin: Middle English adjuren, borrowed from Anglo-French ajurer, borrowed from Latin adjūrāre "to affirm with an oath, swear," from ad-  + jūrāre "to swear"

definition: the period of life when a child develops into an adult : the period from puberty to maturity terminating legally at the age of majority
sentence: Most people start to grow much taller and change during the years of adolescence.
origin: Middle English, borrowed from Middle French & Latin; Middle French, borrowed from Latin adolēscentia, adulēscentia, noun derivative of adolēscent-, adolēscens

definition: extreme or excessive admiration or flattery
sentence: The famous singer smiled at the adulation she received from all the cheering fans.
origin: Middle English adulacioun "insincere praise, flattery," borrowed from Anglo-French, borrowed from Latin adūlātiōn-, adūlātiō, from adūlārī "to fawn upon (of dogs), praise insincerely" (of uncertain origin) + -tiōn-, -tiō, suffix of verbal action

definition: a public notice; especially : a paid notice that is published or broadcast (as to attract customers or to provide information of public interest)
sentence: I saw a funny advertisement on TV for a new kind of cereal that turns milk blue.
origin: Middle English, borrowed from Anglo-French avertisement, advertissement, from avertiss-, advertiss-, stem of avertir, advertir "to notify, (reflexive) recognize, be mindful of" + -ment

definition: of, relating to, or acting in the manner of an advocate.
sentence: The lawyer gave an advocatory speech to explain why the new playground was a good idea.

definition: a system of physical conditioning involving exercises (such as running, walking, swimming, or calisthenics) strenuously performed so as to cause marked temporary increase in respiration and heart rate
sentence: Every Tuesday, my mom goes to the gym to do aerobics and dance to upbeat music.

definition: being pleasant and at ease in talking to others
sentence: The new librarian is very affable and always helps us find the best adventure books.
origin: Middle English affabyl, borrowed from Anglo-French affable, borrowed from Latin affābilis, from affārī "to speak to, address" (from ad-  + fārī "to speak") + -bilis "capable of (being acted upon)" ,

definition: to assess or settle the amount of an amercement or fine.
sentence: The judge had the power to affeer the penalty to make sure the fine was fair for everyone.

definition: to bring or receive into close connection as a member or branch
sentence: Our local soccer team decided to affiliate with the national league to play in bigger games.
origin: probably from French affilier "to bring into close connection" (going back to Middle French, "to adopt as a son," borrowed from Medieval Latin affīliāre, from Latin ad-  + -fīliāre, verbal derivative of fīlius "son") +

definition: having an abundance of goods or riches : wealthy
sentence: The affluent family donated a large amount of money to build a new wing for the library.
origin: Middle English, "flowing in abundance, copious," borrowed from Latin affluent-, affluens "flowing with, abundant," present participle of affluere "to flow in, come streaming along, be abundantly present," from ad-  + fluere "to flow, run"

definition: a dessert consisting of a scoop of vanilla gelato or ice cream topped with a shot of hot espresso.
sentence: For dessert, my dad ordered an affogato, which is vanilla ice cream with espresso poured over it.

definition: pashtun
sentence: Grandma knitted a colorful wool afghan to keep us warm while we watch movies on the couch.
origin: borrowed from Persian afghān "Pashtun"

definition: a person who likes, knows about, and appreciates a usually fervently pursued interest or activity : devotee
sentence: Since he knows everything about every player, my brother is a total baseball aficionado.
origin: borrowed from Spanish aficionado, from past participle of aficionar "to inspire devotion or affection in," verbal derivative of afición "liking, interest," going back to earlier afeción, afección, borrowed from Latin affectiōn-, affectiō "feeling, feeling of attachment"

definition: a votive offering or cult statue in ancient Greece.
sentence: The museum displayed a beautiful agalma, which is an ancient Greek statue dedicated to a god.

definition: a spiny shrub of the southwestern U.S. and Mexico that produces edible red berries.
sentence: While hiking in Texas, we saw an agarita bush with sharp leaves and bright red berries.

definition: a fine-grained variegated chalcedony having its colors arranged in stripes, blended in clouds, or showing mosslike forms
sentence: I found a shiny agate stone at the river that had beautiful colorful stripes inside it.
origin: Middle English achates, accate, agaten, borrowed from Anglo-French & Latin; Anglo-French achate, agathe, borrowed from Latin achātēs, borrowed from Greek achā́tēs, of uncertain origin

definition: any of a genus (Agave of the family Asparagaceae, the asparagus family) of plants having spiny-margined leaves and flowers in tall spreading panicles and including some cultivated for their fiber or sap or for ornament
sentence: The desert garden had a giant agave plant with thick, pointy leaves that look like spikes.
origin: borrowed from New Latin, borrowed from Greek agauḗ, feminine of agauós "admirable, illustrious, brilliant," of uncertain origin

definition: the doctrine that society or the group is the primary unit of human existence.
sentence: The teacher explained agelicism as the idea that a group of people is more important than just one person.

definition: to make great or greater : increase, enlarge
sentence: The emperor built giant statues of himself for his own aggrandizement to make himself look powerful.
origin: borrowed (with assimilation of the ending to ) from French agrandiss-, stem of agrandir, going back to Old French, from a-, verb-forming prefix (going back to Latin ad- ) + -grandir, verbal derivative of grand "large, great," going back to Latin grandis "fully grown, large, great"

definition: the premium paid for the exchange of one currency for another.
sentence: When we went to Europe, we had to pay a small agio to trade our dollars for euros.

definition: having no tongue.
sentence: The scientist studied an aglossal frog, which is a special kind of frog that does not have a tongue.

definition: a sore or inflammation around a fingernail; a hangnail.
sentence: I had to use a small pair of clippers to fix the painful agnail on the side of my thumb.

definition: of or relating to the athletic contests of ancient Greece
sentence: The two wolves showed agonistic behavior by growling at each other to see who was the leader.
origin: borrowed from Late Latin agōnisticus "of a contest," borrowed from Greek agōnistikós "fit for a contest, contentious," from agōnistḗs "one engaged in a contest or struggle" + -ikos

definition: abnormal fear of being helpless in a situation from which escape may be difficult or embarrassing that is characterized initially often by panic or anticipatory anxiety and finally by the avoidance of open or public places
sentence: Because of her agoraphobia, the woman felt very nervous whenever she had to go into a big, crowded park.
origin: borrowed from German Agoraphobie, from Greek agorā-, combining form of agorá "place of assembly, " + German -phobie

definition: a large tropical American palm tree or its edible fruit.
sentence: In the rainforest, people climb the aguaji palm tree to pick the scaly fruit that grows at the top.

definition: a Japanese art of self-defense employing locks and holds and utilizing the principle of nonresistance to cause an opponent's own momentum to work against them
sentence: In my aikido class, I learned how to use my partner's movement to protect myself without hurting them.
origin: Japanese aikidō, from ai- match, coordinate + ki breath, spirit + dō art, way

definition: a mayonnaise flavored with garlic and sometimes other ingredients (such as red pepper)
sentence: My brother likes to dip his french fries in garlic aioli instead of plain ketchup.
origin: Occitan, from ai garlic + oli oil

definition: even though : although
sentence: The puppy was very cute, albeit a little bit messy after playing in the mud.
origin: Middle English, literally, all though it be

definition: a medieval chemical science and speculative philosophy aiming to achieve the transmutation of the base metals into gold, the discovery of a universal cure for disease, and the discovery of a means of indefinitely prolonging life
sentence: Long ago, people studied alchemy because they believed they could turn lead into gold.
origin: Middle English alkemye, alkamye, alchymie, borrowed from Anglo-French & Medieval Latin; Anglo-French alkemye (Middle French also alquimie, arquemie), borrowed from Medieval Latin alkimia, alchymia "transmutation of base metals into gold, the philosopher's stone," borrowed from Arabic al-kīmiyāʼ, from al "the" + kīmiyāʼ "art of transmuting base metals," borrowed, perhaps via Syriac kīmiyā, from Late Greek chymeîā, chēmeîā, of uncertain origin

definition: a double salt of mercuric chloride and ammonium chloride, used formerly as a stimulant.
sentence: The old chemistry book mentioned alembroth, a salty substance used by scientists hundreds of years ago.

definition: city in central Louisiana population 47,723
sentence: We learned about the Great Library of Alexandria, which was a famous place for books in ancient Egypt.

definition: a procedure for solving a mathematical problem (as of finding the greatest common divisor) in a finite number of steps that frequently involves repetition of an operation; broadly : a step-by-step procedure for solving a problem or accomplishing some end
sentence: The computer uses a special algorithm to decide which math games to show me next.
origin: alteration of Middle English algorisme, from Old French & Medieval Latin; Old French, from Medieval Latin algorismus, from Arabic al-khuwārizmi, from al-Khwārizmī flourished a.d. 825 Islamic mathematician

definition: the act or process of affording nutriment or nourishment
sentence: Good alimentation is important for kids because eating healthy food helps our bodies grow strong.
origin: borrowed from Middle French & Medieval Latin; Middle French, "nourishment, sustenance," borrowed from Medieval Latin alimentātiōn-, alimentātiō, from Late Latin alimentāre "to nourish, maintain" + Latin -tiōn-, -tiō, suffix of verbal action

definition: a substance (such as pollen) that induces allergy
sentence: My mom bought a special pillow that is not allergenic so I won't sneeze at night.
origin: borrowed from German Allergen,, blend of allerg- (in Allergie ) and -gen (in Antigen )

definition: the repetition of usually initial consonant sounds in two or more neighboring words or syllables (such as wild and woolly, thrifty and thriving) —called also head rhyme, initial rhyme
sentence: The phrase 'Peter Piper picked a peck of pickled peppers' is a famous example of alliteration.
origin: borrowed from New Latin allīterātiōn-, allīterātiō, from Latin ad-  + lītera "letter" + -ātiōn-, -ātiō

definition: capable of being allocated
sentence: The teacher made sure the extra craft supplies were allocable to every student in the room.

definition: a name of another person assumed by an author as a pen name.
sentence: The author used an allonym, which means he published the book using another person's name.

definition: an implied or indirect reference; also : the use of such references
sentence: The story was full of allusions to fairy tales, like mentioning a glass slipper and a magic bean.
origin: borrowed from Late Latin allūsiōn-, allūsiō, from Latin allūdere "to play or romp beside, make a playful allusion to" + -tiōn-, -tiō, suffix of verbal action

definition: relating to, composed of, or found in alluvium
sentence: The farmers planted their crops in the rich alluvial soil left behind by the flooding river.

definition: a school, college, or university which one has attended or from which one has graduated
sentence: My dad went back to visit his alma mater to see his favorite teachers at his old college.
origin: Latin, fostering mother

definition: relating to or growing in high mountains; subalpine.
sentence: The hikers looked for alpestrine plants that only grow high up in the cold mountains.

definition: an alto saxhorn
sentence: During the parade, we saw a musician playing the althorn, a brass instrument that looks like a small tuba.
origin: German, from alt alto + Horn horn

definition: a small cavity or pit: such as
sentence: In our science lesson, we learned that the alveoli are tiny air sacs in our lungs that help us breathe.
origin: New Latin, from Latin, diminutive of alveus cavity, hollow, from alvus belly, beehive; akin to Lithuanian aulys beehive, Greek aulos tube, flute

definition: of, relating to, used in, or affected by Alzheimer's disease
sentence: The girl’s grandfather has Alzheimer, so she helps him remember where he put his glasses.

definition: a mixture of different elements
sentence: The bowl was filled with an amalgam of different snacks, like pretzels, nuts, and chocolate chips.
origin: Middle English amalgam, malgame "alloy of mercury with another metal," borrowed from Medieval Latin amalgama, borrowed from Arabic al maljam, al muljam, from al "the" + maljam, muljam, perhaps borrowed from Greek málagma "emollient," from malak-, stem of malássein "to soften" (derivative of malakós "soft') + -ma, resultative noun suffix

definition: capable of being understood in two or more possible senses or ways
sentence: The ending of the movie was ambiguous, so my friends and I had to guess what actually happened.
origin: Latin ambiguus "unresolved, hesitating in mind, of uncertain outcome, having more than one possible meaning, untrustworthy" (from ambigō, ambigere "to dispute, be undecided, call in question, be in doubt" —from amb- "around, about, on both sides" + agere "to drive [cattle], be in motion, do, perform"— + -uus, deverbal adjective suffix) +  ,

definition: the food of the Greek and Roman gods
sentence: The fresh peach pie had an ambrosial smell that made everyone want a slice immediately.
origin: Latin, from Greek, literally, immortality, from ambrotos immortal, from a- + -mbrotos (akin to brotos mortal)

definition: any of a subclass (Ammonoidea) of extinct cephalopods especially abundant in the Mesozoic age that had flat spiral shells with the interior divided by septa into chambers
sentence: I found a fossil of an ammonite, which looks like a spiral shell from a creature that lived long ago.
origin: borrowed from New Latin ammōnīta or ammōnītēs, from Latin Ammōn, the Egyptian god Ammon (in cornu Ammōnis, a name for the fossils, literally "horn of Ammon," alluding to the ram's head of the god and the hornlike shape of the stones) + -īta, -ītēs

definition: the one of the four basal ganglia in each cerebral hemisphere that is part of the limbic system and consists of an almond-shaped mass of gray matter in the anterior extremity of the temporal lobe —called also amygdaloid nucleus
sentence: The brain uses the amygdala to help us feel emotions, like when we are excited or scared.
origin: New Latin, from Latin, almond, from Greek amygdalē

definition: marked by or promoting metabolic activity concerned with the biosynthesis of complex molecules (such as proteins or nucleic acids) : relating to, characterized by, or stimulating anabolism
sentence: The doctor explained that anabolic processes in our bodies help us build new muscles as we grow.

definition: an error in chronology; especially : a chronological misplacing of persons, events, objects, or customs in regard to each other
sentence: Seeing a knight in a movie using a smartphone would be a funny anachronism.
origin: borrowed from New Latin anachronismus, borrowed from Middle Greek anachronismós, from Late Greek anachronízein to be late, (middle voice) be an anachronism (from Greek ana-  + chrónos time + -izein ) + Greek -ismos

definition: a poem in the manner of ancient Greek poet Anacreon; especially : a drinking song or light lyric
sentence: The poet wrote an anacreontic song that was all about celebrating and having a good time.

definition: the art of carving or embossing in low relief.
sentence: We used red and blue glasses to see the anaglyphy picture pop out in 3D.

definition: selected miscellaneous written passages
sentence: The students read the analects of Confucius to learn about his wise sayings and ideas.
origin: New Latin analecta, from Greek analekta, neuter plural of analektos, verbal adjective of analegein to collect, from ana- + legein to gather

definition: a literary technique that involves a flashback to an earlier event.
sentence: The author used analepsis to show a scene from the main character's childhood.

definition: insensibility to pain without loss of consciousness
sentence: The medicine provided analgesia, which means it helped take away the boy's pain after he fell.
origin: borrowed from New Latin, borrowed from Greek analgēsía "lack of feeling, insensibility," from an-  + álgēsis "sense of pain" (from algē-, variant stem of algéō, algeîn "to feel pain, suffer" — derivative of álgos "pain" — + -sis ) + -ia , probably formed after análgētos "insensible to pain"

definition: the union of parts or branches (as of streams, blood vessels, or leaf veins) so as to intercommunicate or interconnect
sentence: In biology, an anastomosis is when two different branches of a river or blood vessel join back together.
origin: Late Latin, from Greek anastomōsis, from anastomoun to provide with an outlet, from ana- + stoma mouth, opening

definition: of or relating to anatomy or the body structure of organisms
sentence: We looked at an anatomical model of the human body to see where the heart and stomach are located.

definition: a place where vessels anchor : a place suitable for anchoring
sentence: The sailors looked for a safe anchorage where they could drop the anchor and stay for the night.

definition: having a subordinate, subsidiary, or secondary nature
sentence: The teacher gave us an ancillary book to read that had extra facts about the history of space travel.
origin: see

definition: relating to or affected with anemia
sentence: The doctor suggested eating more spinach because the girl felt a little anemic and tired.
origin: see

definition: about, concerning
sentence: The principal made a short announcement anent the rules for the upcoming field trip.
origin: Middle English onevent, anent, from Old English on efen alongside, from on + efen even

definition: a person who greatly admires or favors England and things English
sentence: Since she loves tea and stories about London, my aunt is a huge anglophile.
origin: French, from anglo- + -phile

definition: any of a genus (Anhinga) of fish-eating birds related to the cormorants but distinguished by a longer neck and sharply pointed rather than hooked bill; especially : one (A. anhinga) occurring from the southern U.S. to Argentina
sentence: While visiting the swamp, we saw an anhinga bird drying its wings in the sun after diving for fish.
origin: borrowed from New Latin, borrowed from Tupi ayíŋa (phonetically ãĩŋã)

definition: the Buddhist doctrine of impermanence.
sentence: Our teacher explained that anicca is the idea that everything in the world is always changing.

definition: of or relating to anions
sentence: In science class, we learned that an anionic particle has a negative charge.

definition: a Eurasian annual herb (Pimpinella anisum) of the carrot family having carminative and aromatic seeds; also : aniseed
sentence: The cookies had a very strong smell and taste of anise, which reminded me of black licorice.
origin: Middle English anis, from Anglo-French, from Latin anisum, from Greek annēson, anison

definition: a spirit of an ancestor or a nature deity in traditional Philippine folk religion.
sentence: In the Philippines, an anito is a spirit of an ancestor or nature that people used to honor.

definition: a large pear that has usually yellowish-green skin and sweet, juicy, relatively firm flesh and is more or less egg-shaped with the base typically broader than the stem end —called also d'Anjou
sentence: I packed a sweet, green Anjou pear in my lunchbox for a healthy snack.
origin: Anjou, France

definition: a cross having a loop for its upper vertical arm and serving especially in ancient Egypt as an emblem of life
sentence: In our book about ancient Egypt, we saw a drawing of an ankh, a symbol that looks like a cross with a loop.
origin: Egyptian ʽnḫ live

definition: to heat and then cool (a material, such as steel or glass) usually for softening and making less brittle; also : to cool slowly usually in a furnace
sentence: The blacksmith had to anneal the metal by heating it and cooling it slowly to make it stronger.
origin: Middle English anelen to set on fire, from Old English onǣlan, from on + ǣlan to set on fire, burn, from āl fire; akin to Old English ǣled fire, Old Norse eldr

definition: a sum of money payable yearly or at other regular intervals
sentence: My grandmother receives an annuity, which is a fixed amount of money paid to her every year.
origin: Middle English annuite, from Anglo-French annuité, from Medieval Latin annuitat-, annuitas, from Latin annuus yearly

definition: the act of annulling something : the state of being annulled
sentence: The judge signed an annulment to officially state that the contract was no longer valid.

definition: serving to alleviate pain
sentence: The soft music was an anodyne for the baby, helping him stop crying and fall asleep.
origin: borrowed from Latin anōdynus "allaying pain," borrowed from Greek anṓdynos "free from pain, causing no pain, harmless, allaying pain," from an-  + -ōdynos, adjective derivative (with compositional lengthening) of odýnē "pain," of uncertain origin

definition: any of a genus (Anolis) of arboreal American lizards (such as the green anole) of the iguana family that have a brightly colored dewlap and the ability to change color
sentence: We watched a tiny green anole lizard climb up the garden fence and change its color to brown.
origin: borrowed from French anolis, borrowed from Dominica Island Carib anáoli

definition: the quality or state of being anonymous
sentence: The donor wanted to maintain her anonymity, so she didn't put her name on the gift to the school.

definition: a usually pullover hooded jacket long enough to cover the hips
sentence: Put on your warm anorak before we go outside so the wind and rain don't get you wet.
origin: borrowed from Norwegian, Danish or German, borrowed from Greenlandic Inuit annoraaq, name for a hooded outer garment originally made of skin; (sense 2) from the alleged popularity of anoraks as outerwear among such people

definition: of, relating to, or resembling a goose; stupid or silly.
sentence: The way the silly goose waddled across the lawn was very anserine.

definition: an agent that counteracts or neutralizes acidity
sentence: After eating too much spicy food, my dad took an antacid to settle his stomach.

definition: showing dislike or opposition : marked by or resulting from antagonism
sentence: The two characters in the story were antagonistic toward each other and were always arguing.
origin: see

definition: described or thought of as having a human form or human attributes
sentence: The cartoon featured anthropomorphic animals that wore clothes and talked like humans.
origin: Greek anthrōpómorphos "having human form" (from anthrōpo-  + -morphos ) +

definition: a strong feeling of dislike
sentence: The cat showed great antipathy toward the vacuum cleaner and would hide whenever it turned on.
origin: Latin antipathia, from Greek antipatheia, from antipathēs of opposite feelings, from anti- + pathos experience

definition: one who collects or studies antiquities
sentence: The antiquarian book shop was filled with dusty old novels from hundreds of years ago.

definition: the direct opposite
sentence: Love is often considered the complete antithesis of hate.
origin: Late Latin, from Greek, literally, opposition, from antitithenai to oppose, from anti- + tithenai to set

definition: apprehensive uneasiness or nervousness usually over an impending or anticipated misfortune : a state of being anxious
sentence: I felt a little bit of anxiety before my big piano recital, but I did a great job.
origin: Middle English anxiete, borrowed from Middle French & Latin; Middle French anxieté, borrowed from Latin anxietāt-, anxietās "apprehensive uneasiness, worry, solicitude," from anxius "worried, disturbed, " + -etāt-, -etās, variant of -itāt-, -tās

definition: an opening or open space : hole
sentence: The photographer adjusted the aperture on the camera to let in more light for the photo.
origin: Middle English, borrowed from Latin apertūra, from apertus, past participle of aperīre "to open" + -ūra

definition: a place where bees are kept; especially : a collection of hives or colonies of bees kept for their honey
sentence: We visited an apiary to see how the beekeepers collect honey from the hives.
origin: borrowed from Latin apiārium, from apis "bee" (of obscure origin) + -ārium

definition: an expression of real or pretended doubt or uncertainty especially for rhetorical effect
sentence: The detective was in a state of aporia because the clues didn't seem to make any sense.
origin: French aporie, ultimately from Greek aporia difficulty, perplexity, from aporos impassable, from a- + poros passage

definition: a mark ' used to indicate the omission of letters or numerals, the possessive case (as in "John's book"), or sometimes the plural of letters or numerals (as in "the 1960's")
sentence: Don't forget to put an apostrophe in the word 'can't' to show that a letter is missing.
origin: borrowed from French & Late Latin; French, borrowed from Late Latin apostrophus, apostrophos "mark placed above a consonant to indicate that a following vowel has been deleted," borrowed from Greek apóstrophos (feminine noun, presumably shortened from the collocation apóstrophos prosōidía, with prosōidía in sense "accent mark"), from apóstrophos, adjective, "turned away, averted," derivative of apostréphein "to turn back, turn away"

definition: one who prepares and sells drugs or compounds for medicinal purposes
sentence: In old stories, people went to an apothecary to get medicine made from herbs and roots.
origin: Middle English apothecarie, apotecarie, pothecarie, borrowed from Anglo-French & Medieval Latin; Anglo-French apothecaire, ipotecaire, borrowed from Medieval Latin apotēcārius, apothēcārius, going back to Late Latin, "shopkeeper," from Latin apothēca "storeroom, storehouse, repository" (borrowed from Greek apothḗkē, from apothē-, variant stem of apotithénai "to put away, stow away" —from apo-  + tithénai "to put, place"— + -kē, noun suffix) + -ārius

definition: the perfect form or example of something : quintessence
sentence: The winning goal was the apotheosis of the team's hard work throughout the whole season.
origin: borrowed from Late Latin apotheōsis "transformation into a god, deification," borrowed from Greek apothéōsis, from apotheō-, variant stem of apotheóō, apotheoûn "to transform into a god, deify" (from apo-  + theoûn "to make a god of," verbal derivative of theós "god") + -sis

definition: designed to avert evil
sentence: Ancient people often wore apotropaic charms to ward off bad luck or evil spirits.
origin: Greek apotrópaios "averting evil, that should be averted, ill-omened" (from apotrop-, stem in nominal derivation of apotrépein "to turn away from, turn aside, avert" —from apo-  + trépein "to turn"— + -aios, adjective suffix) +

definition: a set of materials or equipment designed for a particular use
sentence: The gymnast used a special apparatus called the balance beam to show her routine.
origin: borrowed from Latin apparātus "act of preparing, display, trappings, equipment," from apparāre "to make ready, make preparations for" (from ad-  + parāre "to supply, provide, make ready") + -tus, suffix of verbal nouns

definition: commendation, praise
sentence: The teacher gave an approbatory nod to show she was pleased with my answer.
origin: see

definition: of, relating to, or resembling water
sentence: The scientist explained that the liquid was an aqueous solution, meaning it was mostly made of water.
origin: Medieval Latin aqueus, from Latin aqua

definition: a body of rock or sediment that stores groundwater but does not allow it to flow through.
sentence: The layer of solid rock acted as an aquiclude, preventing water from flowing through it.

definition: chosen, decided, etc. seemingly at random or on a whim rather than in a reasoned or methodical way; also : random
sentence: Choosing the blue folder instead of the red one was a completely arbitrary decision.
origin: Middle English, "depending on individual discretion," borrowed from Anglo-French & Latin; Anglo-French arbitraire, arbitrarie "relating to arbitration," borrowed from Latin arbitrārius "relating to or depending on the discretion of an arbiter," from arbitr-, arbiter  + -ārius

definition: a place where trees, shrubs, and herbaceous plants are cultivated for scientific and educational purposes
sentence: We went on a school trip to the arboretum to see many different types of rare trees.
origin: New Latin, from Latin, plantation of trees, from arbor

definition: any of a genus (Arbutus) of shrubs and trees of the heath family with white or pink flowers and red or orange berries
sentence: The arbutus tree is easy to recognize because of its peeling red bark and white flowers.
origin: New Latin, from Latin, strawberry tree

definition: the original pattern or model of which all things of the same type are representations or copies : prototype; also : a perfect example
sentence: In many stories, the brave knight is the archetype of a hero.
origin: Latin archetypum, from Greek archetypon, from neuter of archetypos archetypal, from archein + typos type

definition: hard to accomplish or achieve : difficult
sentence: Climbing to the very top of the steep mountain was an arduous task that took all day.
origin: Latin arduus high, steep, difficult; akin to Old Irish ard high

definition: the language used by a particular type or group of people : an often more or less secret vocabulary and idiom peculiar to a particular group
sentence: The sailors used their own argot, using special words that people on land didn't understand.
origin: French

definition: a short aria
sentence: The singer performed a short, beautiful arietta before the main part of the opera began.
origin: Italian, diminutive of aria

definition: a military or naval force
sentence: The castle was built with strong walls and many armaments to protect the kingdom.
origin: probably borrowed from French armement "action of arming, equipping of an armed force" (from armer "to " + -ment ), reshaped after Latin armāmenta (neuter plural) "sailing gear of a ship, equipment, implements," from armāre "to , equip" + -menta, plural of -mentum

definition: an organ or structure (such as teeth or thorns) for offense or defense
sentence: The artist built a wire armature to hold up the clay while she sculpted the statue.
origin: Middle English, "armor, armed force," borrowed from Latin armātūra "armament, troop" (Medieval Latin, "suit of armor, defensive equipment of an animal"), from armātus, past participle of armāre "to , equip" + -ūra

definition: temporary stopping of open acts of warfare by agreement between the opponents : truce
sentence: The two countries finally signed an armistice to stop the fighting and begin peace talks.
origin: borrowed from New Latin armistitium, from Latin arma "implements of war, weapons" + -stit-, -stes (going back to *-sta-t-s, root noun derivative from Indo-European *steh2- the base of Latin sistere "to make stand, halt, bring to a standstill," stāre "to stand") + -ium, suffix of compounded nouns ,

definition: production of the tones of a chord in succession and not simultaneously
sentence: I practiced playing an arpeggio on my violin by playing the notes of a chord one after another.
origin: borrowed from Italian, noun derivative of arpeggiare "to play the harp," from arpa "harp" (going back to a Vulgar Latin loan from Germanic *harpō- "harp") + -eggiare, factitive verb suffix, going back to Latin -idiāre, originally representing variant pronunciation (or spelling variant) of -izāre

definition: to call (a defendant) before a court to answer to an indictment : charge
sentence: The court will arraign the suspect tomorrow to officially tell him what he is being accused of.
origin: Middle English araynen, areynen, arreynen "to ask (a question), ask (someone) a question, interrogate, rebuke, (in law) call upon to answer an accusation," borrowed from Anglo-French arener, araisner, arrener "to speak to, ask questions of, call to account, (in law) call upon to answer an accusation," going back to Vulgar Latin *adratiōnāre, from Latin ad-  + Vulgar Latin *ratiōnāre "to speak, converse," verbal derivative of Latin ratiōn-, ratiō "reckoning, calculation, explanation" (early Medieval Latin also "justification, dispute, discussion, speech")

definition: the condition of being in arrears
sentence: The shop owner had a small arrearage, which meant he still owed some money for his rent.
origin: Middle English arrerage, arerage "unpaid debt, balance due, state of being behind in payment," borrowed from Anglo-French arrerage, from arere, arrere  + -age

definition: muleteers or mule drivers.
sentence: In the mountains of South America, the arrieros lead their mules along the narrow trails.

definition: an establishment for the manufacture or storage of arms and military equipment
sentence: The coach has an arsenal of different plays to help our team win the game.
origin: earlier, "dockyard for the construction and repair of naval vessels," borrowed from Middle French archenal, arsenail, arsenal (in reference to the naval dockyard of Venice), borrowed (with conformation of the final to -al ) from Upper Italian (Venice) arzanà, presumably alteration (by metanalysis, with the initial taken as the preposition d', di "from") of darsenà (attested in Genoese, earlier in Medieval Latin as darsena, darsana), borrowed from Arabic dār al-ṣināʽa "place of manufacture," from dār "house" + al "the" (assimilated to aṣ) + ṣināʽa "manufacture" (derivative of ṣanaʽa "to make")

definition: raw or primitive art made by people outside the established art world, such as prisoners or patients.
sentence: We looked at a painting of art brut, which is art made by people who never went to art school.

definition: a well in which water is under pressure; especially : one in which the water flows to the surface naturally
sentence: The family got their water from an artesian well that bubbled up naturally from deep underground.
origin: artesian borrowed from French artésien "of ," going back to Old French, from Arteis "Artois" + -ien

definition: clever or artful skill : ingenuity
sentence: The magician used clever artifice to make the rabbit look like it disappeared into thin air.
origin: borrowed from Anglo-French & Middle French, "trade, craft, craftsmanship, contrivance," borrowed from Latin artificium "artistry, craftsmanship, craft, craftiness, cunning," from artific-, artifex "practitioner of an art, specialist, craftsman, creator" (from art-, ars "acquired skill, craftsmanship" + -fic-, -fex, agentive derivative of facere "to make, bring about, do") + -ium, denominal or deverbal suffix of function or state ,

definition: a technique and social event for having or attending a barbecue in South America.
sentence: In Argentina, families often gather for an asado, which is a big barbecue with lots of grilled meat.

definition: the act or process of ascending
sentence: The mountain climbers celebrated their ascension to the very peak of the snowy mountain.
origin: Middle English, from Latin ascension-, ascensio, from ascendere

definition: to find out or learn with certainty
sentence: The detective looked for clues to ascertain exactly who had eaten the last cookie from the jar.
origin: Middle English acertainen to inform, give assurance to, from Anglo-French acerteiner, from a- (from Latin ad-) + certein, certain certain

definition: practicing strict self-denial as a measure of personal and especially spiritual discipline
sentence: The monk lived an ascetic life, choosing to own very few things and spend his time in quiet prayer.
origin: Greek askētikos, literally, laborious, from askētēs one that exercises, hermit, from askein to work, exercise

definition: the home of the Norse gods
sentence: In Norse mythology, Asgard is the magnificent home of the gods like Odin and Thor.
origin: Old Norse āsgarthr

definition: a cheese of Italian origin that is pungent, hard, yellow, and suitable for grating when aged and mild, semisoft, and whitish when fresh
sentence: My mom grated some salty Asiago cheese over the top of our big bowl of pasta.
origin: Asiago, town in Italy

definition: resembling or characteristic of an asp; venomous or spiteful.
sentence: The grumpy character in the book had an aspish personality and was often mean to his neighbors.

definition: a person who attacks someone violently
sentence: The brave knight chased away the assailant who was trying to break into the castle gates.

definition: showing great care, attention, and effort : marked by careful unremitting attention or persistent application
sentence: Being an assiduous student means studying hard and checking your homework for mistakes.
origin: Latin assiduus, from assidēre to sit beside

definition: a taking to or upon oneself
sentence: I made an assumption that it would be cold outside, so I wore my thickest sweater.
origin: Middle English, from Late Latin assumption-, assumptio taking up, from Latin assumere see

definition: to make sure or certain : convince
sentence: I can assure you that if we leave now, we will arrive at the movie theater on time.
origin: Middle English, from Anglo-French asseurer, assurer, from Medieval Latin assecurare, from Latin ad- + securus secure

definition: a chronic lung disorder that is marked by recurring episodes of airway obstruction (as from bronchospasm) manifested by labored breathing accompanied especially by wheezing and coughing and by a sense of constriction in the chest, and that is triggered by hyperreactivity to various stimuli (such as allergens or rapid change in air temperature)
sentence: The coach made sure the asthmatic player had his inhaler nearby during the soccer game.
origin: Middle English asma, borrowed from Medieval Latin asma, asthma, borrowed from Greek ásthma "panting, shortness of breath, asthma (as a medical condition)," of uncertain origin

definition: a defect of an optical system (such as a lens) causing rays from a point to fail to meet in a focal point resulting in a blurred and imperfect image
sentence: Because of my astigmatism, things sometimes look a little blurry unless I wear my glasses.
origin: + Greek stigmat-, stígma mathematical point, mark, tattoo mark (more usually stigmḗ in this sense; referring to the point on the retina at which light rays converge in a normal eye) +

definition: of, relating to, or coming from the stars
sentence: The scientist studied astral bodies like stars and planets using a powerful telescope.
origin: borrowed from Late Latin astrālis, from Latin astrum "star, celestial body" (borrowed from Greek ástron) + -ālis

definition: causing a tightening of soft organic tissues : styptic
sentence: The lemon juice felt very astringent on my tongue, making my whole mouth pucker up.
origin: probably from Middle French, from Latin astringent-, astringens, present participle of astringere to bind fast, from ad- + stringere to bind tight

definition: an eroded remnant of a large crater made by the impact of a meteorite or comet.
sentence: We looked at a map of a giant astrobleme, which is a crater left behind by a meteorite long ago.

definition: a genus of hawks including the goshawk.
sentence: A hawk is a type of bird that belongs to the Astur family, known for being great hunters.

definition: an inviolable place of refuge and protection giving shelter to criminals and debtors : sanctuary
sentence: In the old story, the travelers sought asylum in the church to stay safe from the storm.
origin: Middle English, from Latin, from Greek asylon, neuter of asylos inviolable, from a- + sylon right of seizure

definition: recurrence in an organism of a trait or character typical of an ancestral form and usually due to genetic recombination
sentence: Seeing a dark forest can sometimes trigger an atavistic fear that humans have felt for thousands of years.
origin: French atavisme, from Latin atavus ancestor, from at- (probably akin to atta daddy) + avus grandfather

definition: an inability to coordinate voluntary muscular movements that is symptomatic of some central nervous system disorders and injuries and not due to muscle weakness —called also incoordination
sentence: The dog was wobbly because of ataxia, which made it hard for him to walk in a straight line.
origin: borrowed from Greek ataxía "lack of discipline, disorder, confusion," from a-  + -taxia, from táxis "drawing up in rank and file, order of battle, order, arrangement" + -ia

definition: to refuse to go near or become involved with (someone or something)
sentence: In ancient Egypt, some people worshipped Aten, which was the symbol of the sun disk.

definition: a device for throwing a spear or dart that consists of a rod or board with a projection (such as a hook) at the rear end to hold the weapon in place until released
sentence: Before bows and arrows were invented, people used an atlatl to throw spears much further.
origin: Nahuatl ahtlatl

definition: the innermost essence of each individual
sentence: In some philosophies, the atman is the true self or soul that lives inside every person.
origin: Sanskrit ātman, literally, breath, soul; akin to Old English ǣthm breath

definition: given to or marked by melancholy : gloomy
sentence: The old man was often atrabilious, which is a fancy word for being very gloomy or irritable.
origin: Latin atra bilis black bile

definition: absence or closure of a natural passage of the body
sentence: The doctor explained that atresia is a condition where a part of the body is closed when it should be open.
origin: New Latin, from  + Greek trēsis perforation, from tetrainein to pierce

definition: a person on the staff of an ambassador or with a specific technical responsibility.
sentence: The diplomat traveled with his attaché, who helped him organize all of his important meetings.

definition: relating to or of the nature of an attribute : attributing
sentence: In the phrase 'the blue sky,' the word 'blue' is an attributive adjective because it describes the sky.

definition: a reduction in numbers (as of employees or participants) usually as a result of resignation, retirement, or death
sentence: The smooth rocks on the beach were shaped by years of attrition from the crashing waves.
origin: borrowed from Late Latin attrītiōn-, attrītiō "act of wearing away, diminishment," from Latin attrī-, variant stem of atterere "to rub (against), wear away, diminish, impair" (from at-  + terere "to rub, grind, wear down") + -tiōn-, -tiō, suffix of verbal action; (sense 1) Middle English attricioun "repentance falling short of contrition," borrowed from Medieval Latin attrītiōn-, attrītiō, going back to Latin

definition: eggplant
sentence: In some countries, people call an eggplant an aubergine, but it’s the same purple vegetable.
origin: French, from Catalan albergínia, from Arabic al-bādhinjān the eggplant, ultimately from Middle Indo-Aryan *vātiñjaṇa-, vātiṅgaṇa-

definition: of the color auburn
sentence: My sister has beautiful auburn hair that looks reddish-brown when the sun shines on it.
origin: Middle English auborne blond, from Middle French, from Medieval Latin alburnus whitish, from Latin alburnum sapwood

definition: zero, cipher
sentence: Many popular songs from the aughts, which were the years from 2000 to 2009, are still played today.
origin: alteration (resulting from false division of a naught) of naught

definition: to make greater, more numerous, larger, or more intense
sentence: I decided to augment my stamp collection by trading some stickers for a rare bird stamp.
origin: Middle English, from Anglo-French augmenter, from Late Latin augmentare, from Latin augmentum increase, from augēre to increase

definition: divination from auspices or omens; also : an instance of this
sentence: In ancient times, people thought a flock of birds flying north was an augury of good weather.
origin: Middle English augurie, borrowed from Anglo-French & Latin; Anglo-French augorrye, augurrie, borrowed from Latin augurium "divination by an augur, art of divination, omen, portent," from augur  + -ium, suffix of function or state

definition: any of several small seabirds (especially genera Aethia and Ptychorhamphus) of the alcid family that occur along North Pacific coasts
sentence: We saw a small auklet bird diving into the cold ocean water to catch a tiny fish.

definition: a radiant light around the head or body of a representation of a sacred personage
sentence: In the painting, the saint had a bright aureole of light shining around his head.
origin: Middle English aureole heavenly crown worn by saints, from Medieval Latin aureola, from Latin, feminine of aureolus golden, diminutive of aureus

definition: told privately
sentence: The doctor used a special tool to check the boy's auricular canal and make sure his ear was healthy.

definition: dawn
sentence: People travel far north to see the aurora, which are beautiful green and purple lights in the night sky.
origin: Latin

definition: kindly patronage and guidance
sentence: The science fair was held under the auspices of the local university, which provided the prizes.
origin: borrowed from Middle French, borrowed from Latin auspicium "augury from the behavior of birds, leadership, authority," from auspic-, auspex "augur taking omens from birds (from avis "bird" + -spic-, -spex, derivative of specere "to see, observe") + -ium, deverbal suffix of function or state ,

definition: stern and cold in appearance or manner
sentence: The principal's office looked very austere, with only a plain desk and two simple chairs.
origin: Middle English, from Anglo-French, from Latin austerus, from Greek austēros harsh, severe; akin to Greek hauos dry

definition: a German, Swiss, or Austrian expressway
sentence: In Germany, some parts of the big highway called the autobahn do not have a speed limit.
origin: borrowed from German Autobahn, from Auto  + Bahn "path, way, lane," going back to Middle High German ban, bane "cleared path, track," akin to Middle Low German & Middle Dutch bāne in same sense, of uncertain origin

definition: excessive or insatiable desire for wealth or profit : greediness, cupidity
sentence: The greedy dragon’s avarice led him to guard a mountain of gold that he never even used.
origin: Middle English, from Anglo-French, from Latin avaritia, from avarus avaricious, from avēre to crave

definition: the birds or the kinds of birds of a region, period, or environment
sentence: The park is famous for its diverse avifauna, meaning it is home to many different kinds of birds.
origin: New Latin, from Latin avis + New Latin fauna

definition: suggestive of an uncle especially in kindliness or geniality
sentence: Our neighbor is very avuncular; he always tells us funny jokes and gives us treats like a kind uncle.
origin: Latin avunculus maternal uncle

definition: a sweet bread made with yeast and butter:
sentence: For dessert, we had a slice of chocolate babka, which is a sweet, swirly bread.
origin: borrowed from Yiddish & Polish; Yiddish babke (in sense a), borrowed from Polish babka (in sense b), literally, "old woman, grandmother," diminutive of baba "grandmother, midwife, old woman"

definition: a Moroccan slipper that is flat and has no heel.
sentence: While visiting Morocco, my mom bought a pair of babouche slippers with pointy toes.

definition: destruction or dissolution of bacterial cells
sentence: The scientist discovered a bacteriolytic substance that can destroy harmful bacteria.
origin: New Latin

definition: ancient country of southwestern Asia between the Hindu Kush and the Oxus River; capital Bactra
sentence: A Bactrian camel is easy to spot because it has two humps instead of just one.

definition: a noisy attention-getting demonstration or talk
sentence: The new superhero movie was highly ballyhooed, so there were long lines at the theater.
origin: origin unknown

definition: of, relating to, yielding, or containing balsam
sentence: We dipped our pieces of bread into a mixture of olive oil and dark balsamic vinegar.

definition: any of several very large rats (genera Bandicota and Nesokia) of southern Asia destructive to crops
sentence: The bandicoot is a small, furry animal from Australia that likes to dig for bugs in the ground.
origin: Telugu pandikokku

definition: the practice of banditry, especially in Spanish-speaking regions.
sentence: We learned about bandolerismo in history class, which describes the stories of outlaws and bandits.

definition: a type of bamboo used for various structural purposes.
sentence: The fisherman used a small bango boat to travel across the calm waters of the Philippines.

definition: a usually unleavened flat bread or biscuit made with oatmeal or barley meal
sentence: Our scout leader showed us how to bake bannock, a simple type of flatbread, over the campfire.
origin: Scots & northern English dialect, going back to Middle English (northern) bannoke "bread baked on the hearth," going back to Old English bannuc "a small piece (of bread)," of obscure origin

definition: a Dutch breed of large domestic fowl that produces dark brown eggs.
sentence: The farmer raised a Barnevelder chicken, which is famous for laying beautiful dark brown eggs.

definition: the rank of a baronet
sentence: In the story, the brave knight was rewarded with a baronetcy, giving him a special title of honor.

definition: an oblong building ending in a semicircular apse used in ancient Rome especially for a court of justice and place of public assembly
sentence: We visited a giant basilica that had beautiful stained-glass windows and very tall ceilings.
origin: borrowed from Latin, borrowed from Greek basilikḗ (for basilikḕ stoá "royal stoa"), noun derivative from feminine of basilikós "of a king, royal," from basil- (base of basileús "king, prince," of pre-Greek substratal origin) + -ikos

definition: a type of fortified town built in medieval France.
sentence: While traveling in France, we saw a bastide, which is a town built like a fort to keep people safe.

definition: flavored custard or pureed fruit combined with gelatin and whipped cream
sentence: The doughnut was filled with sweet, smooth Bavarian cream and topped with chocolate.

definition: of, possessing, or imparting beatitude
sentence: The baby had a beatific smile on her face while she was dreaming of happy things.
origin: borrowed from Latin beātificus "making happy," from beātus "happy, fortunate" (from past participle of beāre "to make happy, gladden, bless," perhaps, if going back to *dwe-jo-, akin to bonus "good," going back to *dwe-nos) + -ficus

definition: hoodwink
sentence: The clever fox tried to beguile the birds into coming closer by telling them a funny story.
origin: Middle English bigilen, beguilen, from bi-, be-  + gile  or gilen "to deceive, cheat," borrowed from Old French guiler, derivative of guile

definition: district of west central London, England, in the borough of Kensington and Chelsea south of Hyde Park
sentence: Belgravia is a very fancy neighborhood in London with beautiful white houses and parks.

definition: an Old World poisonous plant (Atropa belladonna) of the nightshade family having purple or green bell-shaped flowers, glossy black berries, and root and leaves that yield atropine —called also deadly nightshade
sentence: The teacher warned us that belladonna is a plant with pretty berries that are actually very poisonous.
origin: Italian, literally, beautiful lady

definition: a bright star of the second magnitude in the constellation Orion.
sentence: Looking through my telescope, I found Bellatrix, which is a very bright star in the constellation Orion.

definition: of a mild type or character that does not threaten health or life; especially : not becoming cancerous
sentence: The doctor told the boy that the bump on his arm was benign, which means it wasn't dangerous at all.
origin: Middle English benigne, from Anglo-French, from Latin benignus, from bene + gignere to beget

definition: blessing, benediction
sentence: The rain was a great benison to the farmers whose crops were getting very thirsty.
origin: Middle English beneson, from Anglo-French beneiçon, from Late Latin benediction-, benedictio

definition: to give or leave by will —used especially of personal property
sentence: The elderly woman decided to bequeath her large collection of books to the town library.
origin: Middle English bequethen, from Old English becwethan, from be- + cwethan to say

definition: a member of any of various peoples living in northern Africa west of Tripoli
sentence: We saw a beautiful Berber rug that was woven by hand by people from North Africa.
origin: ultimately from Arabic barbar

definition: the state or fact of being bereaved or deprived of something or someone
sentence: The family received many kind cards during their time of bereavement after their pet passed away.
origin: see

definition: a visorless usually woolen cap with a tight headband and a soft full flat top
sentence: Maya wore a bright red beret on her head that made her look like a professional artist.
origin: French béret, from Gascon berret, from Old Occitan, cap

definition: bermuda shorts
sentence: On the first day of summer, I put on my favorite blue bermudas to stay cool at the park.

definition: to beg for urgently or anxiously
sentence: The kittens seemed to beseech their owner for another treat by meowing very softly.
origin: Middle English besechen, from be- + sechen to seek

definition: to surround with armed forces
sentence: The castle was besieged by an army that surrounded the walls so no one could get out.

definition: to cause harm or damage to the purity, luster, or beauty of (something) : sully, soil
sentence: You shouldn't tell lies about your friends because it could besmirch their good reputation.

definition: unincorporated population center in Maryland, a northern suburb of Washington, D.C. population 60,858
sentence: In old stories, a bethesda is often described as a place where people go to get healed.

definition: a card game similar to pinochle that is played with a pack of 64 cards
sentence: Grandpa taught me how to play bezique, which is a fun card game for two people.
origin: French bésique

definition: the art of binding books
sentence: A bibliopegist is a person who is an expert at binding books and making them look beautiful.
origin: ultimately from Greek bibli- + pēgnynai to fasten together

definition: having, consisting of, or based on two legislative chambers
sentence: Our government is bicameral, which means it is made up of two different groups of lawmakers.
origin: + Late Latin camera chamber

definition: to cause to divide into two branches or parts
sentence: The hiking trail started to bifurcate, so we had to choose between the left path or the right path.
origin: Medieval Latin bifurcatus, past participle of bifurcare, from Latin bifurcus two-pronged, from bi- + furca fork

definition: any animal exhibiting bilateral symmetry, having a front, back, top, and bottom.
sentence: Most animals are bilaterian, which means their left side looks just like their right side.

definition: a long bar of iron with sliding shackles used to confine the feet of prisoners especially on shipboard
sentence: In the museum, we saw an old bilbo, which is a long sword used by sailors many years ago.
origin: perhaps from Bilboa, Spain

definition: a blind channel leading out from a river
sentence: In the Australian outback, animals gather to drink water at a quiet billabong.
origin: Wiradhuri (Australian aboriginal language of central New South Wales) bilabaŋ

definition: a brief letter : note
sentence: Each soldier received a billet that told them exactly which house they would be staying in.
origin: Middle English bylet, from Anglo-French billette, diminutive of bille bill

definition: coarsely abusive language
sentence: The teacher told the students that using billingsgate, or mean language, is not allowed in class.
origin: Billingsgate, old gate and fish market, London, England

definition: jerked meat
sentence: While visiting South Africa, we tried biltong, which is a snack made of dried, seasoned meat.
origin: Afrikaans, from bil rump + tong tongue

definition: a mathematical expression consisting of two terms connected by a plus sign or minus sign
sentence: In math class, we learned that a binomial is an expression that has exactly two parts.
origin: New Latin binomium, from Medieval Latin, neuter of binomius having two names, alteration of Latin binominis, from bi- + nomin-, nomen name

definition: the design and production of materials or systems modeled on biological entities.
sentence: Designing a train to look like a bird's beak is an example of biomimicry in engineering.

definition: a Mexican dish of stewed meat seasoned especially with chili peppers
sentence: We went to a food truck to get birria tacos, which are filled with delicious, slow-cooked meat.
origin: borrowed from Mexican Spanish, from Spanish, "thing of no consequence, trash," earlier "obstinacy, tantrum, whim," perhaps going back to Vulgar Latin *verrea, derivative of Latin verrēs "uncastrated male pig, boar," going back to Indo-European *u̯ers-ēn- "male of an animal" (in Latin restructured from a presumed nominative singular *werrēn), whence also, with varying ablaut, Sanskrit vŕṣan- "manly, mighty," (as noun) "male of an animal," Avestan varəšna- "manly," Ossetic wyrs- (Iron dialect), urs- (Digor dialect) "stallion," Lithuanian ver͂šis "calf, bull"

definition: any of various small or medium-sized, short-necked, usually secretive herons (especially genera Botaurus and Ixobrychus)
sentence: The bittern is a shy bird that hides in the tall grass and makes a very loud booming sound.
origin: Middle English bitoure, from Anglo-French butor, from Vulgar Latin *butitaurus, from Latin buteo hawk + taurus bull

definition: a mass of undifferentiated cells capable of growth and differentiation
sentence: The scientist explained that a blastema is a group of cells that helps a lizard grow back its tail.
origin: borrowed from Greek blástēma "shoot, offshoot," from blastē-, variant stem of blastánein, aorist blasteîn "to bud, sprout, grow" + -ma, resultative noun suffix

definition: reproduction by budding; also the transformation of small lymphocytes into larger cells.
sentence: We studied blastogenesis to learn how some tiny creatures can grow a whole new body from a small bud.

definition: noisy especially in a vulgar or offensive manner : clamorous
sentence: The player made a blatant foul by grabbing the other student's jersey right in front of the coach.
origin: perhaps from Latin blatire to chatter

definition: a thin usually wheat-flour pancake folded to form a casing (as for cheese or fruit) and then sautéed or baked
sentence: My grandmother makes the best cheese blintzes, which are like thin pancakes rolled with sweet filling.
origin: Yiddish blintse, of Slavic origin; akin to Ukrainian mlynets', diminutive of mlyn pancake

definition: to speak or write verbosely and windily
sentence: The character in the book loved to bloviate, talking for a long time without saying anything important.
origin: perhaps irregular from

definition: a storehouse for maturing wine
sentence: We stopped at the corner bodega to buy some fresh fruit and a cold bottle of water.
origin: Spanish, from Latin apotheca storehouse

definition: dagger, stiletto
sentence: The tailor used a bodkin, which is a large needle, to pull the ribbon through the hem of the dress.
origin: Middle English bodekin

definition: a scientific expert; especially : one involved in technological research
sentence: My brother is a real computer boffin because he knows how to fix any glitch in a video game.
origin: origin unknown

definition: a panel or paneling of carved wood
sentence: The walls of the palace were decorated with boiserie, which are beautiful carved wooden panels.
origin: borrowed from French, from bois "grove, forest, wood (the material)" (going back to Old French bois, bos, bosc, going back to Old Low Franconian *boska- "shrub," going back to Germanic, by-form of *buska- "shrub, thicket") + -erie

definition: noisily turbulent : rowdy
sentence: The classroom became very boisterous when the teacher announced that it was time for recess.
origin: Middle English boistous crude, clumsy, from Anglo-French

definition: the basic monetary unit of Venezuela
sentence: When we went to Venezuela, we used the bolivar as the type of money to buy snacks.
origin: American Spanish bolívar, from Simón Bolívar

definition: authentic, true, or real : genuine
sentence: The museum confirmed that the dinosaur bone was a bona fide fossil and not a plastic model.
origin: Latin, literally, in good faith

definition: a rare great ape (Pan paniscus) that has a more slender build and longer limbs than the related common chimpanzee (P. troglodytes) and that inhabits a small geographic region in equatorial Africa south of the Congo River —called also pygmy chimpanzee
sentence: At the zoo, we watched a bonobo use a stick as a tool to reach some honey.
origin: origin unknown

definition: a large, venomous green tree snake of sub-Saharan Africa.
sentence: The guide pointed out a green boomslang snake hiding perfectly among the tree leaves.

definition: a braided cord worn by Boy Scouts as a neckerchief slide, hatband, or ornament
sentence: The long, unnecessary meeting turned out to be a total boondoggle that wasted everyone's afternoon.
origin: coined by Robert H. Link †1957 American scoutmaster

definition: of, relating to, or located in northern regions
sentence: Animals like moose and wolves are common in the chilly boreal forests of the north.
origin: Middle English boriall, from Late Latin borealis, from Latin boreas north wind, north, from Greek, from Boreas

definition: a silicate containing boron in the anion and occurring naturally
sentence: The scientist used borosilicate glass for the test tubes because it doesn't crack when it gets hot.
origin: International Scientific Vocabulary

definition: a medieval fortified group of houses forming a town with special duties and privileges
sentence: New York City is made up of five different areas, and each one is called a borough.
origin: Middle English burgh, from Old English burg fortified town; akin to Old High German burg fortified place, and probably to Old English beorg hill

definition: the studio or workshop of a major artist in which apprentices are trained.
sentence: We visited a small bottega in Italy where an artist was hand-painting beautiful ceramic bowls.

definition: puffed out
sentence: In the old photograph, my grandmother had a very puffy bouffant hairstyle.
origin: French, from Middle French, from present participle of bouffer to puff

definition: a large spar projecting forward from the stem of a ship
sentence: The pirate ship had a long wooden pole called a bowsprit sticking out from the very front.
origin: Middle English bouspret, probably from Middle Low German boochspreet, from booch bow + spreet pole

definition: a two-masted fishing vessel used in the Adriatic Sea.
sentence: While in Venice, we saw a bragozzo, which is a traditional fishing boat with colorful sails.

definition: a system of writing for people who are blind that uses characters made up of raised dots
sentence: Books written in braille have raised dots so that people who are blind can read with their fingers.
origin: Louis Braille

definition: relating to the architectural style of Donato Bramante, characterized by classical purity and dignity.
sentence: The tall arches and round domes of the building gave it a very classic Bramantesque style.

definition: blustering swaggering conduct
sentence: Even though he was scared of the dark, Leo walked into the cave with a lot of bravado.
origin: Middle French bravade & Old Spanish bravata, from Old Italian bravata, from bravare to challenge, show off, from bravo

definition: briefness or conciseness in speech or writing.
sentence: The principal's speech was full of breviloquence, meaning she was very brief and got straight to the point.

definition: a place that is idyllic, unaffected by time, or remote from reality
sentence: The play we watched was about Brigadoon, a magical village that only appears once every hundred years.
origin: from Brigadoon, village in the musical Brigadoon (1947) by A. J. Lerner and F. Loewe

definition: a vegetable that is a hybrid between broccoli and Chinese broccoli.
sentence: For dinner, we had roasted Broccolini, which looks like tiny broccoli with long, thin stems.

definition: an imperfectly minted coin
sentence: The coin collector showed me a brockage, which is a rare coin that was stamped incorrectly at the factory.
origin: English dialect brock rubbish + English -age

definition: a stout coarse shoe worn formerly in Ireland and the Scottish Highlands
sentence: My uncle grew up in Ireland, so he speaks with a very lovely Irish brogue.
origin: Irish bróg & Scottish Gaelic bròg, from Middle Irish bróc, probably from Old Norse brōk leg covering; akin to Old English brōc leg covering

definition: a binary compound of bromine with another element or a radical including some (such as potassium bromide) used as sedatives
sentence: Saying 'everything happens for a reason' is a common bromide that people say to try and be helpful.

definition: an abnormal fear of thunder.
sentence: Because of her brontophobia, the little girl always hides under her blankets during a thunderstorm.

definition: a witch or female sorcerer.
sentence: In the folk tale, the village children were afraid of the mysterious bruja who lived in the woods.

definition: the habit of unconsciously gritting or grinding the teeth especially in situations of stress or during sleep
sentence: The dentist noticed that the boy had bruxism because his teeth showed signs of grinding at night.
origin: irregular from Greek brychein to gnash the teeth + English -ism

definition: an inflammatory swelling of a lymph gland especially in the groin
sentence: We learned in history class that the bubonic plague was a very famous sickness from a long time ago.
origin: Medieval Latin bubon-, bubo, from Greek boubōn

definition: an 18th century farcical comic opera with dialogue in recitative
sentence: The school choir performed an opera buffa, which is a funny type of play with lots of singing.
origin: Italian, literally, comic opera

definition: a Korean dish of thinly sliced beef marinated and grilled.
sentence: We went to a Korean restaurant and ordered bulgogi, which is delicious thin slices of grilled beef.

definition: parched cracked wheat
sentence: My mom made a healthy salad using bulgur, which is a type of cereal grain made from wheat.
origin: Turkish

definition: a solid wall-like structure raised for defense : rampart
sentence: The heavy sandbags acted as a bulwark to keep the river water from flooding the town.
origin: Middle English bulwerke, from Middle Dutch bolwerc, from bolle tree trunk + werc work

definition: —used for a cake pan having a tube in the center and scalloped sides
sentence: For the bake sale, we made a lemon cake in a special Bundt pan that has a hole in the middle.

definition: a one-storied house with a low-pitched roof; also : a house having one and a half stories and usually a front porch
sentence: My grandparents live in a cozy bungalow that has all its rooms on just one floor.
origin: Hindi baṅglā & Urdu banglā, literally, (house) in the Bengal style

definition: the tendency of a body to float or to rise when submerged in a fluid
sentence: The life jacket provides enough buoyancy to keep you floating safely in the pool.
origin: see

definition: writing desk; especially : one having drawers and a slant top
sentence: I keep my socks and t-shirts neatly folded inside the top drawer of my wooden bureau.
origin: French, desk, cloth covering for desks, from Old French burel woolen cloth, from Old French *bure, from Late Latin burra shaggy cloth

definition: the crime of entering a structure (such as a house or commercial building) with the intent to commit a felony (such as theft)
sentence: The detective looked for any burglarious signs, like a broken lock or an open window.

definition: oatmeal gruel
sentence: At the town festival, we ate a big bowl of burgoo, which is a thick stew made with many vegetables.
origin: origin unknown

definition: a military full-dress fur hat with a pendent bag on one side usually of the color of regimental facings
sentence: The palace guard wore a very tall, fuzzy black hat called a busby.
origin: probably from the name Busby

definition: a shop selling wines and liquors
sentence: The talented dancers performed a lively cabaret show with colorful costumes and fast music.
origin: French, from Middle French dialect (Picard or Walloon), from Middle Dutch, alteration of cambret, cameret, from Middle French dialect (Picard) camberete small room, ultimately from Late Latin camera

definition: a town council or the building in which it meets in Spanish-speaking countries.
sentence: In history, we saw a picture of a cabildo, which was an important town hall in Spanish colonies.
