definition: a dried, fermented, fatty seed of the fruit of a South American evergreen tree (Theobroma cacao of the family Malvaceae) that is used in making cocoa, chocolate, and cocoa butter : cocoa bean
sentence: The farmer showed us how they take the seeds from the cacao pod to eventually make chocolate.
origin: Spanish, from Nahuatl cacahuatl

definition: marked by cacophony : harsh-sounding
sentence: The room became cacophonous when all thirty students started playing their recorders at once.
origin: borrowed from New Latin cacophōnus (borrowed from Greek kakóphōnos "disagreeable-sounding," from kako-  + -phōnos "having a sound [of the kind specified]," adjective derivative of phōnḗ "sound made by something living, voice, speech") +

definition: to obtain (something) for free often by persuading or imposing on another : sponge; also : to take, use, or borrow (something) without acknowledgment
sentence: The little dog would always try to cadge a piece of crust whenever someone was eating pizza.
origin: back-formation from Scots cadger carrier, huckster, from Middle English cadgear

definition: the symbolic staff of a herald; specifically : a representation of a staff with two entwined snakes and two wings at the top
sentence: In the doctor's office, I saw a symbol of a caduceus, which is a staff with two snakes wrapped around it.
origin: Latin, modification of Greek karykeion, from karyx, kēryx herald; akin to Sanskrit kāru singer

definition: the quality of being transitory or perishable
sentence: The old building showed signs of caducity, with crumbling bricks and a sagging roof.
origin: probably borrowed from French caducité dilapidation, senility, going back to Middle French, from caduc on the verge of collapsing, dilapidated (borrowed from Latin cadūcus on the verge of collapsing, unsteady, transitory) + -ité

definition: a usually cotton or silk ankle-length garment with long sleeves that is common throughout the Middle East
sentence: On the hot summer day, my aunt wore a loose, flowy caftan to stay cool and comfortable.
origin: Russian & Turkish; Russian kaftan, from Turkish, from Persian qaftān

definition: a tarsal bone that in humans is the large bone of the heel
sentence: The doctor checked my calcaneus, which is the large bone that makes up the heel of my foot.
origin: Late Latin, heel, alteration of Latin calcaneum

definition: to make calcareous by deposit of calcium salts
sentence: Over time, the soft parts of the shell can calcify and turn into a hard, stony material.

definition: any of a small genus (Calendula) of yellow-rayed composite herbs of temperate regions
sentence: We planted bright orange calendula flowers in the garden to attract butterflies.
origin: borrowed from New Latin Calendula, genus name, probably borrowed from Italian calendola "the plant Calendula officinalis," from calenda "first day of the month" (borrowed from Latin Kalendae ) + -ola, diminutive suffix

definition: lacking adult sophistication : immature
sentence: The callow young bird was still learning how to flap its wings and fly to the nearest branch.
origin: Middle English calu bald, from Old English; akin to Old High German kalo bald, Old Church Slavic golŭ bare

definition: a highly ornamented ceremonial pipe used by some Indigenous American peoples
sentence: In our history book, we learned that a calumet was a special pipe used by Native Americans during ceremonies.
origin: American French, from French dialect, pipe stem, from Late Latin calamellus, diminutive of Latin calamus reed

definition: a sea nymph in Homer's Odyssey who keeps Odysseus seven years on the island of Ogygia
sentence: The band played a happy calypso song that made everyone want to dance and clap their hands.
origin: Latin, from Greek Kalypsō

definition: a place where money is exchanged.
sentence: When we crossed the border, we looked for a cambio to exchange our money for the local currency.

definition: a person who carves cameos.
sentence: The cameist used a tiny tool to carve a beautiful portrait into a small piece of gemstone.

definition: the art of bell ringing
sentence: Someone who studies campanology knows everything there is to know about how bells are made and rung.
origin: New Latin campanologia, from Late Latin campana + New Latin -o- + -logia -logy

definition: a Spanish song, especially one of a lyrical nature.
sentence: The singer performed a beautiful Spanish cancion that told a story about a hidden garden.

definition: candelabra
sentence: The dining table was decorated with a large golden candelabrum that held five tall candles.
origin: borrowed from Latin candēlābrum "stand for holding candles or lamps," from candēla  + -ā-brum, variant (after stems with an -l-) of -bulum, suffix of instruments (going back to Indo-European *-dhlom); -ā- by analogy with deverbative derivatives

definition: a deep-fried tube of pastry filled with sweetened and flavored ricotta cheese
sentence: For my birthday treat, we bought a box of cannoli filled with sweet, creamy cheese.
origin: Italian, plural of cannolo small tube, diminutive of canna

definition: a star of the first magnitude in the constellation Carina not visible north of 37° latitude
sentence: Canopus is a very bright star that sailors used a long time ago to help find their way at night.
origin: Latin, from Greek Kanōpos

definition: habitually angry or annoyed
sentence: The old mule was being cantankerous and refused to walk no matter how much we pulled.
origin: perhaps irregular from obsolete contack contention

definition: resembling a hair especially in slender elongated form
sentence: A capillary is a tiny blood vessel that is even thinner than a single strand of your hair.
origin: French or Latin; French capillaire, from Latin capillaris, from capillus hair

definition: a monitoring device that measures and numerically displays the concentration of carbon dioxide in exhaled air
sentence: The nurse used a capnometer to measure how much carbon dioxide the patient was breathing out.
origin: capno- (in ) + -meter

definition: governed or characterized by sudden irrational and unpredictable impulses or whims : impulsive; broadly : unpredictable, erratic
sentence: The weather was very capricious today, changing from sunny to rainy five different times.
origin: borrowed from Middle French capricieux, borrowed from Italian capriccioso, from capriccio  + -oso

definition: a machine for moving or raising heavy weights that consists of a vertical drum which can be rotated and around which cable is turned
sentence: The sailors turned the heavy capstan to pull the thick ropes and lift the heavy anchor.
origin: Middle English, probably from Middle French cabestant

definition: a membrane or sac enclosing a body part (such as a knee joint or kidney)
sentence: We put our favorite drawings and toys into a time capsule to be opened twenty years from now.
origin: French, from Latin capsula, diminutive of capsa box

definition: any of various neutral compounds of carbon, hydrogen, and oxygen (such as sugars, starches, and celluloses) most of which are formed by green plants and which constitute a major class of animal foods
sentence: Foods like bread, pasta, and potatoes are full of carbohydrates that give our bodies energy.

definition: a dead body : corpse; especially : the dressed body of a meat animal
sentence: The vultures circled in the sky when they spotted the carcass of a fallen deer in the field.
origin: Middle English carcays, from Anglo-French carcas, carkeis

definition: a large perennial Mediterranean plant (Cynara cardunculus) related to the artichoke and cultivated for its edible root and stalks; also : the root and petioles
sentence: The cardoon looks like a giant celery plant, but it is actually related to the artichoke.
origin: French cardon, from Late Latin cardon-, cardo thistle, from cardus, from Latin carduus thistle, cardoon

definition: a wedge-shaped mark made on written or printed matter to indicate the place where something is to be inserted
sentence: When editing my essay, the teacher used a small caret symbol to show where I forgot a word.
origin: Latin, there is lacking, from carēre to lack, be without

definition: a large gregarious deer (Rangifer tarandus) of Holarctic taiga and tundra that usually has palmate antlers in both sexes —used especially for one of the New World—called also reindeer
sentence: In the snowy tundra, we saw a herd of caribou with their large, branching antlers.
origin: earlier caribo, borrowed from Micmac qalipu (phonetically ɣalibu, 17th-18th-century *ɣaribu), agentive derivative of qalipi- "shovel snow," going back to proto-Algonquian *maka·lipi-; so called from its habit of scraping aside snow with its front feet in search of food

definition: exaggeration by means of often ludicrous distortion of parts or characteristics
sentence: At the fair, an artist drew a funny caricature of me with a giant nose and tiny ears.
origin: Italian caricatura, literally, act of loading, from caricare to load, from Late Latin carricare

definition: the flesh of slain animals or humans
sentence: The superhero tried to stop the carnage and keep the city streets safe from the giant robot.
origin: French, from Medieval Latin carnaticum tribute consisting of animals or meat, from Latin carn-, caro see

definition: of, relating to, or being a tooth of a carnivore often larger and longer than adjacent teeth and adapted for cutting rather than tearing
sentence: The tiger used its sharp carnassial teeth to easily bite through the meat of its dinner.
origin: French carnassier carnivorous, ultimately from Latin carn-, caro

definition: small chunks or strips of meat and especially pork that are fried or roasted until crisp and are sometimes served in a burrito or taco
sentence: I love eating tacos filled with carnitas, which is slow-cooked pork that is very tender.
origin: borrowed from Mexican Spanish, plural of carnita, diminutive of Spanish carne "meat," going back to Latin carn, carō "flesh, meat"

definition: a quaternary ammonium compound C7H15NO3 that is present especially in vertebrate muscle, that in the levorotatory form is involved in the transfer of fatty acids across mitochondrial membranes, and in humans is obtained from food (such as meat or milk) or is synthesized chiefly in the liver and kidneys from a lysine derivative
sentence: Our science book mentioned that carnitine is a substance that helps our cells turn fat into energy.
origin: International Scientific Vocabulary, from Latin carn-, caro

definition: of or relating to René Descartes or his philosophy
sentence: In math, we used a Cartesian coordinate system to plot points on a graph using x and y lines.
origin: New Latin cartesianus, from Cartesius Descartes

definition: a usually translucent somewhat elastic tissue that composes most of the skeleton of vertebrate embryos and except for a small number of structures (such as some joints, respiratory passages, and the external ear) is replaced by bone during ossification in the higher vertebrates
sentence: Your ears and the tip of your nose are made of cartilage, which is tougher than skin but softer than bone.
origin: Middle English, from Latin cartilagin-, cartilago

definition: a daughter of Priam endowed with the gift of prophecy but fated never to be believed
sentence: In the old myth, Cassandra was a girl who could tell the future, but no one ever believed her.
origin: Latin, from Greek Kassandra

definition: a close-fitting ankle-length garment worn especially in Roman Catholic and Anglican churches by the clergy and by laypersons assisting in services
sentence: The choir boy wore a long black robe called a cassock during the holiday concert.
origin: Middle French casaque

definition: having battlements like a castle
sentence: The top of the castle wall was castellated, with square cutouts for guards to look through.
origin: Medieval Latin castellatus, past participle of castellare to fortify, from Latin castellum

definition: to subject to severe punishment, reproof, or criticism
sentence: The coach had to castigate the players for not following the safety rules during practice.
origin: borrowed from Latin castīgātus, past participle of castīgāre "to discipline for a fault or lapse, reprove, censure," perhaps from *casti-, stem of *castis "reprimand" (going back to Indo-European *ḱHs-ti-, whence also Sanskrit śiṣṭi- "instruction") + *-ig-, going back to Indo-European -h2ǵ-, zero-grade of *h2eǵ- "drive, impel, lead"

definition: a native or inhabitant of Castile; broadly : spaniard
sentence: My teacher explained that the official type of Spanish spoken in Spain is called Castilian.

definition: beaver
sentence: My mom put a little bit of castor oil on the squeaky hinge to make the door open quietly.
origin: Middle English, from Latin, from Greek kastōr, from Kastōr Castor

definition: living in fresh water and going to the sea to spawn
sentence: A catadromous fish, like some eels, lives in fresh water but swims to the ocean to lay its eggs.
origin: probably from New Latin catadromus, from cata- + -dromus -dromous

definition: a trancelike state marked by loss of voluntary motion in which the limbs remain in whatever position they are placed
sentence: The scientist studied catalepsy, a condition where a person's muscles become very stiff and they can't move.
origin: Middle English catalempsi, from Medieval Latin catalepsia, from Late Latin catalepsis, from Greek katalēpsis, literally, act of seizing, from katalambanein to seize, from kata- + lambanein to take

definition: island in southwestern California; one of the Channel Islands area 70 square miles (182 square kilometers)
sentence: We took a boat ride to visit the beautiful island of Catalina off the coast of California.

definition: a person or thing that provokes or speeds significant change or action
sentence: In the science experiment, adding the vinegar was the catalyst that made the baking soda erupt.
origin: see

definition: to invest with mental or emotional energy
sentence: The boy started to cathect his new puppy, spending every spare minute playing and bonding with him.
origin: back-formation from cathectic

definition: the electrode of an electrochemical cell at which reduction occurs:
sentence: In our circuit experiment, we had to connect the wire to the cathode, which is the negative side.
origin: Greek kathodos way down, from kata- + hodos way

definition: a hybrid animal resulting from a cross between a domestic cow and a bison.
sentence: The farmer showed us a cattalo, which is a unique animal that is half cow and half buffalo.

definition: a type of rubber obtained from a South American tree.
sentence: Long ago, people in the rainforest collected caucho from trees to make natural rubber bouncy balls.

definition: the stem of a palm or tree fern
sentence: The desert plant has a thick, woody caudex at its base to help it store water.
origin: Latin, tree trunk or stem

definition: expressing or indicating cause : causative
sentence: The teacher explained the causal link between not studying and getting a low grade on the quiz.
origin: borrowed from Late Latin causālis, from Latin causa  + -ālis

definition: capable of destroying or eating away by chemical action : corrosive
sentence: The cleaner was very caustic, so my dad had to wear gloves to protect his skin.
origin: Latin causticus, from Greek kaustikos, from kaiein to burn

definition: to sear with a cautery or caustic
sentence: The doctor had to cauterize the small wound to stop the bleeding and help it heal.
origin: see

definition: a procession of riders or carriages
sentence: The parade featured a magnificent cavalcade of horses and riders dressed in shiny armor.
origin: borrowed from French, going back to Middle French, probably borrowed from Italian cavalcata "journey made by horse, group riding horseback, procession of riders accompanying a distinguished person, or formed on the occasion of a ceremony," from cavalcare "to ride horseback" (going back to Late Latin caballicāre, from Latin caballus "work horse, gelding" + Latin -icāre, verb formative) + -ata, suffix of action and result; caballus, of obscure origin, perhaps a loanword from a language of the Balkans or Anatolia

definition: cayenne pepper
sentence: My dad added a tiny pinch of cayenne pepper to the soup to give it a little bit of heat.

definition: regenerated cellulose in thin transparent sheets used especially for packaging
sentence: The gift basket was wrapped in clear, crinkly cellophane and tied with a big red ribbon.
origin: French, from cellulose + -phane (as in diaphane diaphanous, from Medieval Latin diaphanus)

definition: relating to, conforming to, or having the international thermometric scale on which the interval between the triple point of water and the boiling point of water is divided into 99.99 degrees with 0.01° representing the triple point and 100° the boiling point; also : centigrade —abbreviation C
sentence: When we visited Canada, the thermometer showed the temperature in degrees Celsius instead of Fahrenheit.
origin: Anders Celsius

definition: a tomb or a monument erected in honor of a person or group of persons whose remains are elsewhere
sentence: The stone monument is a cenotaph built to honor the soldiers who never came home from the war.
origin: French cénotaphe, from Latin cenotaphium, from Greek kenotaphion, from kenos empty + taphos tomb

definition: any of a race of creatures fabled to be half human and half horse and to live in the mountains of Thessaly
sentence: In the fantasy book, a centaur is a creature that is half human and half horse.
origin: Middle English, from Latin Centaurus, from Greek Kentauros

definition: a 100th anniversary or its celebration
sentence: The town had a huge celebration for its centennial, which marks its one-hundredth birthday.
origin: Latin centum + English -ennial (as in biennial)

definition: to guarantee or make certain over a period of one hundred years.
sentence: The mayor wanted to centennialassure the citizens that the city's 100-year history would be honored with a grand festival.

definition: a 3-headed dog that in Greek mythology guards the entrance to Hades
sentence: In Greek myths, Cerberus is a giant dog with three heads that guards the entrance to the underworld.
origin: Latin, from Greek Kerberos

definition: a large dorsally projecting part of the brain concerned especially with the coordination of muscles and the maintenance of bodily equilibrium, situated between the brain stem and the back of the cerebrum, and formed in humans of two lateral lobes and a median lobe
sentence: The cerebellum is the part of your brain that helps you balance and stay steady on your feet.
origin: Medieval Latin, from Latin, diminutive of cerebrum

definition: the Roman goddess of agriculture
sentence: Ceres is the largest object in the asteroid belt and is now considered a dwarf planet.
origin: Latin Cerer-, Cerēs, probably personified noun derivative going back to an Indo-European adjective *ḱerh3-ḗs "of grain," derivative of *ḱérh3-o/es "nourishment, grain," derivative of a verbal base *ḱerh3- "feed, fill, satisfy," whence also Greek koréō "(I) will satiate, fill," Lithuanian šeriù, šérti "to feed," Germanic *hersija- "of grain" (whence Old Saxon hirsi "millet," Old High German hirso, hirsi)

definition: the Spanish word for cherry.
sentence: In my Spanish class, I learned that cereza is the word for a bright red cherry.

definition: a branch of zoology concerned with the cetaceans
sentence: If you love whales and dolphins, you might want to study cetology when you grow up.
origin: Latin cetus whale

definition: island 270 miles (434 kilometers) long and 140 miles (225 kilometers) wide in the Indian Ocean off southern India
sentence: My grandmother still calls the island of Sri Lanka by its old name, which was Ceylon.

definition: a family-controlled industrial conglomerate in South Korea
sentence: The teacher explained that a chaebol is a very large family-owned business in South Korea.
origin: Korean chaebŏl, from chae wealth, property + pŏl faction, clan

definition: an attendant on a sovereign or lord in his bedchamber
sentence: The king's chamberlain was in charge of managing everything inside the royal palace.
origin: Middle English chaumberlein, caumberleyn, borrowed from Anglo-French chamberlein, chamberlenc (continental Old French cambrelenc, chamberlent), going back to Old Low Franconian *kamerling- "servant, steward" (cognate with Middle Dutch kamerlinc, Middle Low German kemerlinc, Old High German kemerlinc, chamerling), from *kamera "room, chamber" (borrowed from Late Latin camera) + *-ling-

definition: a perennial composite herb (Chamaemelum nobile synonym Anthemis nobilis) of Europe and North Africa with aromatic foliage and flower heads
sentence: Before bed, my mom drinks a cup of chamomile tea to help her feel calm and sleepy.
origin: Middle English camemille, from Medieval Latin camomilla, modification of Latin chamaemelon, from Greek chamaimēlon, from chamai + mēlon apple

definition: a member of a people of the Mariana Islands
sentence: The Chamorro people have a rich history and culture on the beautiful island of Guam.
origin: borrowed from Spanish chamorro, probably borrowed from Chamorro chamorri "member of the highest social class in precolonial Chamorro society"

definition: calcined clay that is crushed and used as an ingredient in ceramics.
sentence: The potter mixed some chamotte into the clay to make sure the bowl wouldn't crack in the oven.

definition: the secretary of a nobleman, prince, or king
sentence: The chancellor of the university gave a speech to the students during the graduation ceremony.
origin: Middle English chanceler, from Anglo-French, from Late Latin cancellarius doorkeeper, secretary, from cancellus

definition: escort
sentence: Under the teacher's chaperonage, the entire third-grade class visited the natural history museum.
origin: see

definition: a delicatessen specializing in dressed meats and meat dishes; also : the products sold in such a shop
sentence: For the party, we put together a charcuterie board with different meats, cheeses, and crackers.
origin: French, literally, pork-butcher's shop, from Middle French chaircuiterie, from chaircutier pork butcher, from chair cuite cooked meat

definition: having, exhibiting, or based on charisma or charism
sentence: The lead singer was so charismatic that everyone in the audience was smiling and dancing.
origin: charisma

definition: quack
sentence: The man pretending to be a doctor was actually a charlatan who didn't know anything about medicine.
origin: Italian ciarlatano, alteration of cerretano, literally, inhabitant of Cerreto, from Cerreto, Italy

definition: a large country house or castle in France.
sentence: While visiting France, we saw a beautiful château that looked like a castle from a fairy tale.

definition: a woman's one-piece undergarment
sentence: In the historical museum, we saw a simple white chemise that people wore as an undershirt long ago.
origin: borrowed from French, going back to Old French cheminse, chamisae "tunic-like garment worn directly against the skin," going back to Late Latin camīsia, perhaps borrowed from a continental Celtic word borrowed from West Germanic *hamiþja- (whence Old English hemeþe "undergarment, tunic, shirt," Old Frisian hemethe, hemede, hamed, Old Saxon hemithi, Old High German hemidi), derivative, with the dental suffix *-iþja-, of Germanic *hama- or *haman- "shape, human form, covering" (whence Old English hama [masculine weak noun] "covering, womb, afterbirth, slough of a snake," Old Norse hamr "skin, shape (assumed by a supernatural entity)," and in compounds Old Frisian līkhoma, lichama "body, corpse," Old Saxon gūthhamo "battle shirt," līkhamo "body, corpse," Old High German gundhamo, līhnamo), of uncertain origin

definition: a broadly grinning cat in Lewis Carroll's Alice's Adventures in Wonderland
sentence: In the story, the Cheshire cat slowly faded away until only its wide grin was left.
origin: Cheshire, England

definition: cavalier
sentence: The brave chevalier rode his horse into the village to protect the people from the dragon.
origin: borrowed from French, "knight, young nobleman who has devoted himself to a lady, member of an order conferring knighthood or another honor," going back to Old French chevaler, chevalier "mounted soldier, knight," going back to Late Latin caballārius "horseback rider, groom" (early Medieval Latin also "serf performing duties on horseback, mounted soldier")

definition: state of southeastern Mexico bordering on the Pacific and on Guatemala; capital Tuxtla Gutiérrez area 28,528 square miles (73,888 square kilometers), population 4,796,580
sentence: Chiapas is a state in Mexico known for its beautiful rainforests and ancient ruins.

definition: to speak out in angry or displeased rebuke
sentence: My dad had to gently chide me for forgetting to hang up my wet towel after my bath.
origin: Middle English, from Old English cīdan to quarrel, chide, from cīd strife

definition: any of a breed of very small roundheaded dogs that occur in short-coated and long-coated varieties
sentence: Even though he is a tiny Chihuahua, my dog thinks he is as big and brave as a lion.
origin: Mexican Spanish, from Chihuahua, Mexico

definition: a fire-breathing female monster in Greek mythology having a lion's head, a goat's body, and a serpent's tail
sentence: In Greek mythology, a chimera is a strange monster that has a lion's head, a goat's body, and a snake's tail.
origin: Latin chimaera, from Greek chimaira she-goat, chimera; akin to Old Norse gymbr yearling ewe, Greek cheimōn winter

definition: a member of an Indigenous people of the north shore of the Columbia River at its mouth
sentence: The warm chinook wind blew down from the mountains and melted all the snow in just one afternoon.
origin: Lower Chehalis (Salishan language of western Washington) c̓inúk, name of a Chinook village

definition: decorated with or as if with chintz
sentence: The cheap plastic toy felt a bit chintzy and broke almost as soon as I took it out of the box.

definition: any of several diseases of humans and domestic animals usually marked by severe gastrointestinal symptoms; especially : an acute diarrheal disease caused by an enterotoxin produced by a comma-shaped gram-negative bacillus (Vibrio cholerae synonym V. comma) when it is present in large numbers in the proximal part of the human small intestine
sentence: Long ago, many people got sick with cholera because they didn't have clean water to drink.
origin: borrowed from Latin, acute gastroenteritis, borrowed from Greek choléra

definition: a waxy, fat-like substance C27H46O that is found in the cells, tissues, and body fluids of humans and animals and that serves as a component of cell membranes and functions as a precursor of vitamin D and steroid hormones (such as cortisol and estrogen)
sentence: The doctor told my grandpa to eat more vegetables to help keep his cholesterol at a healthy level.
origin: International Scientific Vocabulary, from chol- + Greek stereos solid

definition: a pupa of a butterfly; broadly : an insect pupa
sentence: We watched the caterpillar build a shiny green chrysalis, where it will turn into a butterfly.
origin: borrowed from Latin chrȳsallid-, chrȳsallis, borrowed from Greek chrȳsallid-, chrȳsallís, from chrȳsós "gold" (referring to the metallic gold-like sheen of some butterfly pupae) + -allid-, -allis, noun suffix of some plant and animal names

definition: olivine
sentence: The jeweler showed us a beautiful green gem called chrysolite that sparkled in the light.
origin: Middle English crisolite "a yellowish gemstone, as topaz," borrowed from Anglo-French, borrowed from Latin chrȳsolithos, borrowed from Greek chrȳsólithos, from chrȳso-  + líthos "stone" (of obscure origin)

definition: a legendary creature said to drink the blood of livestock.
sentence: The campfire story was about the legendary chupacabra, a mysterious creature said to hide in the desert.

definition: a usually excessive or narrowly sectarian attachment to the practices and interests of a particular church
sentence: The author used the word churchianity to describe people who care more about the building than the actual beliefs.
origin: church + -ianity (as in Christianity)

definition: any of a family (Cicadidae) of homopterous insects which have a stout body, wide blunt head, and large transparent wings and the males of which produce a loud buzzing noise usually by stridulation
sentence: In the summer, the loud buzzing of the cicada insects can be heard coming from all the trees.
origin: New Latin, genus name, from Latin, cicada

definition: leaves of coriander used as a flavoring or garnish; also : coriander
sentence: My mom chopped up some fresh cilantro to sprinkle on top of the chicken tacos.
origin: Spanish, coriander, from Medieval Latin celiandrum, alteration of Latin coriandrum

definition: city on the Ohio River in southwestern Ohio population 296,943
sentence: Last summer, my family took a road trip to visit the famous zoo in Cincinnati, Ohio.

definition: being, having, characterized by, or occurring in approximately 24-hour periods or cycles (as of biological activity or function)
sentence: Humans have a circadian rhythm, which is like an internal clock that tells our bodies when to sleep.
origin: Latin circa about + dies day + English

definition: having a circular or winding course
sentence: Because the main road was closed, we had to take a long and circuitous path through the woods.
origin: perhaps from Medieval Latin circuitosus, from Latin circuitus see

definition: characterized by the pitch, quantity, or quality indicated by a circumflex
sentence: In French class, I learned that a circumflex is a little hat-shaped mark that goes over some vowels.
origin: Latin circumflexus, past participle of circumflectere to bend around, mark with a circumflex, from circum- + flectere to bend

definition: belonging to, consisting in, or dependent on circumstances
sentence: The evidence against the cookie thief was only circumstantial, like crumbs being on his shirt.
origin: see

definition: any of various Old World carnivorous viverrid mammals with long bodies, short legs, and a usually long tail
sentence: A civet is a small, cat-like animal from the jungle that has beautiful spots and a long tail.
origin: Middle French civette, from Old Italian zibetto, from Arabic zabād civet perfume

definition: a system of biological taxonomy that defines taxa uniquely by shared characteristics not found in ancestral groups and uses inferred evolutionary relationships to arrange taxa in a branching hierarchy such that all members of a given taxon have the same ancestors
sentence: Scientists use cladistics to group animals together based on the ancestors they share.

definition: a branching diagrammatic tree used in cladistic classification to illustrate phylogenetic relationships
sentence: We drew a cladogram in science class to show how birds and dinosaurs are related to each other.

definition: the power or faculty of discerning objects not present to the senses
sentence: In the movie, the character had the gift of clairvoyance and could see things happening far away.
origin: see

definition: marked by, held in, or conducted with secrecy : surreptitious
sentence: The spies had a clandestine meeting in the park to share their secret messages.
origin: Middle French or Latin; Middle French clandestin, from Latin clandestinus, from clam secretly; akin to Latin celare to hide

definition: a medieval trumpet with clear shrill tones
sentence: The trumpeter gave a clarion call that was so loud and clear it could be heard across the field.
origin: Middle English, from Middle French & Medieval Latin; Middle French clairon, from Medieval Latin clarion-, clario, from Latin clarus

definition: an early keyboard instrument having strings struck by tangents attached directly to the key ends
sentence: Before the piano was invented, people played music on a smaller instrument called a clavichord.
origin: Medieval Latin clavichordium, from Latin clavis key + chorda string

definition: disposition to be merciful and especially to moderate the severity of punishment due
sentence: The king decided to show clemency and let the prisoner go home for the holidays.
origin: see

definition: the closing or limitation of debate in a legislative body especially by calling for a vote
sentence: The senators voted for cloture so they could stop debating and finally vote on the new law.
origin: French clôture, literally, closure, alteration of Middle French closure

definition: to grow together
sentence: Rain happens because of the coalescence of many tiny water droplets in the clouds.
origin: Latin coalescere, from co- + alescere to grow

definition: the act of croaking like a frog.
sentence: The loud coaxation of the bullfrogs by the pond kept us awake during our camping trip.

definition: any of an Asian breed of large domestic chickens with thick plumage, small wings and tail, and densely feathered legs and feet —called also Cochin China
sentence: The cochin chicken is very fluffy and has feathers all the way down to its toes.
origin: Cochin China, part of French Indochina

definition: a hollow tube in the inner ear of higher vertebrates that is usually coiled like a snail shell and contains the sensory organ of hearing
sentence: The doctor explained that the cochlear part of the ear is shaped like a snail shell and helps us hear.
origin: New Latin, from Latin, snail, snail shell, from Greek kochlias, from kochlos snail; probably akin to Greek konchē mussel

definition: words or ideas that are foolish or untrue : nonsense
sentence: When the boy said a giant dragon ate his homework, the teacher said, 'That is total codswallop!'
origin: origin unknown

definition: serving or intended to coerce
sentence: You shouldn't use coercive language to force your friends to do something they don't want to do.

definition: of the same or equal age, antiquity, or duration
sentence: The two giant redwood trees are coeval, meaning they both started growing at the same time.
origin: Late Latin coaevus "of the same age" (from Latin co-  + -aevus, adjective derivative of aevus, aevum "time as the medium in which events occur, age, lifetime") +

definition: appealing forcibly to the mind or reason : convincing
sentence: She argued her point so cogently that the whole class agreed with her idea for the field trip.
origin: borrowed from Latin cōgent-, cōgens, present participle of cōgere "to drive together, gather, compress, force, compel," from co-, variant before a vowel and h of com-  + agere "to drive (cattle), be in motion, do"

definition: the act of cogitating : meditation
sentence: After much cogitation, Leo finally decided that the chocolate cake was his favorite.

definition: knowledgeable of something especially through personal experience; also : mindful
sentence: When walking in the city, you must be cognizant of the traffic and look both ways before crossing.

definition: exhibiting or producing cohesion or coherence
sentence: The team worked together in a cohesive way, which helped them win the championship.
origin: Latin cohaesus, past participle of cohaerēre "to stick together, " +

definition: any of several North American medicinal or poisonous plants: such as
sentence: My grandmother grows black cohosh in her garden, which is a plant with tall spikes of white flowers.
origin: Eastern Abenaki kkʷὰhas

definition: a style or manner of arranging the hair
sentence: The princess spent hours at the salon getting a fancy coiffure for the royal ball.
origin: borrowed from French, going back to Middle French, "head covering, adornment of the hair," from coiffer "to cover with a coif, arrange (hair)" (going back to Old French coiffer, coifer, derivative of coife ) + -ure

definition: an attack of acute abdominal pain localized in a hollow organ and often caused by spasm, obstruction, or twisting
sentence: The baby cried all night because she had colic and her tummy felt very upset.
origin: Middle English, from Medieval Latin colica (passio) intestinal (suffering), from Late Latin colicus of the colon, colicky, from Greek kōlikos, from kōlon, alteration of kolon colon

definition: an associate or coworker in a workplace or profession and often of similar rank or status : a fellow worker or professional
sentence: My dad went to lunch with a colleague from his office to talk about their new project.
origin: Middle French collegue, from Latin collega, from com- + legare to depute

definition: collected writings; also : literary items forming a collection
sentence: The book was a collectanea of short stories and poems written by students at our school.
origin: borrowed from Medieval Latin collēctānea, noun derivative from neuter plural of Latin collēctāneus "assembled from various sources, collected," from collēctus, past participle of colligere "to gather together, assemble, accumulate" + -āneus, adjective suffix (from -ānus  + -eus )

definition: the cooperative relationship of colleagues; specifically : the participation of bishops in the government of the Roman Catholic Church in collaboration with the pope
sentence: The teachers showed great collegiality by sharing their best lesson plans with each other.

definition: to make parallel
sentence: The scientist had to collimate the light beams so they would all travel in a perfectly straight line.
origin: Latin collimatus, past participle of collimare, manuscript variant of collineare to make straight, from com- + linea line

definition: to work together secretly especially in order to do something illegal or dishonest : conspire, plot
sentence: The two naughty puppies seemed to collude to steal the slipper when no one was looking.
origin: Latin colludere, from com- + ludere to play, from ludus game

definition: to locate (two or more things) together or be located together: such as
sentence: The library and the post office decided to colocate in the same building to save space.

definition: a perfumed liquid composed of alcohol and fragrant oils
sentence: My older brother sprayed on too much cologne, and now the whole hallway smells like flowers.
origin: Cologne, Germany

definition: a structure of vaults lined with recesses for cinerary urns
sentence: A columbarium is a peaceful place with small niches where people keep the ashes of their loved ones.
origin: Latin, literally, dovecote, from columba dove

definition: denunciation
sentence: The sign on the fence had a comminatory message that warned people not to climb over it.
origin: Middle English comminacion "threat of punishment or vengeance," borrowed from Anglo-French comminacioun, borrowed from Latin comminātiōn-, comminātiō "act of threatening or menacing," from comminor, comminārī "to make a threat of, threaten" (from com-  + minor, minārī "to threaten") + -tiōn-, -tiō, suffix of verbal action

definition: to feel or express sympathy : condole
sentence: When I fell down, my friend gave me a commiserative look and helped me get back up.
origin: Latin commiseratus, past participle of commiserari, from com- + miserari to pity, from miser wretched

definition: a person with a commission: such as
sentence: The police commissioner visited our school to talk to us about staying safe in the neighborhood.
origin: Middle English, "person empowered to carry out defined duties," borrowed from Anglo-French, borrowed from Medieval Latin commissiōnārius, from commissiōn-, commissiō  + Latin -ārius

definition: comfortably or conveniently spacious : roomy
sentence: Our new tent is very commodious, with enough room for our whole family and all our sleeping bags.
origin: Middle English, fertile, useful, modification of Medieval Latin commodosus, from Latin commodum convenience, from neuter of commodus

definition: to move violently : agitate
sentence: The heavy wind began to commove the water in the lake, creating large, choppy waves.
origin: Middle English commoeven, from Anglo-French commoveir, from Latin commovēre, from com- + movēre to move

definition: a brief summary of a larger work or of a field of knowledge : abstract
sentence: I have a thick compendium of fun facts that contains information about almost every animal.
origin: borrowed from Latin, "gain, profit, saving, short cut, abridgement, summary," from com-  + pendere "to weigh, have a weight of, pay (out), estimate, consider" + -ium, suffix forming nouns from compound verbs

definition: a musical direction meaning 'with force'.
sentence: The conductor told the orchestra to play the final notes con forza, which means with great strength.

definition: the quality or state of being concise
sentence: When writing a summary, you should use concision to tell the story in as few words as possible.
origin: Middle English concisioun "slaughter, mutilation," borrowed from Latin concīsiōn-, concīsiō "dividing up (of words into clauses)" (Late Latin also, "cutting to pieces, mutilation"), from concīdere "to cut up, break up, slaughter, chop to pieces" + -tiōn-, -tiō, suffix of verbal action

definition: a private meeting or secret assembly; especially : a meeting of Roman Catholic cardinals secluded continuously while choosing a pope
sentence: The club members held a secret conclave in the treehouse to plan the surprise party.
origin: Middle English, from Middle French or Medieval Latin; Middle French, from Medieval Latin, from Latin, room that can be locked up, from com- + clavis key

definition: an alphabetical index of the principal words in a book or the works of an author with their immediate contexts
sentence: The two witnesses were in perfect concordance about what the runaway dog looked like.
origin: Middle English, from Anglo-French, from Medieval Latin concordantia, from Latin concordant-, concordans, present participle of concordare to agree, from concord-, concors

definition: deserved, appropriate
sentence: The villain in the story finally received a condign punishment for all his mean deeds.
origin: Middle English condigne, from Anglo-French, from Latin condignus, from com- + dignus worthy

definition: a natural or artificial channel through which something (such as a fluid) is conveyed
sentence: The thick plastic conduit protects the electric wires that run under the floor of the house.
origin: Middle English conduyt, condyt, cundyte "channel or pipe for conveying water, act of escorting for protection" borrowed from Anglo-French conduit, condet "channel for water, guide, escort party," (also continental Old French), noun derivative from conduit, past participle of conduire "to guide, escort," going back to Latin condūcere "to bring together, join, hire, accept a contract for" (Medieval Latin also "to lead, escort, provide a channel for [water]")

definition: a broad-wheeled covered wagon drawn usually by six horses and used especially for transporting freight across the prairies —called also Conestoga
sentence: Pioneers traveled across the plains in a large Conestoga wagon covered with a white cloth.
origin: Conestoga, Pennsylvania

definition: to talk informally : chat
sentence: I saw my two aunts having a long confabulation over tea in the kitchen.
origin: borrowed from Latin confābulātus, past participle of confābulārī "to talk together, converse," from con-  + fābulārī "to talk, converse, invent a story, make up a fable," derivative of fābula "talk, gossip, tale, legend"; (sense 3) translation of German konfabulieren

definition: small bits or streamers of brightly colored paper made for throwing (as at weddings)
sentence: We threw colorful paper confetti into the air to celebrate my sister's graduation.
origin: Italian, plural of confetto sweetmeat, from Medieval Latin confectum, from Latin, neuter of confectus, past participle of conficere to prepare

definition: friendly concern, interest, and support : the quality or state of being congenial
sentence: The new student was liked by everyone because of her kindness and congeniality.

definition: having the power to stick together or unite.
sentence: The sticky sap of the tree acted as a conglutinant, gluing the two broken branches together.

definition: any of an order (Coniferales) of mostly evergreen trees and shrubs having usually needle-shaped or scalelike leaves and including forms (such as pines) with true cones and others (such as yews) with an arillate fruit
sentence: A pine tree is a coniferous tree because it has needles instead of leaves and grows cones.
origin: ultimately from Latin conifer cone-bearing, from conus cone + -fer

definition: the act of conniving or pretending ignorance of a fault or crime.
sentence: The fox used sneaky connivery to trick the crow into dropping its piece of cheese.

definition: dedicated to a sacred purpose
sentence: The community gathered to consecrate the new park and dedicate it to the children of the town.
origin: see

definition: following one after the other in order : successive
sentence: It has rained for three consecutive days, so we haven't been able to play outside since Monday.
origin: borrowed from Middle French & Medieval Latin; Middle French consecutif "following one after the other," borrowed from Medieval Latin consecūtīvus "following as a result or effect," from Latin consecūtus, past participle of consequī "to come after, succeed in time, follow as a necessary consequence" + -īvus

definition: deduction
sentence: The ground was very muddy as a consequent result of the heavy rainstorm last night.
origin: Middle English, "effect, result taken as a precedent," borrowed from Anglo-French & Late Latin; Anglo-French, "consequence, reasoning," borrowed from Late Latin consequent-, consequens, noun derivative of Latin consequent-, consequens "following as a logical consequence"

definition: of or relating to a constable or constabulary
sentence: The local constabulary is responsible for making sure everyone follows the rules in our town.

definition: amazement or dismay that hinders or throws into confusion
sentence: The baker looked on in consternation when he realized he had forgotten to put sugar in the cookies.
origin: French or Latin; French, from Latin consternation-, consternatio, from consternare to throw into confusion, from com- + -sternare, probably from sternere to spread, strike down

definition: a member of a constituency
sentence: Flour is a main constituent of bread, along with water, yeast, and a little bit of salt.
origin: French constituant, from Middle French, from present participle of constituer to constitute, from Latin constituere see

definition: either of two annually elected chief magistrates of the Roman republic
sentence: The consul works at the embassy and helps people who are traveling in a foreign country.
origin: Middle English, from Latin; perhaps akin to Latin consulere to consult

definition: silent or quiet.
sentence: The library was perfectly conticent, as every student was busy reading and no one was talking.

definition: being in actual contact : touching along a boundary or at a point
sentence: The United States has forty-eight contiguous states that are all connected to each other.
origin: Latin contiguus "adjacent, neighboring" (from contig-, variant stem of contingere "to be in contact with" + -uus, deverbal adjective suffix) +

definition: marked by uninterrupted extension in space, time, or sequence
sentence: The continuous sound of the waterfall was very relaxing to listen to while we hiked.
origin: Latin continuus (from continēre "to hold together, retain, restrain, have as contents" + -uus, deverbal adjective suffix) +

definition: a coherent whole characterized as a collection, sequence, or progression of values or elements varying by minute degrees
sentence: The colors of a rainbow exist on a continuum, where one color slowly fades into the next.
origin: borrowed from Medieval Latin, noun derivative from neuter of Latin continuus

definition: illegal or prohibited traffic in goods : smuggling
sentence: The guard at the airport checked our bags to make sure we weren't carrying any contraband.
origin: borrowed from Middle French & Italian; Middle French contrebande, borrowed from Italian contrabando (later contrabbando), originally Upper Italian (Venetian) chontrabando (Medieval Latin of Venice contrabannum), from contra-  + bando "proclamation, edict, law," borrowed from Gothic bandwo "sign, signal"

definition: of, relating to, or constituting a contract
sentence: The soccer player was contractually required to attend every practice and game for the whole season.
origin: borrowed from New Latin contractuālis, from Latin contractu-, stem of contractus  + -ālis

definition: on the contrary
sentence: Some people like the heat, but contrariwise, I much prefer the cold and snowy winter.
origin: Middle English contrary-wyse, from contrary  + -wyse

definition: a thing contrived; especially : a mechanical device
sentence: The squirrel used a clever contrivance of jumping from the fence to the branch to reach the bird feeder.

definition: insolently abusive and humiliating
sentence: The bully was sent to the office for making contumelious remarks to the other students.

definition: dried coconut meat yielding coconut oil
sentence: Copra is the dried meat of a coconut that is used to make coconut oil for cooking.
origin: Portuguese, from Malayalam koppara

definition: an Afro-Asiatic language descended from ancient Egyptian and used as the liturgical language of the Coptic church
sentence: In Egypt, some people still use the ancient Coptic language during their religious services.

definition: a small chiefly nocturnal arboreal frog (Eleutherodactylus coqui) native to Puerto Rico that has a high-pitched call and has been introduced into Hawaii and southern Florida
sentence: The tiny coqui frog is famous in Puerto Rico for the loud 'ko-kee' sound it makes at night.
origin: American Spanish coquí

definition: the ciliated first-stage larva of certain tapeworms.
sentence: In biology, we learned that a coracidium is a tiny, swimming larva of certain types of flatworms.

definition: a system of mountain ranges often consisting of a number of more or less parallel chains
sentence: A cordillera is a long chain of mountains, like the Andes that run through South America.
origin: borrowed from Spanish, from cuerda "string, rope, line of mountain peaks" (going back to Latin chorda, corda "tripe, string of a musical instrument") + -ill-, diminutive suffix (going back to Latin -illus) + -era, suffix of place (going back to Latin -āria, feminine of -ārius )

definition: trousers of corduroy fabric
sentence: I like wearing my brown corduroy pants because the ribbed fabric feels soft and warm.
origin: of obscure origin

definition: an Old World annual herb (Coriandrum sativum) of the carrot family with aromatic fruits
sentence: The recipe called for ground coriander, which is a spice made from the seeds of the cilantro plant.
origin: Middle English coriandre, from Anglo-French, from Latin coriandrum, from Greek koriandron, koriannon

definition: a native or resident of Corinth, Greece
sentence: The museum building had tall Corinthian columns with beautiful carvings of leaves at the top.

definition: a rounded thick modified underground stem base bearing membranous or scaly leaves and buds and acting as a vegetative reproductive structure
sentence: A crocus grows from a corm, which is an underground part of the plant that looks like a bulb.
origin: borrowed from New Latin cormus, borrowed from Greek kormós "tree trunk after removal of the boughs," from kor-, o-grade derivative from the base of keírein "to cut off, shave" + -mos, resultative noun suffix

definition: the transparent part of the coat of the eyeball that covers the iris and pupil and admits light to the interior
sentence: The cornea is the clear, protective layer that covers the very front of your eye.
origin: Middle English, borrowed from Medieval Latin (short for cornea tēla "horny web," cornea tunica "horny covering," translating Greek kerātoeidḕs chitṓn), from feminine of Latin corneus "horny"

definition: any of various shrubs or trees (genus Cornus) of the dogwood family
sentence: The cornel tree produces small red fruits and has very hard wood that was used for making tools.
origin: ultimately from Latin cornus cornel cherry tree; akin to Greek kranon cornel cherry tree

definition: a curved, hollow goat's horn or similarly shaped receptacle (such as a horn-shaped basket) that is overflowing especially with fruit and vegetables (such as gourds, ears of corn, apples, and grapes) and that is used as a decorative motif emblematic of abundance —called also horn of plenty
sentence: The basket was a cornucopia of autumn vegetables, filled with pumpkins, squash, and corn.
origin: Late Latin, from Latin cornu copiae horn of plenty

definition: a proposition inferred immediately from a proved proposition with little or no additional proof
sentence: Learning to spell is a natural corollary of reading many books every day.
origin: Middle English correlary, corolarie, borrowed from Late Latin corōllārium, going back to Latin, "garland (given as a reward), unsolicited payment, gratuity," from corōlla "small wreath of flowers" + -ārium

definition: a usually elected public officer who is typically not required to have specific medical qualifications and whose principal duty is to inquire by an inquest into the cause of any death which there is reason to suppose is not due to natural causes
sentence: The coroner is the official who determines the cause of death when someone passes away unexpectedly.
origin: Middle English corowner, coronour "local officer of the crown charged with supervision of royal pleas," borrowed from Anglo-French coroner, corouner, from corone, coroune  + -er

definition: to support or help prove with evidence or authority : make more certain
sentence: My sister was able to corroborate my story that the dog was the one who knocked over the lamp.
origin: Latin corroboratus, past participle of corroborare, from com- + robor-, robur strength

definition: tending or having the power to corrode
sentence: Saltwater can be very corrosive and can cause metal on boats to rust over time.
origin: Middle English corrosif, borrowed from Anglo-French & Medieval Latin; Anglo-French, borrowed from Medieval Latin corrōsīvus, from Latin corrōsus, past participle of corrōdere "to gnaw, " + -īvus

definition: the waist or bodice of a dress
sentence: My sister wore a beautiful flower corsage pinned to her dress for the school dance.
origin: French, bust, bodice, from Old French, bust, from cors body, from Latin corpus

definition: the outer or superficial part of an organ or bodily structure (such as the kidney, adrenal gland, or cerebellum or a bone); especially : cerebral cortex
sentence: The outer layer of an organ or a plant stem is often called the cortex.
origin: Latin cortic-, cortex bark

definition: the first leaf or one of the first pair or whorl of leaves developed by the embryo of a seed plant
sentence: When a bean seed sprouts, the first leaf that pops out of the ground is called a cotyledon.
origin: New Latin, from Greek kotylēdōn cup-shaped hollow, from kotylē cup, anything hollow

definition: to deceive, win over, or induce to do something by artful coaxing and wheedling or shrewd trickery
sentence: The tricky character in the story tried to cozen the king into giving him all the gold.
origin: perhaps from obsolete Italian cozzonare, from Italian cozzone horse trader, from Latin cocion-, cocio trader

definition: mental acceptance as true or real
sentence: You shouldn't give much credence to rumors you hear on the playground until you know the facts.
origin: Middle English, from Anglo-French or Medieval Latin; Anglo-French, from Medieval Latin credentia, from Latin credent-, credens, present participle of credere to believe, trust

definition: readiness or willingness to believe especially on slight or uncertain evidence
sentence: The magician relied on the audience's credulity to make them believe he actually sawed a lady in half.
origin: see

definition: a member of an Algonquian-speaking First Nations people of Quebec, Ontario, Manitoba, and Saskatchewan
sentence: The Cree are one of the largest groups of First Nations people living in Canada and the United States.
origin: Canadian French Cris, plural, short for Cristinaux, from Ojibwa dialect kirištino·, singular, member of a band living south of James Bay

definition: a wicker basket (as for carrying newly caught fish)
sentence: The fisherman put the trout he caught into a woven basket called a creel.
origin: Middle English creille, crele

definition: of, relating to, or resembling twilight : dim
sentence: Animals like deer and fireflies are crepuscular, meaning they are most active during the twilight of dawn and dusk.
origin: borrowed from New Latin crepusculāris, from Latin crepusculum "twilight" + -āris

definition: marked by gradual spontaneous development
sentence: The crescive moon looked like a thin silver sliver in the night sky as it grew larger each night.
origin: Latin crescere to grow

definition: of, relating to, or being the last period of the Mesozoic era characterized by continued dominance of reptiles, emergent dominance of angiosperms, diversification of mammals, and the extinction of many types of organisms at the close of the period; also : of, relating to, or being the corresponding system of rocks
sentence: The Tyrannosaurus rex lived during the Cretaceous period, which was the very last age of the dinosaurs.
origin: Latin cretaceus resembling chalk, from creta chalk

definition: a card game for two players in which each player tries to form various counting combinations of cards
sentence: My grandpa taught me how to play cribbage, a card game where you use a wooden board with pegs to keep score.

definition: a coarse sieve; to pass through a sieve.
sentence: The farmer used a large sieve called a cribble to separate the grain from the sand.

definition: a large, non-venomous snake of the West Indies and Central America.
sentence: In the Caribbean, a cribo is a large, dark-colored snake that is known for eating other snakes.

definition: an open-weave fabric of horsehair or cotton that is usually stiffened and used especially for interlinings and millinery
sentence: In the olden days, women wore a stiff crinoline under their dresses to make their skirts look very wide.
origin: French, from Italian crinolino, from crino horsehair (from Latin crinis hair) + lino flax, linen, from Latin linum

definition: a unit of mass for gases, equal to the weight of one liter of hydrogen at standard conditions.
sentence: A crith is a very tiny unit of mass used by scientists to measure the weight of a liter of hydrogen gas.

definition: one who carries a cross especially at the head of an ecclesiastical procession
sentence: Vegetables like broccoli, cabbage, and kale belong to the cruciferous family and are very healthy for you.
origin: Late Latin, from Latin cruc-, crux + -fer

definition: of or relating to the production of very low temperatures
sentence: Scientists use cryogenic tanks to keep things at extremely cold temperatures, much colder than a regular freezer.

definition: secret, occult
sentence: The treasure map had a cryptic message that was hard to understand without a secret code.
origin: borrowed from Late Latin crypticus "hidden," borrowed from Late Greek kryptikós "obscuring" (Greek kryptikôs "secretly"), from kryptós "hidden, secret" + -ikos

definition: a short heavy club
sentence: In the fairy tale, the giant carried a heavy wooden cudgel to protect his castle.
origin: Middle English kuggel, from Old English cycgel; perhaps akin to Middle High German kugele ball

definition: with distinction
sentence: My cousin worked very hard in college and graduated cum laude, which means 'with praise.'
origin: New Latin, with praise

definition: unwieldy because of heaviness and bulk
sentence: The giant box was very cumbersome to carry up the stairs because it was so wide and heavy.
origin: see

definition: a broad waistband usually worn in place of a vest with men's dress clothes and adapted in various styles of women's clothes
sentence: For the fancy wedding, my uncle wore a tuxedo with a wide silk sash called a cummerbund around his waist.
origin: Hindi & Urdu kamarband, from Persian, from kamar waist + band band

definition: heap, accumulation
sentence: On a sunny day, you can often see fluffy, white cumulus clouds that look like giant pieces of cotton candy.
origin: Latin

definition: inordinate desire for wealth : avarice, greed
sentence: The king's cupidity made him want to tax his people more just so he could buy more gold statues.
origin: Middle English cupidite, from Anglo-French cupidité, from Latin cupiditat-, cupiditas

definition: a complex poison of South American Indigenous people used on arrow tips that causes muscle relaxation and paralysis, includes various substances of plant and animal origin, and typically contains an alkaloid extracted from one of two South American vines (Strychnos toxifera of the family Loganiaceae or Chondodendron tomentosum of the family Menispermaceae) as the primary active ingredient
sentence: Hunters in the rainforest sometimes use a plant poison called curare on the tips of their blowdarts.
origin: Portuguese & Spanish curare, from Carib kurari

definition: a unit quantity of any radioactive nuclide in which 3.7 × 1010 disintegrations occur per second
sentence: The curie is a unit named after Marie Curie that scientists use to measure radioactivity.
origin: Marie & Pierre Curie

definition: a crusty, ill-tempered, and usually old man
sentence: The old curmudgeon next door always yelled at us if our ball accidentally went into his yard.
origin: origin unknown

definition: dermis
sentence: Cutis is just a fancy scientific word for your skin, which is the largest organ of your body.
origin: Latin

definition: a bluish or purplish discoloration (as of skin) due to deficient oxygenation of the blood
sentence: The doctor checked for cyanosis, which is when a person's skin or lips turn blue because they aren't getting enough oxygen.
origin: New Latin, from Greek kyanōsis dark blue color, from kyanos

definition: the science of communication and control theory that is concerned especially with the comparative study of automatic control systems (such as the nervous system and brain and mechanical-electrical communication systems)
sentence: The scientist studied cybernetics to learn how to make robots that can think and react like humans.
origin: Greek kybernētēs pilot, governor (from kybernan to steer, govern) + English -ics

definition: a young swan
sentence: A baby swan is called a cygnet, and it has fluffy gray feathers until it grows up.
origin: Middle English sygnett, from Anglo-French cignet, from cigne swan, from Latin cycnus, cygnus, from Greek kyknos

definition: the doctrine of the Cynics
sentence: Because he had been lied to before, the boy showed some cynicism when the salesman promised a 'free' toy.
origin: see

definition: from the beginning —used as a direction in music to repeat
sentence: The music teacher told me to play the song 'da capo,' which means to go back to the very beginning.
origin: Italian

definition: a small freshwater European cyprinid fish (Leuciscus leuciscus)
sentence: While fishing at the creek, we saw a small, silver dace swimming quickly through the water.
origin: Middle English dace, darce, from Anglo-French dars, from Medieval Latin darsus

definition: a metrical foot consisting of one long and two short syllables or of one stressed and two unstressed syllables (as in tenderly)
sentence: In poetry class, we learned that a dactylic rhythm sounds like a drumbeat: LONG-short-short.
origin: Middle English dactyl, dactile "fruit of the date palm, a dactyl in verse," borrowed from Latin dactylus "dactyl in verse, kind of date," borrowed from Greek dáktylos "digit (finger or toe), finger's width as a measurement, dactyl in verse, date," of uncertain origin

definition: any of a breed of medium-sized dogs having a white short-haired coat with many black or brown spots
sentence: The fire station has a friendly Dalmatian with white fur and many black spots.
origin: from the supposed origin of the breed in Dalmatia

definition: to ornament (something, such as iron or steel) with wavy patterns like those of watered silk or with inlaid work of precious metals
sentence: The museum had an old sword with a damascened blade that had beautiful wavy patterns on the metal.
origin: Middle French damasquiner, from damasquin of Damascus

definition: complex, shallow wetlands found in central and southern Africa.
sentence: In Africa, dambos are grassy wetlands that stay green even during the dry season.

definition: to move up and down in one's arms or on one's knee in affectionate play
sentence: The happy grandfather liked to dandle the baby on his knee while singing a funny song.
origin: origin unknown

definition: a male ballet dancer
sentence: The lead male dancer in the ballet is called a danseur, and he can jump very high.
origin: French, from danser to dance

definition: the Central American tapir.
sentence: A danta is another name for a tapir, a large animal with a short trunk that lives in the jungle.

definition: any of several usually weedy ryegrasses (genus Lolium)
sentence: The farmer had to pull the darnel weeds out of the field because they looked too much like his wheat.
origin: Middle English

definition: a usually brightly colored loose-fitting pullover garment
sentence: For the cultural festival, Kwame wore a colorful dashiki with beautiful patterns around the neck.
origin: modification of Yoruba dàńṣíkí

definition: a person who daubs or smears unskillfully, especially a poor painter.
sentence: The messy painter was a bit of a daubster, often getting more paint on himself than on the canvas.

definition: a small compact writing desk
sentence: My grandmother invited us to sit on the floral davenport in her living room to open our presents.
origin: probably from the name Davenport

definition: to look directly into the eyes of (someone) —sometimes used figuratively
sentence: The deathin is a small, very poisonous plant that people must be careful not to touch in the woods.

definition: a great disaster
sentence: The school play turned into a debacle when the scenery fell down and the lead actor forgot all his lines.
origin: French débâcle, from débâcler to clear, from Middle French desbacler, from des- de- + bacler to block, perhaps from Vulgar Latin *bacculare, from Latin baculum staff

definition: to impair the strength of : enfeeble
sentence: A very bad flu can debilitate you and make you feel too weak to even get out of bed.
origin: Latin debilitatus, past participle of debilitare to weaken, from debilis weak

definition: one making a debut : debutant; especially : a young woman making her formal entrance into society
sentence: The young debutante wore a beautiful white gown for her first official party at the ballroom.
origin: French débutante, feminine of débutant see

definition: no longer living; especially : recently dead —used of persons
sentence: The lawyer had to read the will of the deceased man to find out who would get his house.
origin: see

definition: having a tendency or disposition to deceive or give false impressions:
sentence: It is deceitful to say you finished your homework when you haven't even started it yet.
origin: see

definition: a split aileron used as a speed brake on an aircraft.
sentence: The pilot used the deceleron on the plane's wing to help slow down the aircraft as it landed.

definition: consisting of or lasting for 10 years
sentence: The town holds a decennial parade once every ten years to celebrate its history.

definition: falling off or shed seasonally or at a certain stage of development in the life cycle
sentence: Maple trees are deciduous, which means they lose all their leaves every autumn.
origin: Latin deciduus, from decidere to fall off, from de- + cadere to fall

definition: to select by lot and kill every tenth member of
sentence: The decimation of the forest by the fire meant that many animals had to find new homes.
origin: Latin decimatus, past participle of decimare, from decimus tenth, from decem ten

definition: of, relating to, or marked by declamation or rhetorical display
sentence: The actor used a loud, declamatory voice when he gave his big speech on the stage.

definition: noun, adjective, or pronoun inflection especially in some prescribed order of the forms
sentence: In Latin class, we learned about declension, which is how words change their endings based on how they are used.
origin: Middle English declenson, modification of Middle French declinaison, from Latin declination-, declinatio grammatical inflection, turning aside, from declinare to inflect, turn aside

definition: angular distance north or south from the celestial equator measured along a great circle passing through the celestial poles
sentence: The captain used his compass to find the declination, which is the difference between true north and magnetic north.
origin: Middle English declinacioun, from Middle French declination, from Latin declination-, declinatio angle of the heavens, turning aside

definition: a Roman cavalry officer in command of 10 men
sentence: In the ancient Roman army, a decurion was an officer who was in charge of a small group of ten soldiers.
origin: Middle English decurioun, from Latin decurion-, decurio, from decuria division of ten, from decem

definition: full of or showing a disposition to challenge, resist, or fight : full of or showing defiance : bold, impudent
sentence: The defiant little girl folded her arms and refused to eat her peas.
origin: in part borrowed from French défiant "mistrustful," from present participle of défier "to mistrust, challenge, ," going back to Old French; in part from  +

definition: the melting of ice; specifically : the retreat of a glacier or ice sheet
sentence: As the earth gets warmer, deglaciation happens, causing glaciers to melt and turn into water.

definition: a feeling of having already experienced a current situation.
sentence: When I walked into the new library, I had a strange feeling of déjà vu, like I had been there before.

definition: highly pleasing : delightful
sentence: The fresh strawberry pie smelled delectable and tasted even better.
origin: Middle English, borrowed from Middle French & Latin; Middle French, borrowed from Latin dēlectābilis, from dēlectāre "to entice, exert fascination on, charm, delight" + -bilis "capable (of acting) or worthy of (being acted upon)" ,

definition: harmful often in a subtle or unexpected way
sentence: Spending too much time in the hot sun without sunscreen can have a deleterious effect on your skin.
origin: Greek dēlētērios, from dēleisthai to hurt

definition: to dissolve or melt away
sentence: Certain types of salt will deliquesce, meaning they absorb so much water from the air that they turn into liquid.
origin: Latin deliquescere, from de- + liquescere, inchoative of liquēre to be fluid

definition: an acute mental disturbance characterized by confused thinking and disrupted attention usually accompanied by disordered speech and hallucinations
sentence: When the boy had a very high fever, he was in a state of delirium and started seeing imaginary monsters.
origin: Latin, from delirare to be crazy, literally, to leave the furrow (in plowing), from de- + lira furrow

definition: shaped like a delta or an equilateral triangle.
sentence: The leaf was deltoidal in shape, looking like a wide triangle with a pointy tip.

definition: a usually progressive condition (such as Alzheimer's disease) marked by the development of multiple cognitive deficits (such as memory impairment, aphasia, and the inability to plan and initiate complex behavior)
sentence: The grandmother suffered from dementia, which made it hard for her to remember people's names.
origin: borrowed from Latin dēmentia "derangement, insanity, folly," noun derivative of Latin dēment-, dēmens "out of one's mind, frenzied, insane," from dē-  + -ment, -mens, adjective derivative of ment-, mens "power of reason, mental balance, mind"

definition: offense
sentence: In the old school, students would get demerits if they were caught talking during a lesson.
origin: Middle English, from Anglo-French & Medieval Latin; Anglo-French demerite, from Medieval Latin demeritum, from neuter of demeritus, past participle of demerēre to be undeserving of, from Latin, to earn, from de- + merēre to merit

definition: living near, deposited on, or sinking to the bottom of the sea
sentence: Flounder and cod are demersal fish, which means they spend most of their time living at the bottom of the ocean.
origin: Latin demersus (past participle of demergere to sink, from de- + mergere to dip, sink) + English

definition: the Greek goddess of agriculture
sentence: In Greek myths, Demeter is the goddess of the harvest who makes the crops grow.
origin: Latin, from Greek Dēmētēr

definition: the statistical characteristics of human populations (such as age or income) used especially to identify markets
sentence: The mayor looked at the demographics of the town to see how many kids were ready to start school.
origin: derivative of

definition: demonstrating as real or true
sentence: The words 'this,' 'that,' 'these,' and 'those' are called demonstrative pronouns because they point things out.
origin: Middle English demonstratyf "based on logic, pointing out (of a pronoun)," borrowed from Anglo-French & Late Latin; Anglo-French demonstratif, borrowed from Late Latin dēmonstrātīvus "pointing out (of a pronoun), able to prove" (Latin, "displaying—in rhetoric"), from Latin dēmonstrātus, past participle of dēmonstrāre "to indicate, show, " + -īvus

definition: soothing
sentence: The honey in the tea acted as a demulcent, soothing the girl's scratchy sore throat.
origin: Latin demulcent-, demulcens, present participle of demulcēre to soothe, from de- + mulcēre to soothe

definition: a branching treelike figure produced on or in a mineral by a foreign mineral; also : the mineral so marked
sentence: A dendrite is a branch-like part of a nerve cell that helps it receive messages from other cells.

definition: to attack the reputation of : defame
sentence: You should never participate in the denigration of your classmates by saying mean things about them.
origin: Latin denigratus, past participle of denigrare, from de- + nigrare to blacken, from nigr-, niger black

definition: the part of a fraction that is below the line and that functions as the divisor of the numerator
sentence: In the fraction 3/4, the number 4 is the denominator because it is on the bottom.
origin: see

definition: to remove from a throne or other high position
sentence: The people decided to depose the mean leader and choose a new president instead.
origin: Middle English, from Anglo-French deposer, from Late Latin deponere (perfect indicative deposui), from Latin, to put down

definition: to lower in honor or esteem
sentence: The value of a new car will depreciate, or go down, as soon as you start driving it.
origin: Middle English, from Late Latin depretiatus, past participle of depretiare, from Latin de- + pretium price

definition: to lay waste : plunder, ravage
sentence: The garden suffered from the depredation of hungry rabbits who ate all the lettuce.
origin: Late Latin depraedatus, past participle of depraedari, from Latin de- + praedari to plunder

definition: the state of being kept from possessing, enjoying, or using something : the state of being deprived : privation; especially : removal from an office, dignity, or benefice
sentence: Sleep deprivation can make you feel very grumpy and make it hard for you to focus in class.
origin: see

definition: abandoned especially by the owner or occupant; also : run-down
sentence: The derelict house had broken windows, peeling paint, and weeds growing all over the porch.
origin: Latin derelictus, past participle of derelinquere to abandon, from de- + relinquere to leave

definition: expressing or causing contemptuous ridicule or scorn : expressing or causing derision
sentence: The boy gave a derisive laugh when his friend told a joke that wasn't very funny.
origin: see

definition: a word formed from another word or base : a word formed by derivation
sentence: The word 'unhappy' is a derivative of the word 'happy' because it was made by adding a prefix.
origin: see

definition: a person who deserts; especially : a member of a military force who abandons service without leave
sentence: In the story, the soldier became a deserter when he left his post and ran away from the battle.
origin: + , after Latin dēsertor and French déserteur

definition: the process of becoming desert (as from land mismanagement or climate change)
sentence: Desertification is when land becomes very dry and turns into a desert because there isn't enough rain.

definition: devoid of inhabitants and visitors : deserted
sentence: The empty playground looked desolate in the middle of the cold, gray winter.
origin: Middle English desolat, desolate "deserted, lonely, distressed," borrowed from Latin dēsōlātus, past participle of dēsōlāre "to leave all alone, forsake, empty of inhabitants," from dē-  + -sōlāre, verbal derivative of sōlus "lone, acting without a partner, lonely, deserted," of uncertain origin

definition: discontinuance from use or exercise : disuse
sentence: The old typewriter had fallen into desuetude because everyone started using computers instead.
origin: Middle English dissuetude, from Latin desuetudo, from desuescere to become unaccustomed, from de- + suescere to become accustomed; akin to Latin sodalis comrade

definition: loose material (such as rock fragments or organic particles) that results directly from disintegration
sentence: The forest floor was covered with detritus, like fallen leaves, twigs, and pieces of bark.
origin: borrowed from French détritus, borrowed from Latin dētrītus, past participle of dēterere "to wear away, impair," from dē-  + terere "to rub, grind, wear down"

definition: a god introduced by means of a crane in ancient Greek and Roman drama to decide the final outcome
sentence: The story had a deus ex machina ending where a magic fairy suddenly appeared and solved all the problems.
origin: New Latin, a god from a machine, translation of Greek theos ek mēchanēs

definition: of, relating to, or characteristic of the devil : extremely evil
sentence: The villain had a diabolical plan to steal all the toys in the city on Christmas Eve.
origin: diabolical from diabolic + ; diabolic going back to Middle English deabolik, borrowed from Middle French & Late Latin; Middle French dyabolique, borrowed from Late Latin diabolicus, borrowed from Late Greek diabolikós, going back to Greek, "slanderous," from diábolos "accuser, backbiter, slanderer" + -ikos

definition: a mark near or through an orthographic or phonetic character or combination of characters indicating a phonetic value different from that given the unmarked or otherwise marked element
sentence: A diacritic is a small mark, like an accent or a dot, added to a letter to show how to say it.

definition: crown; specifically : a royal headband
sentence: The queen wore a shiny gold diadem decorated with diamonds and pearls on her head.
