origin: Middle English diademe "monarch's crown, crownlike headdress," borrowed from Anglo-French, borrowed from Latin diadēma "ornamental headband, crown," borrowed from Greek diadēmat-, diádēma "headband, band wrapped around the headdress by Persian monarchs," from diadē-, variant stem of diadéō, diadeîn "to bind on either side, bandage" (from dia-  + déō, deîn "to bind, tie") + -mat-, -ma, resultative noun suffix; Greek déō, deîn probably going back to a zero-grade form (*dh1-i̯é-?) of the Indo-European verbal base *deh1- "tie, bind," whence also Sanskrit ā́-dhyati "(s/he) binds," Hittite tiya "bind!"; from a full grade *deh1- Greek édēsa "(I) bound," Sanskrit dāman-, dā́ma "cord, fetter"

definition: the separation of substances in solution by means of their unequal diffusion through semipermeable membranes; especially : such a separation of colloids from soluble substances
sentence: The patient had to go to the hospital for dialysis, a treatment that helps clean the blood when kidneys don't work.
origin: New Latin, from Greek, separation, from dialyein to dissolve, from dia- + lyein to loosen

definition: pink
sentence: The garden was filled with Dianthus flowers, which are also called 'pinks' because of their bright color.
origin: New Latin, genus name, from Greek dios heavenly + anthos flower ,

definition: the Jews living outside Israel —usually used with the
sentence: A diaspora happens when a large group of people from one country move to many different places around the world.
origin: Greek, dispersion, from diaspeirein to scatter, from dia- + speirein to sow

definition: the generation of heat in tissue by electric currents for medical or surgical purposes
sentence: The doctor used diathermy to send heat deep into the patient's muscles to help them heal.
origin: International Scientific Vocabulary

definition: of, relating to, or being a musical scale (such as a major or minor scale) comprising intervals of five whole steps and two half steps
sentence: A diatonic scale is the standard eight-note scale that we usually use in music class.
origin: borrowed from Late Latin diatonicus, borrowed from Greek diatonikós "(of a tetrachord) comprising two steps and a half step," from diátonos "a scale so comprised" (noun use of diátonos, adjective—with génos "type, kind" understood—nominal ablaut derivative of diateínein "to stretch as far as possible, extend," from dia-  + teínein "to stretch, extend") + -ikos

definition: a bitter and abusive speech or piece of writing
sentence: The angry man gave a long diatribe about why he didn't like the new park rules.
origin: borrowed from Late Latin, "disputation," going back to Latin, "school (of rhetoric or philosophy)," borrowed from Greek diatribḗ "wearing down, attrition, spending of time, discussion, discourse, school," derivative of diatrī́bein "to crush, wear out, spend time, occupy oneself," from dia-  + trī́bein "to rub, grind, wear down," of uncertain origin

definition: a double-reed wind instrument of ancient Greece; also a footrace of two laps.
sentence: In ancient Greece, a diaulos was a type of race where athletes ran to the end of the stadium and back.

definition: of or relating to diet
sentence: The grocery store has a dietetic section with foods that are low in sugar for people with health problems.

definition: dihedral angle
sentence: The wings of the airplane were built at a dihedral angle, meaning they tilted up slightly at the ends.

definition: decayed, deteriorated, or fallen into partial ruin especially through neglect or misuse
sentence: The dilapidated shed in the backyard was falling apart and needed to be torn down.
origin: see

definition: steady, earnest, and energetic effort : persistent and careful hard work
sentence: With a lot of diligence and hard work, Sarah was able to finish her giant science project on time.
origin: Middle English, from Anglo-French, from Latin diligentia, from diligent-, diligens see

definition: a diluting agent (such as the vehicle in a medicinal preparation)
sentence: The artist added a little bit of water as a diluent to make the thick paint easier to spread.
origin: Latin diluent-, diluens, present participle of diluere

definition: the condition or property of being dimorphic or dimorphous: such as
sentence: Peacocks show sexual dimorphism because the males have huge colorful tails while the females do not.

definition: the territorial jurisdiction of a bishop
sentence: A diocese is a large district that is looked after by a bishop in the church.
origin: Middle English diocise, dyoces, borrowed from Anglo-French diocise, dyocés, borrowed from Late Latin diocēsis, dioecēsis "administrative district, province, group of provinces (in the later Roman Empire), jurisdiction of a bishop" (Latin, "administrative district"), borrowed from Late Greek dioíkēsis "administration, control, ordering, civil or ecclesiastical group of provinces, jurisdiction of a bishop," going back to Greek, "management, administration," from dioikē-, variant stem of dioikéō, dioikeîn "to control, manage, look after" (from di-  + oikeîn "to live, have one's home, order, govern," derivative of oîkos "house, home") + -sis

definition: a gliding monosyllabic speech sound (such as the vowel combination at the end of toy) that starts at or near the articulatory position for one vowel and moves to or toward the position of another
sentence: In the word 'cloud,' the 'ou' is a diphthong because two vowel sounds are joined together.
origin: Middle English diptonge, from Middle French diptongue, from Late Latin dipthongus, from Greek diphthongos, from di- + phthongos voice, sound

definition: a 2-leaved hinged tablet folding together to protect writing on its waxed surfaces
sentence: A diptych is a piece of art that is made of two separate panels that are often hinged together.
origin: Late Latin diptycha, plural, from Greek, from neuter plural of diptychos folded in two, from di- + ptychē fold

definition: capable of being steered
sentence: A blimp is a type of dirigible, which is a giant airship that floats in the sky and can be steered.
origin: Latin dirigere

definition: the quality of being able to grasp and comprehend what is obscure : skill in discerning
sentence: The judge used his discernment to decide which of the two stories was actually true.
origin: + , perhaps after Middle French discernement

definition: to cause to be in a state of confusion : upset, disorient
sentence: The loud noise and bright lights started to discombobulate the toddler, making him feel very confused.
origin: probably alteration of discompose

definition: abash, disconcert
sentence: The teacher would always discountenance any kind of bullying or mean behavior in the classroom.

definition: having or showing discernment or good judgment in conduct and especially in speech : prudent; especially : cautious and restrained (as in revealing information)
sentence: Maya tried to discreetly whisper the answer to her friend without the teacher noticing.
origin: Middle English discrete, discret, discreet "morally discerning, prudent, separate, distinct," borrowed from Anglo-French & Medieval Latin; Anglo-French discret, borrowed from Medieval Latin discrētus "separate, distinct, showing discernment, prudent," going back to Latin, "separated, differentiated," from past participle of discernere "to separate, distinguish"

definition: left to individual choice or judgment : exercised at one's own discretion
sentence: After paying for rent and food, my parents have a little bit of discretionary money for fun things like movies.

definition: to flow or come forth from or as if from a channel
sentence: The large river began to disembogue into the ocean, pouring out all of its fresh water.
origin: modification of Spanish desembocar, from des- dis- (from Latin dis-) + embocar to put into the mouth, from en in (from Latin in) + boca mouth, from Latin bucca

definition: marked by separation of or from usually contiguous parts or individuals: such as
sentence: The two ideas were disjunct and didn't seem to have anything to do with each other.
origin: Middle English, from Latin disjunctus, past participle of disjungere to disjoin

definition: the transformation (as of something real or unsettling) into carefully controlled and safe entertainment or an environment with similar qualities
sentence: Some people worry about the Disneyfication of old fairy tales, making them much simpler and happier than they used to be.
origin: Walt Disney + -fication

definition: markedly distinct in quality or character
sentence: The museum had a collection of disparate items, ranging from old coins to astronaut suits.
origin: borrowed from Latin disparātus "separate, distinct," from past participle of disparāre "to divide, separate off, make different," from dis-  + parāre "to supply, provide, make ready" (influenced in sense by association with dispar-, dispār "unequal, different")

definition: being out of proportion
sentence: A giant backpack looks disproportionate on such a small kindergarten student.
origin: borrowed from Medieval Latin disprōportiōnātus, past participle of disprōportiōnāre "to make out of proportion," from Latin dis-  + Medieval Latin prōportiōnāre "to compose according to proportions"

definition: to hide under a false appearance
sentence: The boy tried to dissemble his disappointment when he didn't win the prize by smiling anyway.
origin: Middle English dissymbulen, dissymblen, probably reshaping of dissimulen in same sense (after resemblen "to ," semblance , and like forms), borrowed from Anglo-French & Latin; Anglo-French dissimuler, dissumuler "to hide under a false appearance," borrowed from Latin dissimulāre

definition: the act or process of dissolving: such as
sentence: The dissolution of the sugar happened quickly once I stirred it into the hot tea.
origin: see

definition: lack of agreement; especially : inconsistency between the beliefs one holds or between one's actions and one's beliefs
sentence: The piano sounded strange because there was a lot of dissonance when the cat stepped on the keys.
origin: see

definition: agitated with doubt or mental conflict or pain
sentence: The little boy was distraught when he realized he had lost his favorite teddy bear at the park.
origin: Middle English distraght, distrauht, distrawt "disturbed, distressed, insane," alteration of distract (functioning as past participle of distracten "to "), probably by assimilation to past participles ending in -ght, as caght, caught, caut , taught, taut

definition: a solid having 12 plane faces
sentence: In math class, we looked at a dodecahedron, which is a solid shape that has twelve flat faces.
origin: Greek dōdekaedron, from dōdeka- + -edron -hedron

definition: a custom house in Italy or other Mediterranean countries.
sentence: When we traveled to Italy, we had to pass through the dogana, which is the Italian word for customs.

definition: a spell of listlessness or despondency
sentence: After the fun of the holidays ended, I felt like I was in the doldrums because there was nothing to do.
origin: probably akin to Old English dol foolish

definition: a stuffed grape leaf or vegetable shell
sentence: For dinner, we tried dolma, which are grape leaves stuffed with a tasty mix of rice and herbs.
origin: Turkish, literally, something stuffed

definition: a prehistoric monument of two or more upright stones supporting a horizontal stone slab
sentence: We saw a picture of a dolmen, an ancient stone tomb made of huge rocks standing on end.
origin: French, probably modification of Cornish tolmen, from tol hole + men stone

definition: the quality or state of being domestic or domesticated
sentence: The cozy fireplace and the sleeping cat gave the living room a feeling of peaceful domesticity.

definition: to establish in or provide with a domicile
sentence: The rare birds are domiciled in the protected forest where they can build their nests safely.
origin: see

definition: inclined to exercise arbitrary and overbearing control over others
sentence: Nobody wanted to play with the domineering kid because he always tried to tell everyone what to do.

definition: a monoamine C8H11NO2 that is a decarboxylated form of dopa and that occurs especially as a neurotransmitter in the brain
sentence: Our teacher said that dopamine is a chemical in the brain that helps us feel happy and rewarded.
origin: dopa + amine

definition: of, relating to, being, or utilizing a shift in frequency in accordance with the Doppler effect; also : of or relating to Doppler radar
sentence: The Doppler effect explains why an ambulance siren sounds higher as it gets closer and lower as it moves away.

definition: an English breed of large domestic fowl having five toes on each foot.
sentence: A Dorking is a special breed of chicken that is unique because it has five toes instead of four.

definition: a person trained to provide advice, information, emotional support, and physical comfort to a mother before, during, and just after childbirth
sentence: A doula visited my aunt to help her stay calm and comfortable before the new baby was born.
origin: Modern Greek, female helper, maidservant, from Greek doulē female slave

definition: a widow holding property or a title from her deceased husband
sentence: In the story, the wealthy dowager lived in a giant mansion filled with paintings of her late husband.
origin: Middle French douagiere, from douage dower, from douer to endow

definition: not neat or becoming in appearance : shabby
sentence: The old, faded curtains looked a bit dowdy compared to the bright new rug in the room.

definition: —used for dimenhydrinate
sentence: My mom gave me a Dramamine tablet before the boat ride so I wouldn't feel seasick.

definition: of or relating to a racecourse; also used to describe buildings with a long, narrow plan.
sentence: The architects designed a dromic building that featured a long, straight hallway like a racetrack.

definition: one of an ancient Celtic priesthood appearing in Irish and Welsh sagas and Christian legends as magicians and wizards
sentence: We read a legend about a druid who lived in an oak forest and knew the secrets of nature.
origin: Latin druides, druidae, plural, from Gaulish druides; akin to Old Irish druí druid, and perhaps to Old English trēow tree

definition: an elongated or oval hill of glacial drift
sentence: A drumlin is a long, oval-shaped hill that was formed by a moving glacier a long time ago.
origin: Irish druim back, ridge (from Old Irish druimm) + English -lin (alteration of -ling)

definition: bearing or producing drupes (fleshy fruits with a single stone).
sentence: Trees like peaches and cherries are drupiferous because they grow fruit with a hard pit inside.

definition: a spirit that lives in the forest : wood nymph, fairy
sentence: In the fantasy book, a dryad is a magical spirit that lives inside a tree and protects the woods.
origin: Latin dryad-, dryas, from Greek, from drys tree

definition: made for a particular day —used of an item not specified on the regular menu
sentence: The waiter told us that the soup du jour was creamy tomato, which means it was the soup of the day.
origin: French, literally, of the day

definition: a heavy coarse durable cotton twill woven from colored yarns; specifically : blue denim
sentence: I wore my sturdy blue dungarees to the garden so I wouldn't get my legs scratched by the bushes.
origin: Hindi dũgrī & Urdu dungrī

definition: marked by duplicity : deceptive in words or action
sentence: The villain’s duplicitous behavior meant he was saying one thing but secretly doing another.
origin: see

definition: state of northwest central Mexico area 46,196 square miles (119,648 square kilometers), population 1,632,934
sentence: The name Durango refers to a beautiful, rugged area in Mexico known for its mountains.

definition: impairment of handwriting ability that is characterized chiefly by very poor or often illegible writing or writing that takes an unusually long time and great effort to complete
sentence: A student with dysgraphia might find it helpful to use a computer because it is hard for them to write by hand.
origin: + Greek -graphia "writing" (from gráphein "to write" + -ia ), probably after French dysgraphie

definition: indigestion
sentence: The grumpy man had a dyspeptic look on his face, likely because his lunch had given him an upset stomach.
origin: borrowed from Latin, borrowed from Greek dyspepsía, from dys-  + pépsis "cooking, ripening, digestion" (from pep-, base of péttein, péssein, péptein "to cook, ripen, digest" + -sis ) + -ia

definition: an imagined world or society in which people lead wretched, dehumanized, fearful lives
sentence: The movie was about a dystopia, a future world where everything had gone wrong and people were unhappy.
origin: + -topia (in )

definition: of or relating to the ebony family of plants.
sentence: The dark, heavy wood of the antique desk was ebenaceous, meaning it looked like ebony.

definition: the quality of lively or enthusiastic expression of thoughts or feelings : exuberance
sentence: The winner of the race showed great ebullience, jumping up and down with a huge smile.

definition: resembling or made of ivory; creamy-white.
sentence: The statues in the museum had an eburnean color, which is a fancy way to say they looked like ivory.

definition: a spiny-coated toothless burrowing nocturnal monotreme mammal (Tachyglossus aculeatus) of Australia, Tasmania, and New Guinea that has a long extensible tongue and long heavy claws and that feeds chiefly on ants; also : several related mammals (genus Zaglossus) of New Guinea having a longer snout and shorter spines
sentence: An echidna looks like a porcupine but is very special because it is a mammal that lays eggs.
origin: borrowed from New Latin, genus name, going back to Latin, "snake, viper (as an attribute of the Furies)," borrowed from Greek échidna "viper, creature of myth combining the bodies of a woman and a snake," of uncertain origin

definition: the outer relatively rigid granule-free layer of the cytoplasm usually held to be a gel reversibly convertible to a sol
sentence: In the spooky movie, the ghost left behind a trail of glowing green ectoplasm on the wall.

definition: country of western South America bordering on the Pacific and crossed by the Equator; a republic with its capital at Quito area 109,484 square miles (283,561 square kilometers), population 16,499,000
sentence: Ecuador is a country in South America named after the Equator, which runs right through it.

definition: a small alpine perennial composite herb (Leontopodium nivale synonym L. alpinum) of central and southeast Europe that has a dense woolly white pubescence
sentence: The edelweiss is a small, white, fuzzy flower that only grows high up in the cold mountains.
origin: German, from edel noble + weiss white

definition: a person who is being or should be educated.
sentence: The professor referred to each student as an educand, which is a person who is being educated.

definition: of, relating to, or characteristic of Edward VII of England or his age; especially, of clothing : marked by the hourglass silhouette for women and long narrow fitted suits and high collars for men
sentence: The old house was built in the Edwardian style, with large windows and fancy decorations from the early 1900s.

definition: to eliminate or make indistinct by or as if by wearing away a surface; also : to cause to vanish
sentence: Over many years, the wind and rain will efface the writing on the old stone monument.
origin: Middle English, from Anglo-French esfacer, effacer, from e- + face face

definition: having the property of forming bubbles : marked by or producing effervescence
sentence: The soda was very effervescent, with tiny bubbles popping all over the surface.

definition: something given off in or as if in a stream
sentence: The efflux of water from the pipe slowed down once we turned off the main valve.
origin: Medieval Latin effluxus, from effluere

definition: a breaking into or out of a place, especially by force.
sentence: The police investigated the effraction, which is the act of breaking into a building by force.

definition: marked by the expression of great or excessive emotion or enthusiasm
sentence: The coach was very effusive in his praise, telling every player how wonderful they were.
origin: borrowed from Medieval Latin effūsīvus "generating profusely, lavish," from Latin effūsus (past participle of effundere "to pour out, discharge, expend") + -īvus

definition: a word or phrase that sounds like and is mistakenly used in a seemingly logical or plausible way for another word or phrase either on its own or as part of a set expression
sentence: Saying 'old-timers disease' instead of 'Alzheimer’s disease' is an eggcorn because it sounds similar but is wrong.
origin: after eggcorn, altered from , an example of such a usage

definition: a place or means of going out : exit
sentence: The theater has a large sign that points toward the egress so everyone knows where the exit is.
origin: Latin egressus, from egredi to go out, from e- + gradi to go

definition: any of a small American genus (Elodea) of submerged aquatic monocotyledonous herbs
sentence: We put a sprig of elodea in our fish tank because it is a plant that grows well underwater.
origin: borrowed from New Latin, genus name, derivative from the base of Greek helṓdēs "marshy," from hélos (neuter s-stem) "wet meadow, marsh" (probably going back to Indo-European *selos- "marsh," whence also Sanskrit sáraḥ "pond, lake") + -ōdēs "like, having the nature of" (probably generalized from adjectives describing smells, as kēṓdēs "smelling like incense," from the base od- of ózein "to smell, give off odor")

definition: an abnormal particle (such as an air bubble) circulating in the blood
sentence: An embolus is something like a blood clot that moves through the body and can get stuck in a vessel.
origin: New Latin, from Greek embolos wedge-shaped object, stopper, from emballein

definition: a person retired from professional life but permitted to retain as an honorary title the rank of the last office held
sentence: After he retired, the beloved teacher was given the title of professor emeritus.

definition: exhibiting eminence especially in standing above others in some quality or position : prominent
sentence: The school was excited to host an eminent scientist who had won many awards for her work.
origin: Middle English, "standing out, exceed other things in quality or degree," borrowed from Anglo-French & Latin; Anglo-French, "high, lofty" (also continental Old French), borrowed from Latin ēminent-, ēminens "standing out above a surface, projecting, outstanding in merit or importance," from present participle of ēminēre "to stick out, protrude, project, be preeminent, excel," from ē-, variant of ex-  + -minēre, taken to mean "stand out, rise above" (unattested without a prefix)

definition: one designated as the agent of another : representative
sentence: The king sent an emissary to the neighboring land to deliver a message of peace.
origin: Latin emissarius, from emissus, past participle of emittere

definition: a statuette awarded annually by a professional organization for notable achievement in television
sentence: The famous actor was very proud to win an Emmy for her performance in the new TV show.
origin: from alteration of Immy, nickname for image orthicon (a camera tube used in television)

definition: a turnover with a sweet or savory filling
sentence: For lunch, I had an empanada, which is a delicious pastry filled with meat and cheese.
origin: American Spanish, from Spanish, feminine of empanado, past participle of empanar to bread, from em- (from Latin in-) + pan bread, from Latin panis

definition: to disperse in an emulsion; also : to convert (two or more immiscible liquids) into an emulsion
sentence: To make salad dressing, you have to shake the bottle hard to emulsify the oil and vinegar.

definition: in a body : as a whole
sentence: When the bell rang, the students moved en masse toward the playground for recess.
origin: French

definition: glowing and warmly enthusiastic praise; also : an expression of this
sentence: The principal gave a warm encomium to the librarian to thank her for all her hard work.
origin: Latin, from Greek enkōmion, from en in + kōmos revel, celebration

definition: shelter, conceal
sentence: I found the cat comfortably ensconced in a basket of warm laundry.

definition: bewitch, enchant
sentence: In the fairytale, the wicked wizard tried to ensorcell the prince with a magic spell.
origin: Middle French ensorceler, alteration of Old French ensorcerer, from en- + -sorcerer, from sorcier, sorcer sorcerer

definition: to strive to attain : pursue
sentence: After the clown tripped over his own shoes, a lot of laughter ensued from the audience.
origin: Middle English, from Anglo-French ensivre (3rd singular ensiut), from en- + sivre to follow

definition: an international understanding providing for a common course of action
sentence: The two friends made an entente to always share their snacks and help each other with homework.
origin: French, from Old French, intent, understanding

definition: bowels, viscera; broadly : internal parts
sentence: In science class, we looked at a model showing the entrails, which are the organs inside a body.
origin: Middle English entrailles, from Anglo-French, from Medieval Latin intralia, alteration of Latin interanea, plural of interaneum intestine, from neuter of interaneus interior

definition: the districts around a city
sentence: We decided to explore the park and the surrounding environs to see all the different trees.

definition: located above or on the dorsal side of an axis, such as the spine.
sentence: The doctor explained that epaxial muscles are the ones located along the back of an animal's spine.

definition: the insertion or development of a sound or letter in the body of a word (such as \ə\ in \ˈa-thə-ˌlēt\ athlete)
sentence: Adding an extra sound to a word, like saying 'ath-e-lete' instead of 'athlete,' is called epenthesis.
origin: Late Latin, from Greek, from epentithenai to insert a letter, from epi- + entithenai to put in, from en- + tithenai to put

definition: the outer epithelial layer of the external integument of the animal body that is derived from the embryonic epiblast; specifically : the outer nonsensitive and nonvascular layer of the skin of a vertebrate that overlies the dermis
sentence: The epidermis is the very top layer of your skin that you can see and touch.
origin: Late Latin, from Greek, from epi- + derma skin

definition: situated upon or administered or placed outside the dura mater
sentence: The doctor gave my mom an epidural to help her feel less pain while the baby was being born.

definition: a Christian festival held on January 6 in commemoration of the coming of the Magi as the first manifestation of Christ to the Gentiles or in the Eastern Church in commemoration of the baptism of Christ
sentence: I had a sudden epiphany and finally figured out how to solve the difficult math problem.
origin: Middle English Epiphanie, borrowed from Anglo-French Epiphane, Epiphanie, borrowed from Late Latin epiphanīa, epiphania "appearance, manifestation, Christ's first manifestation (to the Gentiles in Western tradition)," borrowed from Late Greek epipháneia "appearance, manifestation (of God in the Old Testament, of Christ's first coming or of the Second Coming)," going back to Greek, "appearance, coming into view, manifestation (of a deity to a worshipper), Christ's coming (in the New Testament), visible surface, outward show, fame," noun derivative of epiphanḗs "coming into view, appearing, manifest, evident," adjective derivative from the stem of epiphaínein "to show, display," mediopassive epiphaínesthai "to come into view, be manifested, appear on the surface," from epi-  + phaínein "to bring to light, cause to appear," phaínesthai "to become visible, appear"

definition: of or relating to a bishop
sentence: The word episcopal refers to anything related to a bishop or the way a church is governed.
origin: Middle English, from Late Latin episcopalis, from episcopus bishop

definition: nosebleed
sentence: The school nurse gave the boy a tissue because he had an epistaxis, which is the medical word for a nosebleed.
origin: New Latin, from Greek, from epistazein to drip on, to bleed at the nose again, from epi- + stazein to drip

definition: a characterizing word or phrase accompanying or occurring in place of the name of a person or thing
sentence: In the story, 'The Great' was an epithet used to describe the brave and powerful king.
origin: Latin epitheton, from Greek, from neuter of epithetos added, from epitithenai to put on, add, from epi- + tithenai to put

definition: an event or a time marked by an event that begins a new period or development
sentence: The invention of the wheel marked a new epoch in history because it changed how people traveled.
origin: Medieval Latin epocha, from Greek epochē cessation, fixed point, from epechein to pause, hold back, from epi- + echein to hold

definition: either of the two points on the celestial sphere where the celestial equator intersects the ecliptic
sentence: During the equinox, the day and the night are exactly the same length of time.
origin: Middle English, from Anglo-French or Medieval Latin; Anglo-French equinocce, from Medieval Latin equinoxium, alteration of Latin aequinoctium, from aequi- equi- + noct-, nox night

definition: equal in force, amount, or value; also : equal in area or volume but not superposable
sentence: Two nickels are equivalent to one dime because they are both worth ten cents.
origin: Middle English, from Middle French or Late Latin; Middle French, from Late Latin aequivalent-, aequivalens, present participle of aequivalēre to have equal power, from Latin aequi- + valēre to be strong

definition: to use equivocal language especially with intent to deceive
sentence: When I asked who broke the vase, my brother started to equivocate so he wouldn't get in trouble.

definition: to do away with as completely as if by pulling up by the roots
sentence: The gardener worked hard to eradicate all the weeds from the flower bed.
origin: Latin eradicatus, past participle of eradicare, from e- + radic-, radix root

definition: for that reason : because of that : therefore, hence
sentence: I forgot my umbrella, ergo I am going to get very wet in this rainstorm.
origin: Middle English, from Latin, from Old Latin, because of, from Old Latin *e rogo from the direction (of)

definition: any of several weasels whose coats become white in winter usually with black on the tip of the tail; especially : a weasel (Mustela erminea) chiefly of northern Eurasia and North America that has a short tail, is found in varied habitats (such as forest, grassland, and tundra), and preys especially on small mammals (such as voles and mice) : short-tailed weasel, stoat
sentence: The ermine is a small weasel whose brown fur turns snowy white in the winter.
origin: Middle English, from Anglo-French hermin, of Germanic origin; akin to Old High German harmo weasel

definition: a list of errors in a printed work discovered after printing and shown with corrections; also : a page bearing such a list
sentence: The back of the book had a page of errata to fix the small spelling mistakes in the first printing.
origin: Latin, plural of erratum

definition: containing or characterized by error : mistaken
sentence: The belief that the moon is made of green cheese is completely erroneous.
origin: Middle English, from Latin erroneus, from erron-, erro wanderer, from errare see

definition: in the past : formerly
sentence: My erstwhile neighbor moved away last year, but we still send each other postcards.

definition: becoming red or blushing.
sentence: The shy girl became erubescent when the teacher praised her beautiful drawing in front of the class.

definition: an act or instance of belching
sentence: The giant had a loud eructation after eating a whole mountain of mashed potatoes.

definition: a steep slope in front of a fortification
sentence: From the top of the steep escarpment, we could see for miles across the valley below.
origin: French escarpement, from escarper to scarp, from Middle French, from escarpe scarp, from Old Italian scarpa

definition: to avoid habitually especially on moral or practical grounds : shun
sentence: Our teacher told us to eschew using pencils that are too dull because they make the paper messy.
origin: Middle English, from Anglo-French eschiver (3rd present eschiu) of Germanic origin; akin to Old High German sciuhen to frighten off

definition: betrothal
sentence: The mayor gave a speech in espousal of the plan to build a new playground for the kids.

definition: a short musical composition designed as an exercise to improve skill.
sentence: I have to practice my piano étude every day until I can play the fast notes perfectly.

definition: the history of a linguistic form (such as a word) shown by tracing its development since its earliest recorded occurrence in the language where it is found, by tracing its transmission from one language to another, by analyzing it into its component parts, by identifying its cognates in other languages, or by tracing it and its cognates to a common ancestral form in an ancestral language
sentence: If you look in a dictionary, you can find the etymological history of where a word came from.
origin: Middle English ethimologie, from Anglo-French, from Latin etymologia, from Greek, from etymon + -logia -logy

definition: any of a genus (Eucalyptus) of mostly Australian evergreen trees or rarely shrubs of the myrtle family that have rigid entire leaves and umbellate flowers and are widely cultivated for their gums, resins, oils, and woods
sentence: Koalas love to snack on the leaves of the eucalyptus tree, which have a very strong smell.
origin: borrowed from New Latin, genus name, from Greek eu-  + kalyptós "covered," verbal adjective of kalýptein "to cover, protect, conceal"; so named for the operculum that covers the developing buds

definition: a state of physical well-being or a healthy temperament.
sentence: Eating healthy and exercising helps your body stay in a state of eucrasia, or good health.

definition: pleasing to the ear
sentence: The wind chimes made a euphonious sound as the gentle breeze moved through the garden.
origin: Late Latin euphōnia  +

definition: centered on Europe or the Europeans; especially : reflecting a tendency to interpret the world in terms of European or Anglo-American values and experiences
sentence: The history book was a bit Eurocentric because it mostly talked about events in Europe.

definition: a metallic chemical element of the rare-earth group that is used especially in television screens and fluorescent lamps
sentence: Scientists use a rare metal called europium to help create the bright colors on computer screens.
origin: New Latin, from Europa Europe

definition: a positive form of stress having a beneficial effect on health, motivation, performance, and emotional well-being
sentence: Feeling excited before a birthday party is a type of eustress, which is a positive kind of stress.

definition: one who or that which carries out or evokes.
sentence: In the science fiction story, the Evactor was a powerful machine that could pull objects through space.

definition: an evacuated person
sentence: The school gym was set up with cots to help the evacuees who had to leave their homes during the flood.

definition: tending to vanish like vapor
sentence: The rainbow was evanescent, appearing for just a moment before the clouds covered the sun.
origin: Latin evanescent-, evanescens, present participle of evanescere

definition: evolutionary developmental biology
sentence: In college, my sister is studying evo-devo to learn how animals have changed over millions of years.

definition: a member of a select Greek infantry unit often serving as a palace guard
sentence: In Greece, we saw an evzone guard wearing a traditional uniform with a kilt and pom-poms on his shoes.
origin: Modern Greek euzōnos, from Greek, active, literally, well girt, from eu- + zōnē girdle

definition: a book owner's identification label that is usually pasted to the inside front cover of a book : bookplate
sentence: I put an ex libris sticker in my favorite book so everyone knows it belongs to my library.
origin: New Latin, from the books; used before the owner's name on bookplates

definition: relating to the end of a term of office; the opposite of inaugural.
sentence: The leader gave an exaugural address to say goodbye as his time in office came to an end.

definition: fine curled wood shavings used especially for packing fragile items
sentence: Long ago, people used thin wood shavings called excelsior to pack fragile glass dishes safely.
origin: trade name, from Latin, higher, comparative of excelsus high, from past participle of excellere

definition: the act or procedure of removing by or as if by cutting out; especially : surgical removal or resection
sentence: The doctor performed a small excision to remove the splinter that was stuck deep in my finger.
origin: Middle French, from Latin excision-, excisio, from excidere

definition: to wear off the skin of : abrade
sentence: If you fall on the gravel, you might excoriate your skin and get a nasty scrape on your knee.
origin: Middle English, from Late Latin excoriatus, past participle of excoriare, from Latin ex- + corium skin, hide

definition: deserving to be execrated : detestable
sentence: The spoiled milk had an execrable smell that made everyone in the kitchen plug their noses.

definition: —used as a stage direction to specify that all or certain named characters leave the stage
sentence: The stage directions in the play said 'exeunt,' which told all the actors to leave the stage at the same time.
origin: borrowed from Latin, third person plural present indicative of exeō, exīre "to come or go out"

definition: excessively scanty : inadequate
sentence: The mouse was still hungry after eating the exiguous crumb of cheese it found on the floor.
origin: Latin exiguus, from exigere

definition: of, relating to, or affirming existence
sentence: Watching the stars can make you ask existential questions, like how big the universe really is.
origin: borrowed from Late Latin existentiālis, exsistentiālis, from existentia, exsistentia  + Latin -ālis ; in the 19th and 20th centuries in part as translation of Danish existentiel (later eksistentiel) & German existentiell

definition: the mainly narrative second book of canonical Jewish and Christian Scripture
sentence: There was a mass exodus of fans from the stadium once the game was over.
origin: Latin, from Greek Exodos, literally, road out, from ex- + hodos road

definition: produced by growth from superficial tissue
sentence: Plants need exogenous factors, like sunlight and water from the outside, to help them grow.
origin: French exogène exogenous, from exo- + -gène (from Greek -genēs born)

definition: not coming within the scope of the law
sentence: Ten dollars for a single candy bar is an exorbitant price that nobody wants to pay.
origin: Middle English, from Late Latin exorbitant-, exorbitans, present participle of exorbitare to deviate, from Latin ex- + orbita track of a wheel, rut, from orbis disk, hoop

definition: to move about freely or at will : wander
sentence: The scientist loved to expatiate on her research, talking for hours about the ants she studied.
origin: Latin exspatiatus, past participle of exspatiari to wander, digress, from ex- + spatium space, course

definition: an agent that promotes the discharge or expulsion of mucus from the respiratory tract; broadly : an antitussive agent
sentence: My dad took an expectorant medicine to help him clear the cough from his chest.

definition: the quality or state of being suited to the end in view : suitability, fitness
sentence: For the sake of expediency, we decided to take the shortcut so we wouldn't be late for dinner.

definition: a report that reveals shocking or hidden information.
sentence: The reporter wrote an exposé to show the truth about why the old bridge was breaking.

definition: a setting forth of the meaning or purpose (as of a writing)
sentence: At the beginning of the story, the exposition introduces us to the characters and where they live.
origin: see

definition: discuss, examine
sentence: My mom tried to expostulate with me about why I should wear a coat, even though I felt warm.
origin: Latin expostulatus, past participle of expostulare to demand, dispute, from ex- + postulare to ask for

definition: capable of being conquered or taken by storm.
sentence: The old wooden fort was expugnable because its walls were not strong enough to stop an army.

definition: to strike out, obliterate, or mark for deletion
sentence: The teacher used a special cleaner to expunge the permanent marker stains from the whiteboard.
origin: Latin expungere to mark for deletion by dots, from ex- + pungere to prick

definition: currently or actually existing
sentence: The blue whale is the largest animal extant, meaning it is the biggest animal currently living on Earth.
origin: Latin exstant-, exstans, present participle of exstare to stand out, be in existence, from ex- + stare to stand

definition: composed, performed, or uttered on the spur of the moment : impromptu
sentence: Since she didn't have a written speech, she gave an extemporaneous talk about her favorite hobby.
origin: Late Latin extemporāneus "done on the spur of the moment" (from Latin ex tempore "on the spur of the moment, " + -āneus, suffix forming adjectives from temporal adverbs) +

definition: tending to lessen the real or apparent seriousness of something (such as a crime, offense, or fault) : providing a partial justification or excuse for something —usually used in the phrase extenuating circumstances
sentence: The teacher allowed him to turn in his work late because there were extenuating circumstances, like his power going out.

definition: to force out or cause to escape from a proper vessel or channel
sentence: The doctor explained that a bruise happens when tiny blood vessels extravasate, or leak, under the skin.
origin: Latin extra + vas vessel

definition: facing outward
sentence: In the flower garden, we noticed that some plants have extrorse anthers that face away from the center.
origin: probably from New Latin *extrorsus, from Late Latin, adverb, outward, from Latin extra- + -orsus (as in introrsus)

definition: joking or sarcastic especially in a way regarded by others as silly, annoying, or inappropriate
sentence: I was being facetious when I said the cat was the one who ate all the cookies.
origin: borrowed from Middle French facetieux, facecieux, from facetie "joke, jesting remark" (borrowed from Latin facētia, facētiae "cleverness, wit," in plural sense, "amusing things, jests") + -eux (going back to Latin -ōsus )

definition: easily accomplished or attained
sentence: The math problem looked difficult, but once the teacher explained it, it seemed quite facile.
origin: borrowed from Anglo-French & Latin; Anglo-French, borrowed from Latin facilis "easy, accommodating, nimble," from fac-, stem of facere "to make, bring about, perform, do" + -ilis

definition: having a figured or patterned effect woven into a fabric.
sentence: My mother wore a beautiful faconne dress that had a pattern woven directly into the fabric.

definition: produced by humans rather than by natural forces
sentence: The diamond in the toy ring was factitious, meaning it was made of plastic and not real.
origin: borrowed from Latin factīcius "manufactured, artificial," from factus (past participle of facere "to make, create, bring about") + -īcius

definition: eloquence or fluency in speech.
sentence: The author’s facundity allowed him to write three whole books in just one year.

definition: relating or conforming to a thermometric scale on which under standard atmospheric pressure the boiling point of water is at 212 degrees above the zero of the scale, the freezing point is at 32 degrees above zero, and the zero point approximates the temperature produced by mixing equal quantities by weight of snow and common salt —abbreviation F
sentence: On a hot summer day, the temperature can reach ninety degrees Fahrenheit.
origin: Daniel G. Fahrenheit

definition: a marinated strip usually of beef or chicken grilled or broiled and served usually with a flour tortilla and various savory fillings —usually used in plural
sentence: We sizzled chicken and peppers in a pan to make delicious fajitas for our family dinner.
origin: American Spanish, diminutive of Spanish faja sash, belt, probably from Catalan faixa, from Latin fascia band

definition: a private secretary or attendant
sentence: In the old story, the magician's famulus helped him organize all of his magic wands and books.
origin: German, assistant to a professor, from Latin, servant

definition: a small tart covered with meringue or whipped cream.
sentence: For the tea party, we served a fanchonette, which is a small, sweet tart topped with whipped cream.

definition: a dry measure used in Spain and Spanish-speaking countries, varying from about 1.5 to 2.5 bushels.
sentence: A fanega is an old unit of measurement that farmers used to weigh out their grain.

definition: a class of specialists in ancient China who practiced divination, medicine, and magic.
sentence: We read a book about ancient China that mentioned the fang shih, who were people believed to have magic powers.

definition: of, relating to, or resembling farce : ludicrous
sentence: The play was farcical, with characters constantly tripping over things and making silly mistakes.

definition: bundle
sentence: The traveler carried a heavy fardel on his back as he walked down the dusty road.
origin: Middle English, from Anglo-French, ultimately from Arabic farda part, bundle

definition: a shrub or small tree (Vaccinium arboreum) of the heath family of the southeastern U.S. having a small hard black berry with stony seeds
sentence: The farkleberry bush has small white flowers and tiny black berries that birds love to eat.
origin: origin unknown

definition: persian
sentence: My new friend moved here from Iran and can speak Farsi fluently.
origin: Persian fārsī, from Fārs Persia

definition: a support (as of hoops) worn especially in the 16th century beneath a skirt to expand it at the hipline
sentence: In the museum, we saw a dress from hundreds of years ago that used a farthingale to make the skirt very wide.
origin: modification of Middle French verdugale, from Old Spanish verdugado, from verdugo young shoot of a tree, from verde green, from Latin viridis

definition: haughty, arrogant
sentence: The king was very fastuous and insisted on wearing a crown even when he was just eating breakfast.
origin: Latin fastuosus, from fastus arrogance

definition: complacently or inanely foolish : silly
sentence: The boy smiled fatuously at the joke, even though he didn't really understand why it was funny.
origin: Latin fatuus foolish

definition: a figure in Roman mythology similar to but gentler than the satyr
sentence: A faun is a mythical creature that is half human and half goat, like Mr. Tumnus in Narnia.
origin: Middle English, from Latin faunus, from Faunus

definition: the fidelity of a vassal or feudal tenant to a lord
sentence: The knights swore fealty to the queen, promising to protect her and the kingdom.
origin: Middle English feute, fealtye, borrowed from Anglo-French feelté, fealté, going back to Latin fidēlitāt-, fidēlitās "faithfulness, loyalty"

definition: weak, ineffective
sentence: The feckless character in the movie always forgot to lock his door and lost his keys every day.
origin: from Scots, earlier fectles "valueless, futile," from fek, fect (later feck) "value, efficacy" (aphetic form of effect ) + -les

definition: fruitful in offspring or vegetation : prolific
sentence: The soil in the valley is very fecund, which is why the vegetables grow so large and healthy.
origin: Middle English, from Anglo-French, from Latin fecundus

definition: to give a false appearance of : induce as a false impression
sentence: The puppy would often feign sleep so that he wouldn't have to go outside in the rain.
origin: Middle English feynen, feignen "to make, fabricate, make a likeness of, dissemble, pretend to be," borrowed from Anglo-French feign-, stem of feindre, going back to Latin fingere "to mold, fashion, make a likeness of, pretend to be," going back to Indo-European *dhi-n-ǵh- (whence also Old Irish con-utuinc "builds, constructs," Armenian dizanem "[I] heap up"), present tense derivative of *dhei̯ǵh- "knead, shape," whence Gothic digan "to knead, form from clay," Old Church Slavic ziždǫ, zĭdati "to build," Lithuanian žiedžiù, žiẽsti "to form, shape (from clay)" (Balto-Slavic with metathesis of stop consonants), Armenian edēz "(s/he) heaped up," Tocharian B tsik- "fashion, shape, build," Sanskrit pari … déhat "will cover over, smear over"

definition: having one or more openings or pores
sentence: The building had a fenestrated wall, which is a fancy way of saying it had lots of windows.

definition: an opening in a tectonic unit that reveals the underlying rock layers.
sentence: Fenster is the German word for window, which I learned in my world languages class.

definition: a weekday of a church calendar on which no feast falls
sentence: During the feria, the whole town was filled with music, dancing, and colorful stalls.
origin: Medieval Latin

definition: marked by great intensity of feeling; zealous.
sentence: The crowd gave a fervorous cheer when the home team scored the winning goal.

definition: to hang or form festoons on
sentence: The living room was festooned with bright balloons and streamers for the surprise party.
origin: see

definition: the system of political organization prevailing in Europe from the 9th to about the 15th centuries having as its basis the relation of lord to vassal with all land held in fee and as chief characteristics homage, the service of tenants under arms and in court, wardship, and forfeiture
sentence: We learned about feudalism, a system where kings and lords ruled over the land in the Middle Ages.

definition: an authoritative or arbitrary order : decree
sentence: The principal issued a fiat that all students must wear their school t-shirts on Friday.
origin: Latin, let it be done, 3rd singular present subjunctive of fieri to become, be done

definition: the outer and usually smaller of the two bones between the knee and ankle in the hind or lower limbs of vertebrates
sentence: The fibula is the smaller of the two bones in your lower leg, located right next to the shin bone.
origin: Latin, pin, clasp; akin to Latin figere to fasten

definition: plastic
sentence: Clay is a fictile material because it can be easily molded into any shape you want.
origin: borrowed from Latin fictilis "made of earthenware," from fig-, variant stem of fingere "to mold, fashion" + -tilis "obtained by, produced by (the action of the verb)"

definition: of, relating to, or involving a confidence or trust: such as
sentence: A banker has a fiduciary duty to take good care of the money that people give them.
origin: borrowed from Latin fīdūciārius "holding in trust, of a trustee, (of property) held on trust," from fīdūcia "transference of a property on trust, trust, reliance, confidence" (from *fīdūcus "trusting" —from fīdere "to trust [in], have confidence [in]" + -ūcus, deverbal adjective suffix— + -ia ) + -ārius

definition: a usually foliated ornament forming an upper extremity especially in Gothic architecture
sentence: The top of the fence post was decorated with a small, round finial made of iron.
origin: Middle English, from final, finial final

definition: any of a group of wind instruments (such as a flageolet or recorder) having a straight tubular shape, a whistle mouthpiece, and finger holes
sentence: The recorder I play in music class has a fipple, which is the part you blow into to make sound.
origin: origin unknown

definition: a small wooden vessel or cask
sentence: A firkin is a small wooden barrel that was used a long time ago to store butter or fish.
origin: Middle English, ultimately from Middle Dutch veerdel fourth, from veer four; akin to Old English fēower

definition: a high, barren plateau, especially in Scandinavia.
sentence: In Norway, a fjeld is a high, rocky mountain plateau where the wind blows very hard.

definition: a large usually metal or pottery vessel (as for wine) with handle and spout and often a lid
sentence: The knight poured some cool water from a large metal flagon into his cup.
origin: Middle English, from Middle French flascon, flacon bottle, from Late Latin flascon-, flasco

definition: served in a flaming sauce of spirits or liqueur.
sentence: The chef made a flambé dessert by carefully setting a small amount of liquid on fire.

definition: an idle man-about-town
sentence: A flaneur is someone who likes to walk around the city slowly just to see all the sights.
origin: French flâneur

definition: a usually corn tortilla rolled tightly around a filling (as of meat) and deep-fried
sentence: For lunch, I had a flauta, which is a crispy rolled taco that looks like a little flute.
origin: American Spanish, literally, flute

definition: the colored outer layer of the rind of a citrus fruit : the pigmented exocarp of a hesperidium
sentence: The flavedo is the colored outer layer of an orange peel that smells so good when you zest it.
origin: borrowed from New Latin flāvēdō yellow color, from Latin flāvus yellow + -ēdō (as in Late Latin albēdō whiteness) ,

definition: a slender spire, especially one over the intersection of the nave and the transepts of a church.
sentence: The church had a very thin, beautiful flèche, which is a small spire on the roof.

definition: referring to the bark of young oak trees, often used in tanning.
sentence: The flittern bark of the young oak tree was much smoother than the bark on the old trees.

definition: of or relating to Florence, Italy
sentence: My mom made a Florentine omelet, which means it was filled with lots of healthy spinach.
origin: borrowed from Medieval Latin Flōrentīnus, from Flōrentia  + Latin -īnus

definition: any of various usually small, compact roses with large flowers in open clusters that derive from crosses of polyantha and tea roses
sentence: The floribunda rose bush in our yard is covered in dozens of small, beautiful flowers.
origin: borrowed from New Latin, originally a specific epithet of various plants, from feminine of flōribundus, apparently taken to mean "full of flowers, flowering freely," from Latin flōrēre "to bloom" + -bundus "carrying on (the activity denoted by the verb)"

definition: a period of flourishing (as of a person or movement)
sentence: The floruit of that famous artist was during the 1920s when he painted his best work.
origin: borrowed from Latin flōruit "(s/he) prospered, flourished," 3rd singular perfect of flōrēre "to bloom, prosper, be at the peak of one's powers"

definition: the First Lady of the United States —often used like a nickname
sentence: FLOTUS is a short way of saying 'First Lady of the United States.'

definition: a compound of fluorine
sentence: Our dentist gives us a fluoride treatment to help keep our teeth strong and healthy.

definition: a flat Italian bread typically seasoned with herbs and olive oil
sentence: We had a piece of salty focaccia bread topped with rosemary and olive oil.
origin: Italian, from Late Latin focacia (neuter plural), from Latin focus hearth

definition: a small anatomical cavity or deep narrow-mouthed depression
sentence: Each hair on your head grows out of a tiny hole in your skin called a follicle.
origin: New Latin folliculus, from Latin, diminutive of follis bag

definition: a cheese that is semisoft to hard in texture and mild to medium sharp in flavor
sentence: Fontina is a creamy, mild cheese that melts perfectly on a grilled cheese sandwich.
origin: Italian

definition: feeding on forbs (herbaceous flowering plants that are not grasses).
sentence: An animal that is forbivorous likes to eat small flowering plants instead of grass.

definition: very loud —used especially as a direction in music
sentence: The music teacher told the band to play fortissimo, which means very, very loud.
origin: Italian, superlative of forte

definition: a style of black-letter typeface or the traditional folk art of German Americans.
sentence: We saw an old book that used fractur, which is a type of fancy, pointed German handwriting.

definition: a member of the Order of Friars Minor founded by St. Francis of Assisi in 1209 and dedicated especially to preaching, missions, and charities
sentence: The Franciscan monk wore a simple brown robe with a white rope tied around his waist.
origin: Medieval Latin Franciscus Francis

definition: a drink, such as a liqueur or coffee, served over or blended with crushed ice.
sentence: On a hot day, a cold coffee frappé is a very refreshing treat.

definition: debris or excrement produced by insects
sentence: While looking at the tree, the gardener found some frass, which is the sawdust that wood-eating bugs leave behind.
origin: German, insect damage, literally, eating away, from Old High German vrāz food, from frezzan to devour

definition: a grouping or organization of brothers or people with common interests.
sentence: The kids formed a fratority, a group where everyone promised to be as kind as brothers and sisters.

definition: characterized by, based on, or done by fraud : deceitful
sentence: It is fraudulent to use someone else's name to sign a paper without their permission.

definition: in Zoroastrianism, the guardian spirit or higher self of an individual.
sentence: In ancient stories, a fravashi is like a guardian spirit that watches over a person.

definition: ice crystals formed in turbulent water, such as a fast-flowing river.
sentence: When the river starts to freeze, small ice crystals called frazil form in the moving water.

definition: of, relating to, or according with the psychoanalytic theories or practices of Sigmund Freud
sentence: The teacher mentioned a Freudian slip, which is when you accidentally say what you are really thinking.

definition: the waste silk produced during the process of reeling silk from cocoons.
sentence: A frison is the fuzzy part of silk that is left over after the best threads are pulled away.

definition: fritillaria
sentence: I saw a beautiful orange fritillary butterfly landing on a purple flower.
origin: New Latin fritillaria

definition: an unfolded omelet often containing chopped vegetables or meats
sentence: My dad made a big frittata with eggs, cheese, and peppers for our Sunday brunch.
origin: Italian, from fritto fried

definition: habitually disposed to disobedience and opposition
sentence: The froward puppy refused to sit and kept running in the opposite direction during training.
origin: Middle English, turned away, froward, from fro from + -ward -ward

definition: bearing or producing fruit.
sentence: An apple tree is fructiferous because it is a plant that produces delicious fruit.

definition: feeding on fruit
sentence: A fruit bat is a frugivore because its main diet consists of sweet fruit.
origin: borrowed from Medieval Latin frūgivorus "crop-devouring," from Latin frūg-, frūx "edible produce of plants, fruit, crops" + -i-  + -vorus

definition: relating to or resembling the rockweeds
sentence: While at the beach, we found a fucoid, which is a type of seaweed that looks like a brown plant.
origin: New Latin Fucus, from Latin

definition: a musical composition in which one or two themes are repeated or imitated by successively entering voices and contrapuntally developed in a continuous interweaving of the voice parts
sentence: In music class, we listened to a fugue, where the same melody is repeated by different instruments.
origin: probably from Italian fuga flight, fugue, from Latin, flight, from fugere

definition: a seabird (Fulmarus glacialis) of colder northern seas closely related to the petrels; also : a related bird (F. glacialoides) of circumpolar distribution in colder southern seas
sentence: The fulmar is a sea bird that looks like a seagull and flies over the cold ocean waves.
origin: of Scandinavian origin; akin to Old Norse fūlmār fulmar, from fūll foul + mār gull

definition: to utter or send out with denunciation
sentence: The angry giant began to fulminate, shouting so loudly that the whole mountain shook.
origin: Middle English fulminaten "to direct (condemnation at an offender)," borrowed from Late Latin fulminātus, past participle of fulmināre "to strike down, confound (an opponent)" (Medieval Latin, "to thunder [threats, denunciations]"), going back to Latin, "to strike (of lightning), strike like lightning," derivative of fulmin-, fulmen "lightning," from fulg- (base of fulgēre "to shine brightly, flash, lighten") + -min-, -men, resultative noun suffix

definition: tightrope walking
sentence: A funambulist is a very brave circus performer who walks across a high tightrope.
origin: Latin funambulus ropewalker, from funis rope + ambulare to walk

definition: being something (such as money or a commodity) of such a nature that one part or quantity may be replaced by another equal part or quantity in paying a debt or settling an account
sentence: Money is fungible because one ten-dollar bill has the exact same value as any other ten-dollar bill.
origin: New Latin fungibilis, from Latin fungi to perform

definition: a forked process or part: such as
sentence: The furcula is the V-shaped bone in a bird, which people often call a 'wishbone.'
origin: New Latin, from Latin, forked prop, diminutive of furca

definition: tapering toward each end
sentence: Many fish have a fusiform shape, meaning they are wide in the middle and pointy at the ends to help them swim fast.
origin: borrowed from New Latin fūsifōrmis, from Latin fūsus "spindle" (of obscure origin) + -i-  + -fōrmis

definition: one who fusses or is fussy especially about trifles
sentence: My little brother is a bit of a fussbudget when it comes to his socks; they have to be perfectly straight.

definition: a cloth or leather leg covering reaching from the instep to above the ankle or to mid-calf or knee
sentence: To keep the snow out of his boots, the hiker wore waterproof gaiters over his lower legs.
origin: borrowed from French guêtre, going back to Middle French guiestres (plural), probably going back to a metathetical variant of Old Low Franconian *wrist- "ankle joint," going back to Germanic *wrih-sti- (whence Middle High German rist, riste "wrist or ankle joint," Old English wrist "wrist joint")

definition: a species of giant tortoise native to the Galápagos Islands.
sentence: The giant galapago tortoise can live for over one hundred years and grows to be very large.

definition: a membranous muscular sac in which bile from the liver is concentrated and stored before being passed to the intestinal duodenum
sentence: The gallbladder is a small organ that helps your body digest fats from the food you eat.

definition: of or relating to Gaul or France
sentence: We learned about the Gallic wars, where the ancient people of France fought against the Romans.
origin: borrowed from Latin Gallicus, from Gallus "a " + -icus

definition: a padded defensive jacket worn as armor or under chainmail.
sentence: A knight wore a padded coat called a gambeson under his heavy metal armor to stay comfortable.

definition: a chess opening in which a player risks one or more pawns or a minor piece to gain an advantage in position
sentence: Opening the lemonade stand early was a clever gambit to sell more drinks before the parade started.
origin: borrowed from Spanish gambito, borrowed from Italian gambetto, literally, "act of tripping someone," from gamba "leg" (going back to Late Latin) + -etto, diminutive suffix

definition: a sweet creamy chocolate mixture used especially as a filling or frosting
sentence: The baker poured a smooth, shiny chocolate ganache over the top of the birthday cake.
origin: borrowed from French, originally a kind of bonbon manufactured by the Parisian confectioner Siraudin (probably after Les Ganaches, a play by Victorien  first performed in October, 1862), literally, "lower jaw of a horse, jowl, imbecile," borrowed from Italian (Tuscan) ganascia "jaw, jowl," central Italian ganassa, going back to Vulgar Latin (northern and central Italy) *ganassa, re-formation (with gender conformed to the source noun) of Greek gnȧthos "jaw" (attested in Medieval Latin of Italy as ganathos)

definition: a room or unfinished part of a house just under the roof
sentence: The artist lived in a tiny garret room at the very top of the house, right under the roof.
origin: Middle English garite "watchtower, turret, room under a roof," borrowed from Anglo-French & continental Old French, alteration by suffix substitution (after fuite "flight," from fuir "to flee") of garrette "shelter for a sentry," from garir "to support, protect" + -ette, deverbal and diminutive suffix ,

definition: having the form of or being gas; also : of or relating to gases
sentence: Steam is the gaseous form of water that rises into the air when a pot begins to boil.

definition: having the form or nature of a gas.
sentence: The scientist explained that when a liquid evaporates, it turns into a gasiform state.

definition: a lover of good food; especially : one with a serious interest in gastronomy
sentence: My uncle is a true gastronome who travels all over the world just to try famous new foods.
origin: French, back-formation from gastronomie

definition: showy ornamentation; especially : personal finery
sentence: The costume was covered in bright feathers and shiny sequins, adding a lot of gaudery to the show.

definition: a large wild ox (Bos gaurus) of India and southeast Asia with a broad forehead and short thick curved horns
sentence: The gaur is a massive wild ox from India that is known for being very strong and powerful.
origin: Hindi, from Sanskrit gaura; akin to Sanskrit go bull, cow

definition: resembling gelatin or jelly : viscous
sentence: A jellyfish has a gelatinous body that feels like soft, wiggly jelly when you touch it.

definition: a commentary on the Mishnah forming the second part of the Talmud
sentence: The students studied the Gemara to learn more about the traditions and laws of their faith.
origin: Aramaic gĕmārā completion

definition: the third zodiacal constellation that is pictorially represented as the twins Castor and Pollux sitting together, that is visible in the sky on the opposite side of the Milky Way from Taurus and Orion, and that is located between Cancer and Taurus in the zodiac
sentence: If you were born in early June, your zodiac sign is Gemini, which is represented by twins.
origin: Latin (genitive Geminorum), literally, the twins (Castor and Pollux)

definition: an account of the descent of a person, family, or group from an ancestor or from older forms
sentence: My grandmother showed me a genealogical chart that lists all of our relatives from a long time ago.
origin: Middle English genealogie, from Anglo-French, from Late Latin genealogia, from Greek, from genea race, family + -logia -logy; akin to Greek genos race

definition: nativity, birth
sentence: The king's first son was the heir to the throne by right of geniture, meaning his birth order.

definition: one haploid set of chromosomes with the genes they contain; broadly : the genetic material of an organism
sentence: Every living thing has a genome, which is like a giant instruction book for how its body is built.
origin: German Genom, from Gen gene + -om (as in Chromosom chromosome)

definition: a game in which players are given the geographical coordinates of a cache of items which they search for with a GPS device
sentence: We used a GPS on our phone to go geocaching and find a hidden treasure box in the park.

definition: a branch of medicine that deals with the problems and diseases of old age and the medical care and treatment of aging people
sentence: The vet specialized in geriatric care to help older dogs stay healthy and happy.
origin: geriatrics from Greek gḗras "old age" + ; gḗras going back to a lengthened grade ablaut derivative of an Indo-European verbal base *ǵerh2- "become old, ripen," whence also, with varying ablaut and suffixation, Greek géras "gift of honor," geraiós "old," Old Church Slavic sŭzĭrějǫ, sŭzĭrěti "to ripen, mature," Armenian cer "old man, old," Sanskrit járati "(s/he) makes old, ages, decays," jaraṇáḥ "old, decayed," jarā́ "old age," Avestan zarəta- "old," azarəšant- "unaging," Persian zar "old man," zāl "(of persons) old"

definition: relating to a subject in an appropriate way : fitting
sentence: The teacher asked us to only share facts that were germane to the topic of dinosaurs.
origin: Middle English germain, literally, having the same parents, from Anglo-French

definition: marked by convexity or swelling
sentence: The moon looked gibbous tonight, meaning it was more than half full but not yet a circle.
origin: Middle English, from Late Latin gibbosus humpbacked, from Latin gibbus hump

definition: inflammation of the gums
sentence: Brushing your teeth every day helps prevent gingivitis, which can make your gums red and sore.

definition: a person engaged in a fight to the death as public entertainment for ancient Romans
sentence: In ancient Rome, people went to the Colosseum to watch gladiatorial games.
origin: Latin, from gladius sword, of Celtic origin; akin to Welsh cleddyf sword

definition: one who sets glass
sentence: A glazier came to our house to fix the broken window and put in a new pane of glass.

definition: of, relating to, or constituting glia
sentence: Glial cells are important because they protect and support the nerve cells in your brain.

definition: a rapid sliding up or down the musical scale
sentence: The harpist played a beautiful glissando by sliding her fingers quickly across the strings.
origin: probably modification of French glissade

definition: tongue
sentence: The preacher spoke in glossolalia, which sounded like a language that no one had ever heard before.
origin: probably borrowed from German Glossolalie, Glossolalia, from glosso-  + Greek laliá "talk, speech" (from laléō, laleîn "to talk, chat"—of onomatopoeic origin— + -ia ), after Greek laleîn glṓssais and variants in the New Testament (as Acts 2:4), conventionally translated "to speak in tongues"

definition: marked by or given to gluttony
sentence: The gluttonous squirrel tried to stuff ten acorns into its mouth at the same time.
origin: see

definition: of or relating to the jaw
sentence: The scientist studied the gnathic structure of the fossil to see how the dinosaur's jaw worked.
origin: Greek gnathos jaw

definition: dumplings usually made with potato or semolina and served with sauce

origin: Italian, plural of gnocco, from Italian dialect (Veneto), probably of Germanic origin; akin to Middle High German knöchel knuckle, knoche bone

definition: an adherent of gnosticism

definition: of, relating to, living in, or being a controlled environment containing one or a few kinds of organisms; also : axenic

definition: the dark red, mildly tart berry of a thorny, chiefly Asian shrub (Lycium barbarum and L. chinense) that is typically dried and used in beverages
sentence: My mom put a handful of dried goji berries in my oatmeal because they are full of vitamins.
origin: modification of Chinese (Beijing) gǒuqǐ the shrub Lycium chinense

definition: an artificial human being in Hebrew folklore endowed with life
sentence: In the old legend, a man built a golem out of clay to help protect his village.

definition: a Philistine champion who in I Samuel 17 is killed by David

definition: a film of cobwebs floating in air in calm clear weather

definition: new york city —an informal name

definition: a usually older woman of great prestige or ability

definition: a lofty, extravagantly colorful, pompous, or bombastic style, manner, or quality especially in language

origin: probably from Middle French, from Latin grandiloquus using lofty language, from grandis + loqui to speak

definition: a yarn made of two or more differently colored strands twisted together.
sentence: My new shirt is made of grandrelle yarn, which uses two different colors twisted together.

definition: reticle
sentence: A graticule is the grid of lines on a map that helps you find the exact latitude and longitude.
origin: French, from Latin craticula fine latticework, diminutive of cratis wickerwork, hurdle

definition: the measurement of weight, a gravitational field, or density
sentence: Scientists use gravimetry to measure the strength of gravity in different parts of the world.
origin: + , after  and

definition: high seriousness (as in a person's bearing or in the treatment of a subject)

origin: borrowed from Latin gravitās "heaviness, weight, dignity, seriousness"

definition: a musical direction meaning graceful, smooth, or elegant.

definition: armor for the shin
sentence: The knight buckled his shiny metal greaves onto his shins to protect his legs in battle.
origin: Middle English greve, from Anglo-French

definition: of or relating to Pope Gregory XIII or the Gregorian calendar
sentence: Most of the world uses the Gregorian calendar, which has 365 days in a normal year.

definition: adapted for walking, as the feet of certain birds or insects.
sentence: Insects like ants have gressorial legs that are perfectly designed for walking long distances.

definition: a long, slender, crusty breadstick of Italian origin.
sentence: At the Italian restaurant, I snacked on a crunchy grissino breadstick while waiting for my pizza.

definition: hulled grain broken into fragments larger than grits

definition: a rude, boorish, or crude person.

definition: of, relating to, or having the characteristics of the grotesque: such as

origin: see

definition: any of various chiefly ground-dwelling birds (family Tetraonidae) that are usually of reddish-brown or other protective color and have feathered legs and that include many important game birds
sentence: While walking in the woods, we saw a grouse bird fly out from the bushes.
origin: origin unknown

definition: of or relating to a governor
sentence: The people went to the polls to vote in the gubernatorial election to choose their new governor.
origin: Latin gubernator governor, steersman, from gubernare to govern

definition: pivot, journal
sentence: A gudgeon is a small freshwater fish that is often used as bait by fishermen.
origin: Middle English gojoun, from Middle French goujon

definition: a machine for beheading by means of a heavy blade that slides down in vertical guides
sentence: In history class, we saw a picture of a guillotine, a machine used a long time ago in France.

definition: the heraldic color red
sentence: In heraldry, gules is the special word used to describe the color red on a shield.

definition: easily duped or cheated; especially : quick to believe something that is not true
sentence: The prankster relied on the boy's gullibility to make him believe that the moon was made of cheese.
origin: see

definition: enterprise, initiative
sentence: It took a lot of gumption for the girl to stand up and speak in front of the whole school.
origin: origin unknown

definition: gyrocompass
sentence: For lunch, I had a tasty gyro, which is meat and vegetables wrapped in a soft pita bread.

definition: any of several common-law writs issued to bring a party before a court or judge; especially : habeas corpus ad subjiciendum
sentence: Habeas corpus is a rule that says a person cannot be kept in jail without a fair reason.

definition: characteristic apparatus : trappings

definition: lacking in freshness or originality
sentence: The phrase 'it's not you, it's me' has become very hackneyed because people say it too often.

definition: a narrative record of the sayings or customs of Muhammad and his companions

definition: a writer of hagiography

definition: sanctioned by Islamic law; especially : ritually fit for use

origin: Arabic ḥalāl permissible

definition: Earl of 1881—1959 Edward Frederick Lindley Wood English statesman and diplomat
sentence: My pen pal lives in Halifax, which is a beautiful city on the coast of Canada.

definition: to affect with visions or imaginary perceptions

origin: Latin hallucinatus, past participle of hallucinari, allucinari to prate, dream, modification of Greek alyein to be distressed, to wander

definition: a usually vertical gradient in salinity (as of the ocean)
sentence: A halocline is a place in the water where the salty water meets the fresh water.

definition: the accidental omission of a letter or group of letters in writing or copying.
sentence: The student made an error of haplography when he accidentally skipped a letter while writing 'Mississippi.'

definition: a speech addressed to a public assembly

definition: someone or something that foreshadows a future event : one that gives an anticipatory sign of what is to come

definition: any of a breed of hunting dogs resembling a small English foxhound and originally bred for hunting rabbits
sentence: We watched a harrier hawk glide over the marsh looking for its next meal.

definition: the ancient Egyptian goddess of love, happiness, and music, often represented with the head or horns of a cow.
sentence: Hathor was an ancient Egyptian goddess who was often shown with the ears of a cow.

definition: a tunic of chain mail worn as defensive armor from the 12th to the 14th century

origin: Middle English hauberk, haubrek, borrowed from Anglo-French hauberc (also continental Old French), borrowed from Old Low Franconian *halsberg- (cognate with Old English healsbearh, halsbearh "mail tunic," Middle Dutch halsberch, Old High German halsberg, halsberga), from Germanic *halsa- "neck" + *-berga-, *-bergō- "protection" ,

definition: arrogance, haughtiness

definition: a native or resident of Hawaii; especially : one of Polynesian ancestry

definition: a monetary unit of the Chumash people, traditionally consisting of shell beads.

definition: a vehicle for conveying the remains of a deceased person to the grave

definition: the doctrine that pleasure or happiness is the sole or chief good in life

definition: strong influence or authority over others : domination

definition: relating to the period in Japanese history (794–1185) characterized by the flourishing of court culture.

definition: the plankton found in small, shallow ponds or marshes.

definition: relating to or near the sun —used especially of the last setting of a star before and its first rising after invisibility due to conjunction with the sun

definition: a group of seven

definition: the study of the methodological principles of interpretation (as of the Bible)

definition: in an airtight manner : so as to be completely airtight —usually used in the phrase hermetically sealed

definition: a condition in which the irises of the eyes are different in color.

definition: of or relating to sacred rites or liturgy.

definition: a species of cypress native to central Japan, valued for its high-quality timber.

definition: hipness

definition: city and port on the Inland Sea in southwestern Honshu, Japan population 1,173,843

definition: theatrical performances

definition: Sir Alfred Joseph 1899—1980 British film director

definition: thoughtless giddy behavior
