definition: a large lobulated gland of vertebrates that secretes digestive enzymes and the hormones insulin and glucagon
sentence: The pancreas is an organ in your body that helps you digest food and control your blood sugar.
origin: New Latin, from Greek pankreas sweetbread, from pan- + kreas flesh, meat

definition: an optical instrument combining the telescope and microscope
sentence: The building was designed as a panopticon, so a guard in the center could see all the rooms at once.

definition: pantomimist
sentence: During the game, I had to use pantomime to act out 'brushing my teeth' without saying a word.
origin: Latin pantomimus, from pant- + mimus mime

definition: a tall perennial sedge (Cyperus papyrus) of the Nile valley
sentence: Ancient Egyptians made a type of paper called papyrus from the tall reeds that grew by the river.
origin: Middle English, from Latin

definition: being the best of a kind : preeminent
sentence: The baker is a pastry chef par excellence, meaning he is the very best at making cakes.
origin: French, literally, by excellence

definition: a plane curve generated by a point moving so that its distance from a fixed point is equal to its distance from a fixed line : the intersection of a right circular cone with a plane parallel to an element of the cone
sentence: When you throw a ball into the air, its path follows a curve called a parabola.
origin: borrowed from New Latin, borrowed from Greek parabolḗ "juxtaposition, placement of a figure in contact with another, parabola"

definition: an arbitrary constant whose value characterizes a member of a system (such as a family of curves); also : a quantity (such as a mean or variance) that describes a statistical population
sentence: The teacher set the parameters for the project, telling us exactly how long it should be.
origin: New Latin, from para- + Greek metron measure

definition: partial or complete paralysis of the lower half of the body with involvement of both legs that is usually due to injury or disease of the spinal cord in the thoracic or lumbar region
sentence: The brave athlete didn't let being paraplegic stop him from competing in the wheelchair race.
origin: New Latin, from Greek paraplēgiē hemiplegia, from para- + -plēgia -plegia

definition: a lightweight umbrella used as a sunshade
sentence: The woman held a colorful parasol to keep the sun off her face while she walked in the park.
origin: borrowed from French, "screen or canopy shielding from the sun," going back to Middle French, borrowed from Italian parasole, from para "(it) shields, keeps out" (3rd singular present of parare "to prepare, adorn, avert, shield") + sole "sun," going back to Latin sōl ,

definition: a small, decorative triangular dagger worn by high-ranking military officers in ancient Rome.
sentence: In the museum, we saw a parazonium, which was a short sword worn by officers in ancient Rome.

definition: an arrangement of rope for hoisting or lowering a cylindrical object by making fast the middle of the rope aloft and looping both ends around the object which rests in the loops and rolls in them as the ends are hauled up or paid out; also : a single line made fast at one end and passed around an object that is used similarly
sentence: The workers used a parbuckle, a system of ropes, to roll the heavy log up the ramp.
origin: origin unknown

definition: —used for a board game adapted from pachisi
sentence: My family loves to play Parcheesi, a classic board game where you try to get all your pieces home.

definition: a raw hide soaked in lye to remove the hair and dried
sentence: Native Americans used a parfleche, which is a bag made of tough rawhide, to carry their belongings.
origin: Canadian French parflèche, from French parer to ward off + flèche arrow

definition: one that is despised or rejected : outcast
sentence: The student felt like a pariah when no one would sit with him after he was mean to the group.
origin: Tamil paṟaiyan, literally, drummer

definition: to bet in a parlay
sentence: The girl tried to parlay her small allowance into a big savings account by doing extra chores.
origin: verbal derivative (perhaps with conformation to  or French parler "to speak") of paroli "series of bets set up so that the original stake and winnings are placed on successive wagers," borrowed from French, borrowed from Italian, plural of parolo (stress on first syllable), of uncertain origin

definition: a very hard dry sharply flavored cheese that is sold grated or in wedges
sentence: I like to sprinkle extra Parmesan cheese on top of my spaghetti and meatballs.
origin: short for Parmesan cheese; Parmesan "of the city of Parma," borrowed from Middle French parmisan, probably borrowed from a western Upper Italian variant of Tuscan parmigiano, from Parma "Parma" + -igiano, adjective suffix of appurtenance, from Vulgar Latin *-ēs- (going back to Latin -ensis, adjective suffix of place) + Latin -iānus

definition: of or relating to a church parish
sentence: Some of my friends go to a parochial school, which is a school run by a local church.
origin: Middle English parochiall, from Anglo-French parochial, from Late Latin parochialis, from parochia parish

definition: a literary or musical work in which the style of an author or work is closely imitated for comic effect or in ridicule
sentence: The funny song was parodic, making fun of a famous pop star's serious music.
origin: Latin parodia, from Greek parōidia, from para- + aidein to sing

definition: a young salmon actively feeding in fresh water
sentence: A parr is a young salmon that has dark stripes and lives in the river before going to the ocean.
origin: origin unknown

definition: a unit of measure for interstellar space that is equal to 3.26 light-years and is the distance to an object having a parallax of one second as seen from points separated by one astronomical unit
sentence: In science fiction movies, pilots often use a parsec to measure the huge distances between stars.
origin: parallax + second

definition: the quality of being careful with money or resources : thrift
sentence: Because of his parsimony, the man refused to spend money even on a new pair of shoes.
origin: Middle English parcimony, borrowed from Latin parsimōnia, from pars-, perfect stem of parcere "to act sparingly, be thrifty (with), refrain from" (of uncertain origin) + -i-  + -mōnia, suffix of abstract nouns (going back to the Indo-European noun-forming suffix *-mĕ̄n-/*mŏ̄n- + the abstract noun formative *-i-)

definition: the quality or state of being partial : bias
sentence: The judge showed partiality by choosing his own daughter as the winner of the contest.

definition: of or relating to minute separate particles
sentence: Smoke is made of tiny particulate matter that can make it hard for people to breathe.
origin: Latin particula

definition: bringing forth or about to bring forth young
sentence: The parturient cat found a quiet, cozy spot in the closet to have her kittens.
origin: borrowed from Latin parturient-, parturiens, present participle of parturīre "to be in labor, be ready to give birth," from partus (past participle of parere "to give birth to, bring into being, produce") + -urīre, desiderative suffix; parere, going back to Indo-European *perh3-/*pr̥h3- "bring forth, give rise to, produce," whence also Old Irish ernaid "(s/he) bestows, grants," Greek époron "(s/he) provided, gave, granted," Sanskrit pṛṇā́ti "(s/he) gives, bestows"

definition: parvovirus
sentence: We had to take the puppy to the vet to get a vaccine so he wouldn't get sick with parvo.

definition: a fine wool similar to cashmere made from the undercoat of domestic Himalayan goats; also : a shawl made from this wool
sentence: My mom wore a soft pashmina shawl over her shoulders to stay warm during the evening party.
origin: Persian, from pashmin woolen, from pashm wool

definition: out of date; no longer fashionable.
sentence: My older brother thinks my favorite cartoon is passé and that I should watch cooler shows.

definition: to subject to pasteurization
sentence: Factories pasteurize milk by heating it up to kill any germs that might make people sick.
origin: Louis Pasteur

definition: a highly seasoned smoked beef prepared especially from shoulder cuts
sentence: For lunch, my dad made a sandwich with thin slices of spicy pastrami and mustard.
origin: Yiddish pastrame, from Romanian pastramă pressed and cured meat

definition: a thick flat triangular movable bone that forms the anterior point of the knee and protects the front of the joint : kneecap
sentence: The patella is the scientific name for your kneecap, which protects the joint in your leg.
origin: Latin, from diminutive of patina shallow dish

definition: an element in experience or in artistic representation evoking pity or compassion
sentence: The sad ending of the movie was full of pathos and made almost everyone in the theater cry.
origin: borrowed from Greek páthos "experience, misfortune, emotion, condition," noun derivative of a verbal base path- "experience, undergo, suffer" (present páschō, páschein, aorist épathon), going back to *p(h)nth-, zero ablaut grade of a base seen also in pénthos "grief, sorrow," of uncertain origin

definition: a name derived from that of the father or a paternal ancestor usually by the addition of an affix
sentence: In some cultures, your last name is a patronymic, meaning it comes from your father's first name.
origin: ultimately from Greek patronymia patronymic, from patr- + onyma name

definition: smallness of number : fewness
sentence: The paucity of rain this summer meant that all the grass in the park turned brown.
origin: Middle English paucite, from Latin paucitat-, paucitas, from paucus little

definition: an opponent of war; specifically : one who participates in antiwar demonstrations
sentence: My uncle was a real peacenik who always carried signs and marched for world peace.

definition: embezzle
sentence: The employee was caught trying to peculate money from the cash register.
origin: Latin peculatus, past participle of peculari, from peculium

definition: consisting of or measured in money
sentence: Winning the contest provided a pecuniary reward of fifty dollars.
origin: Latin pecuniarius, from pecunia money

definition: pedantic presentation or application of knowledge or learning
sentence: The student's pedantry made him correct the teacher's spelling, even over a tiny mistake.

definition: of or relating to the open sea.
sentence: Tuna and sharks live in the pelagial zone, which is the open part of the ocean away from the shore.

definition: a woman's narrow cape made of fabric or fur and usually with long ends hanging down in front
sentence: In the historical museum, we saw a pelerine, which is a small cape that covers only the shoulders.
origin: probably from French pèlerine

definition: money, riches
sentence: The greedy pirate only cared about the pelf he found inside the treasure chest.
origin: Middle English, from Anglo-French pelfre booty

definition: peninsula between the Ionian Sea and the Aegean Sea forming the southern part of the mainland of Greece
sentence: The Peloponnesian War was a famous battle in ancient Greece between the cities of Athens and Sparta.

definition: one of the concave triangular members that support a dome over a square space
sentence: A pendentive is a triangular piece of masonry that helps hold up a round dome over a square room.
origin: borrowed from French pendentif, going back to Middle French, from Latin pendent-, pendens, present participle of pendēre "to hang" + Middle French -if, noun derivative of -if

definition: a supreme chief or leader in ancient Britain.
sentence: In the legends of King Arthur, a pendragon was a title used for a supreme leader or king.

definition: poised without visible support
sentence: The willow tree has pendulous branches that hang down and sway in the wind.
origin: borrowed from Latin pendulus, from pendēre "to hang" + -ulus, adjective suffix denoting repeated or prolonged action

definition: an officer in some Roman Catholic dioceses vested with power from the bishop to deal with cases of a nature normally handled only by the bishop
sentence: The thief was sent to a penitentiary, which is another word for a large prison.
origin: Middle English penitenciary, from Medieval Latin poenitentiarius, from poenitentia

definition: next to the last
sentence: Friday is the penultimate day of the school week, since Saturday is the last.
origin: see

definition: the edible seed of a pumpkin or squash often dried or toasted
sentence: A pepita is a pumpkin seed that has been roasted and is a very healthy snack.
origin: Spanish

definition: by, of, or in itself or oneself or themselves : as such : intrinsically
sentence: The movie wasn't bad per se, but it was much too long for me to enjoy.
origin: Latin

definition: doubt
sentence: By peradventure, I found my lost ring hiding under the couch while I was looking for my toy.

definition: capable of being perceived especially by the senses
sentence: There was a perceptible change in the air when the sun went behind a cloud and it got colder.

definition: a revolving triangular prism used for changing scenery in ancient Greek theater.
sentence: In ancient theaters, a periaktos was a spinning three-sided pillar used to quickly change the scenery.

definition: borne on a ring or cup of the receptacle surrounding a pistil; also : having perigynous stamens and petals
sentence: A flower is perigynous when its petals and stamens are attached around the middle of the ovary.
origin: borrowed from New Latin perigynus, from peri-  + -gynus

definition: a branch of dentistry that deals with diseases of the supporting and investing structures of the teeth including the gums, cementum, periodontal membranes, and alveolar bone
sentence: My mom went to the periodontist to make sure her gums were healthy and strong.
origin: New Latin periodontium periodontal tissue, from peri- + Greek odont-, odous, odōn tooth

definition: of, relating to, involving, or forming a periphery or surface part
sentence: Out of my peripheral vision, I saw the cat jump onto the counter even though I wasn't looking right at her.

definition: any of several trailing or woody evergreen herbs of the dogbane family: such as
sentence: My favorite crayon is the one that is a light purple-blue color called periwinkle.
origin: Middle English perwinke, from Old English perwince, from Vulgar Latin *pervinca, short for Latin vincapervinca

definition: often major or fundamental change (as in character or condition) based primarily on rearrangement of existent elements; also : a form or variety resulting from such change
sentence: In math, we learned that a permutation is a specific way of ordering a set of objects.
origin: Middle English permutacioun exchange, transformation, from Anglo-French, from Latin permutation-, permutatio, from permutare

definition: highly damaging or destructive often in a way that is not easily seen or noticed
sentence: Spreading lies about people can have a pernicious effect on their friendships.
origin: Middle English, from Anglo-French, from Latin perniciosus, from pernicies destruction, from per- + nec-, nex violent death

definition: to bring about or carry out (something, such as a crime or deception) : commit
sentence: The police used the security camera to find the perpetrator who broke the shop window.
origin: Latin perpetratus, past participle of perpetrare, from per- through + patrare to accomplish, from pater father

definition: a privilege, gain, or profit incidental to regular salary or wages; especially : one expected or promised
sentence: A perquisite of working at the ice cream shop is getting a free scoop every single day.
origin: Middle English, property acquired by means other than inheritance, from Anglo-French perquisit, Medieval Latin perquisitum, from neuter of perquisitus, past participle of perquirere to purchase, acquire, from Latin, to search for thoroughly, from per- thoroughly + quaerere to seek

definition: continued effort to do or achieve something despite difficulties, failure, or opposition : the action or condition or an instance of persevering : steadfastness
sentence: It took a lot of perseverance for the girl to keep practicing her scales until she got them right.
origin: Middle English perseveraunce, borrowed from Anglo-French parseverance, parsevrance, borrowed from Latin persevērantia, noun derivative of persevērant-, persevērans "persisting in a course of action, steadfast," from present participle of persevērāre "to persist in a course of action or an attitude in spite of opposition, keep on"

definition: of acute mental vision or discernment : keen
sentence: The perspicacious detective noticed a tiny clue that everyone else had missed.
origin: Latin perspicac-, perspicax, from perspicere

definition: persuadable
sentence: My little brother is very persuasible and will do whatever I tell him if I offer him a cookie.
origin: Middle English, plausible, from Middle French, from Latin persuasibilis persuasive, from persuasus, past participle of persuadēre

definition: adhering resolutely to an opinion, purpose, or design
sentence: The puppy's pertinacity was shown when he spent an hour trying to get the treat out from under the chair.
origin: Latin pertinac-, pertinax, from per- thoroughly + tenac-, tenax tenacious, from tenēre

definition: of, relating to, or resembling whooping cough.
sentence: The doctor listened to the boy's pertussal cough to see if he had whooping cough.

definition: a grayish-blue color, like that of a periwinkle flower.
sentence: The artist used a beautiful shade of pervenche blue to paint the sky in his picture.

definition: a contagious or infectious epidemic disease that is virulent and devastating; especially : bubonic plague
sentence: In history, a pestilence was a very serious disease that spread through the whole town.

definition: an oily flammable bituminous liquid that may vary from almost colorless to black, occurs in many places in the upper strata of the earth, is a complex mixture of hydrocarbons with small amounts of other substances, and is prepared for use as gasoline, naphtha, or other products by various refining processes
sentence: Gasoline is made from petroleum, which is a liquid found deep underground.
origin: Middle English, "mineral oil," borrowed from Medieval Latin, "mineral oil, crude oil," from Latin petra "rock" (borrowed from Greek pétra) + oleum "oil" ,

definition: an exhibition of optical effects and illusions
sentence: The carnival at night was a phantasmagoria of bright lights, loud music, and colorful costumes.
origin: borrowed from French phantasmogorie (later fantasmagorie) "theatrical show using magic lanterns in a darkened performance space to suggest supernatural phenomena," from fantasme  + -ogorie, -agorie, of uncertain origin

definition: the observable characteristics or traits of an organism that are produced by the interaction of the genotype and the environment : the physical expression of one or more genes
sentence: Your phenotype includes things you can see, like your eye color and the shape of your nose.
origin: German Phänotypus, from Greek phainein to show + typos type

definition: to reason in the manner of a philosopher
sentence: My grandpa likes to philosophize about the best way to live a happy and kind life.

definition: the vertical groove between the base of the nose and the border of the upper lip.
sentence: The philtrum is the small vertical groove that is located right between your nose and your upper lip.

definition: the practice of tricking Internet users (as through the use of deceptive email messages or websites) into revealing personal or confidential information which can then be used illicitly
sentence: You should never click on strange links because it might be a phishing scam to steal your information.
origin: respelling of , with ph- probably after

definition: the drawing of blood (as by venipuncture) for transfusion, apheresis, diagnostic testing, or experimental procedures —called also venesection
sentence: Phlebotomy is the job of a person who is trained to take blood from patients at the hospital.
origin: Middle English fleobotomie, from Middle French flebothomie, from Late Latin phlebotomia, from Greek, from phleb- + -tomia -tomy

definition: a legendary bird which according to one account lived 500 years, burned itself to ashes on a pyre, and rose alive from the ashes to live another period; also : a person or thing likened to the phoenix
sentence: In the legend, the phoenix is a magical bird that burns up and is born again from its own ashes.
origin: Middle English fenix, from Old English, from Latin phoenix, from Greek phoinix

definition: a specialist in phonetics
sentence: A phonetician is a scientist who studies exactly how people make the sounds of speech.

definition: exhibiting phosphorescence
sentence: I have phosphorescent stars on my ceiling that glow in the dark after I turn off the light.

definition: a manner of organizing words and phrases into longer elements : style
sentence: The phraseology used by doctors can be very hard for normal people to understand.
origin: New Latin phraseologia, irregular from Greek phrasis + -logia -logy

definition: the study or science of algae —called also algology
sentence: If you are interested in seaweed and algae, you might want to study phycology when you grow up.

definition: a direct line of descent within a group
sentence: In science, a phylum is a large group used to classify animals, like the group for all animals with backbones.
origin: New Latin, from Greek phylon tribe, race

definition: an identifiable plant fragment in coal.
sentence: The scientist studied the phyteral remains of the ancient plant to see what it looked like.

definition: a young or small pike
sentence: A pickerel is a type of freshwater fish that has a long body and very sharp teeth.
origin: Middle English pikerel, diminutive of pike

definition: city and capital of South Dakota on the Missouri River in the central part of the state population 13,646
sentence: Pierre is the capital city of the state of South Dakota.

definition: an upright architectural member that is rectangular in plan and is structurally a pier but architecturally treated as a column and that usually projects a third of its width or less from the wall
sentence: A pilaster is a flat column that is built into the surface of a wall to make it look fancy.
origin: Middle French pilastre, from Italian pilastro

definition: a pointed or close-fitting cap worn by ancient Romans
sentence: The pileus is the name for the cap of a mushroom that sits on top of the stem.
origin: borrowed from Latin pilleus, pīleus, pilleum, pīleum "felt cap," of uncertain origin

definition: steal; especially : to steal stealthily in small amounts and often again and again
sentence: The sneaky crow was a bit of a pilferer, always stealing shiny objects from people's yards.
origin: Middle French pelfrer, from pelfre booty

definition: covered with usually soft hair
sentence: The bear's thick pilosity, or hairiness, helps keep it warm even in the middle of a snowy winter.
origin: Latin pilosus, from pilus hair

definition: the action or business of piloting
sentence: The captain used his knowledge of pilotage to steer the large ship safely through the narrow harbor.

definition: an upright architectural member generally ending in a small spire and used especially in Gothic construction to give weight especially to a buttress
sentence: After a long climb, the hikers finally reached the pinnacle of the mountain and looked at the clouds.
origin: Middle English pinacle, from Anglo-French, from Late Latin pinnaculum small wing, gable, from Latin pinna wing, battlement

definition: resembling a feather especially in having similar parts arranged on opposite sides of an axis like the barbs on the rachis of a feather
sentence: The leaf was pinnate, with small leaflets growing on both sides of the stem like a feather.
origin: New Latin pinnatus, from Latin, feathered, from pinna feather, wing, fin

definition: marked by or showing reverence for deity and devotion to divine worship
sentence: The pious man visited the temple every morning to say his prayers and help the community.
origin: Middle English, from Latin pius

definition: a zodiacal constellation directly south of Andromeda
sentence: My birthday is in early March, so my zodiac sign is Pisces, which is shown as two fish.
origin: Middle English, from Latin (genitive Piscium), from plural of piscis fish

definition: of or relating to the pituitary gland
sentence: The pituitary gland is a tiny part of the brain that tells your body when it is time to grow taller.
origin: Latin pituita phlegm; from the former belief that the pituitary gland secreted phlegm

definition: any of a class (Placodermi) of extinct chiefly Devonian fishes with an armor of bony plates and primitive jaw structures
sentence: A placoderm was a prehistoric fish that had hard, bony plates on its head like a suit of armor.
origin: New Latin Placodermi, ultimately from Greek plak-, plax + derma skin

definition: an act or instance of plagiarizing
sentence: The teacher explained that plagiarism is wrong because you should always use your own words for your essay.

definition: a person who brings a legal action
sentence: In the courtroom, the plaintiff explained to the judge why he thought the neighbor should fix the fence.
origin: Middle English plaintif, from Anglo-French, from pleintif, adjective

definition: any of numerous small celestial bodies that may have existed at an early stage of the development of the solar system
sentence: Scientists believe the planets were formed when many tiny planetesimal rocks crashed into each other.
origin: planet + -esimal (as in infinitesimal)

definition: the quality or state of being plangent
sentence: The plangency of the sad violin music made everyone in the audience feel very quiet.

definition: a representation of the circles of the sphere on a plane; especially : a polar projection of the celestial sphere and the stars on a plane with adjustable circles or other appendages for showing celestial phenomena for any given time
sentence: I used a planisphere to help me find the constellations in the night sky during our camping trip.
origin: alteration of Middle English planisperie, from Medieval Latin planisphaerium, from Latin planum plane + sphaera sphere

definition: a schematic drawing or plan for displaying merchandise in a store so as to maximize sales
sentence: The store manager used a planogram to decide exactly which shelf the cereal boxes should go on.
origin: plan- (taken as combining form of ) + -gram

definition: any of a genus (Plantago of the family Plantaginaceae, the plantain family) of herbs with basal rosettes of usually lanceolate or elliptical leaves and spikes of minute greenish flowers
sentence: A plantain looks like a green banana, but it is usually cooked before you eat it.
origin: Middle English, from Anglo-French, from Latin plantagin-, plantago, from planta sole of the foot; from its broad leaves

definition: walking on the sole with the heel touching the ground
sentence: Bears are plantigrade animals because they walk with their entire foot touching the ground, just like humans.
origin: French, from Latin planta sole + French -grade

definition: an act or round of applause
sentence: The young actor received many plaudits and cheers from the crowd after the play was over.
origin: Latin plaudite applaud, plural imperative of plaudere to applaud

definition: the quality or state of being full : completeness
sentence: After the harvest, the farmers had a plenitude of apples to share with the whole town.
origin: Middle English, borrowed from Anglo-French & Latin; Anglo-French, borrowed from Latin plēnitūdō, from plēnus "full" + -i-  + -tūdō

definition: containing or yielding plenty
sentence: There were plentiful snacks at the party, so everyone got to have their favorite treat.
origin: Middle English plentiful, plentefull, from plente  + -ful, -full

definition: any of a genus (Plumbago of the family Plumbaginaceae, the plumbago family) of chiefly tropical herbs and shrubs with alternate leaves and spikes of showy flowers
sentence: The garden was decorated with plumbago bushes that had beautiful clusters of light blue flowers.
origin: Latin plumbagin-, plumbago galena, from plumbum

definition: frangipani
sentence: The Plumeria flower smells very sweet and is often used to make colorful leis in Hawaii.
origin: New Latin, genus name, from Charles Plumier †1704 French botanist

definition: the study or management of wealth; also an economy controlled by the wealthy.
sentence: In a plutonomy, a small group of very wealthy people controls most of the money in the country.

definition: a large usually mild heart-shaped chili pepper especially when fresh and dark green
sentence: My mom made stuffed peppers using a poblano, which is a mild green chili pepper.
origin: Mexican Spanish (chile) poblano, literally, chili pepper of Puebla (Mexico)

definition: any of various rather heavy-bodied diving ducks (especially genus Aythya) with a large head and with feet and legs placed far back under the body
sentence: The pochard is a type of diving duck with a reddish-brown head that swims in the lake.
origin: origin unknown

definition: indifferent, nonchalant
sentence: The boy acted in a pococurante way, pretending he didn't care about the broken toy even though he was sad.
origin: Italian poco curante caring little

definition: an attitude of complacent ignorance or refusal to acknowledge anything unpleasant.
sentence: The man's podsnappery made him ignore any problems in the world that didn't affect him personally.

definition: a small, unimportant, and isolated town
sentence: In the movie, the character lived in a tiny Podunk town where there was only one stoplight.
origin: Podunk, village in Massachusetts or locality in Connecticut

definition: any of several spurges (genus Euphorbia) with flower clusters subtended by showy involucral bracts; especially : a showy Mexican and Central American plant (E. pulcherrima) with tapering usually scarlet bracts that suggest petals and surround small yellow flowers
sentence: We put a bright red poinsettia plant on the table to decorate the house for the holidays.
origin: New Latin, from Joel R. Poinsett †1851 American diplomat

definition: an openwork design (as in knitted fabric) typically in the shape of chevrons; also : a fabric with this design
sentence: My new sweater has a pretty pointelle pattern with tiny little holes that look like lace.
origin: perhaps from  + -elle (as in dentelle lace)

definition: a technique of using dots or small strokes of color in painting or engraving.
sentence: The artist used pointillage to create a whole picture out of thousands of tiny colored dots.

definition: to engage in often partisan political discussion or activity
sentence: The students began to politick by handing out stickers to get their friends to vote for them for class president.
origin: back-formation from politicking, noun, from or +

definition: something that pollutes; especially : something (such as waste created by human activity) that makes an environment unsuitable or unsafe for use
sentence: Smoke from the factory can be a pollutant that makes the air dirty for the people living nearby.

definition: an elaborate short-sleeved overdress with a fitted waist and a draped cutaway overskirt
sentence: The dancers performed a polonaise, a slow and grand dance that started in Poland.
origin: French, from feminine of polonais Polish, from Pologne Poland, from Medieval Latin Polonia

definition: a radioactive metallic element that has similar chemical properties to tellurium and bismuth, is produced mainly from the radioactive decay of neutron-irradiated bismuth, and emits an alpha particle to form an isotope of lead
sentence: Polonium is a very rare and radioactive metal that was discovered by the scientist Marie Curie.
origin: New Latin, from Medieval Latin Polonia

definition: any of a group of polymers that consist basically of repeated units of an ester and are used especially in making fibers or plastics; also : a product (such as a fiber or fabric) composed of polyester
sentence: My sports jersey is made of polyester because the fabric dries very quickly when I sweat.

definition: consisting of many kinds; having multiple origins.
sentence: The scientist explained that the forest was polygenous because it was made of many different types of trees.

definition: a molecular chain of amino acids
sentence: A polypeptide is a long chain of molecules that join together to help build a protein.
origin: International Scientific Vocabulary

definition: having multiple meanings
sentence: The word 'bank' is an example of polysemy because it can mean a place for money or the side of a river.
origin: Late Latin polysemus, from Greek polysēmos, from poly- + sēma sign

definition: having more than one and usually more than three syllables
sentence: A polysyllabic word is a long word, like 'hippopotamus,' that has more than three syllables.
origin: Medieval Latin polysyllabus, from Greek polysyllabos, from poly- + syllabē syllable

definition: a hybrid plant produced by grafting a tomato scion onto a potato stock.
sentence: A pomato is a strange plant that grows tomatoes on the top and potatoes on the roots.

definition: a several-celled reddish berry that is about the size of an orange with a thick leathery skin and many seeds with pulpy crimson arils of tart flavor
sentence: A pomegranate is a round fruit filled with hundreds of juicy, tart red seeds.
origin: Middle English poumgrenet, from Anglo-French pome garnette, literally, seedy fruit

definition: any of a breed of long-haired compact toy dogs with a soft dense undercoat
sentence: Our neighbor has a tiny Pomeranian dog that looks like a little ball of orange fluff.

definition: the science and practice of growing fruit
sentence: If you are interested in how apples and pears grow, you might want to study pomology.
origin: New Latin pomologia, from Latin pomum fruit + -logia -logy

definition: pompous demeanor, speech, or behavior
sentence: The king's pomposity made him act like he was much more important than everyone else.

definition: a thin soft fabric of Chinese origin woven from raw silk; also : an imitation of this fabric in cotton or a synthetic fiber (as of polyester or rayon)
sentence: The soft scarf was made of pongee, which is a type of silk fabric with a bit of a rough texture.
origin: Chinese (Beijing) běnjī, from běn own + jī loom

definition: pontifex
sentence: The word 'pontiff' is another name for a high-ranking religious leader, like the Pope.
origin: French pontif, from Latin pontific-, pontifex

definition: the common people : masses
sentence: The entire populace of the small town gathered in the square to hear the mayor's announcement.
origin: borrowed from Middle French, "mob, rabble," borrowed from Italian popolazzo, popolaccio "the common people, the masses, rabble, mob," from popolo  + -azzo, -accio, augmentative and pejorative suffix, going back to Latin -āceus

definition: a hard, fine-grained, sonorous, nonporous, and usually translucent and white ceramic ware that consists essentially of kaolin, quartz, and a feldspathic rock and is fired at a high temperature —called also hard-paste porcelain, true porcelain
sentence: Grandma keeps her delicate porcelain teacups on a high shelf so they don't get broken.
origin: Middle French porcelaine cowrie shell, porcelain, from Italian porcellana, from porcello vulva, literally, little pig, from Latin porcellus, diminutive of porcus pig, vulva; from the shape of the shell

definition: the quality or state of being porous
sentence: The porosity of the sponge allows it to soak up a lot of water very quickly.

definition: a colonnade or covered ambulatory especially in classical architecture and often at the entrance of a building
sentence: We stood under the portico of the museum to stay dry while we waited for the doors to open.
origin: Italian, from Latin porticus

definition: an inn in Spanish-speaking countries
sentence: In Mexico, people celebrate a posada by walking together and singing carols before a big party.
origin: Spanish, from posar to lodge, from Late Latin pausare

definition: a large group often with a common interest
sentence: The sheriff gathered a posse of volunteers to help search for the lost hikers.
origin: Medieval Latin posse comitatus, literally, power or authority of the county

definition: of, relating to, or constituting a word, a word group, or a grammatical case that denotes ownership or a relation analogous to ownership
sentence: To show something belongs to you, you use a possessive word like 'my' or 'mine.'

definition: the offspring of one progenitor to the furthest generation
sentence: The museum keeps old letters so that posterity can learn about how people lived long ago.
origin: Middle English posterite, from Anglo-French pusterité, from Latin posteritat-, posteritas, from posterus coming after

definition: born after the death of the father
sentence: The artist became very famous after his death, receiving a posthumous award for his paintings.
origin: Latin posthumus, alteration of postumus late-born, posthumous, from superlative of posterus coming after

definition: of, relating to, or involving posture; also : orthostatic
sentence: Sitting up straight in your chair is a good postural habit that helps your back stay healthy.

definition: a silver-white soft light low-melting monovalent metallic element of the alkali metal group that occurs abundantly in nature especially combined in minerals
sentence: Eating a banana is a good way to get potassium, which is a mineral that helps your muscles work.
origin: New Latin, from potassa potash, from English potash

definition: ruler, sovereign; broadly : one who wields great power or sway
sentence: In the fairy tale, the powerful potentate ruled over a kingdom filled with magic and treasure.

definition: a small, nocturnal, kangaroo-like marsupial of Australia.
sentence: The potoroo is a small, hopping animal from Australia that looks a bit like a tiny kangaroo.

definition: a soft usually heated and sometimes medicated mass spread on cloth and applied to sores or other lesions
sentence: Grandpa made a warm poultice out of herbs to put on his sore knee to help it feel better.
origin: Middle English pultes, from Medieval Latin, literally, pap, from Latin, plural of pult-, puls porridge

definition: adapted for seizing or grasping especially by wrapping around
sentence: Some monkeys have a prehensile tail that they can use like an extra hand to grab branches.
origin: French préhensile, from Latin prehensus, past participle of prehendere to seize

definition: characteristic of or belonging to the time or state before the fall of humankind
sentence: The story was about a prelapsarian world where everyone was perfectly happy and lived in peace.
origin: pre- + Latin lapsus slip, fall

definition: a superiority in weight, power, importance, or strength
sentence: There was a preponderance of red jellybeans in the jar, so it was easy to find my favorite color.

definition: contrary to nature, reason, or common sense : absurd
sentence: The idea that a cat could fly an airplane is completely preposterous!
origin: Latin praeposterus, literally, in the wrong order, from prae- + posterus hinder, following

definition: of, relating to, or suitable for the time just before dinner
sentence: We had a quick preprandial snack of crackers and cheese before the big family dinner started.

definition: something that is necessary to an end or to the carrying out of a function
sentence: Learning to crawl is a prerequisite for learning how to walk.

definition: a right or privilege; especially : an exclusive or special right, power, or privilege: such as
sentence: Since it was her birthday, it was her prerogative to choose which movie we would watch.
origin: Middle English prerogatif, prerogative, borrowed from Anglo-French, borrowed from Latin praerogātīva "the century (Roman voting unit) on which the lot fell to vote first, the verdict of that century (seen as predicting the outcome of the whole vote), omen, prior choice, prior right or claim," (short for centuria praerogātīva "century voting first"), from feminine of praerogātīvus "appointed by lot to vote first," from prae-  + rogātus, past participle of rogāre "to ask, ask (an assembly for a decision)" + -īvus

definition: having a presentiment
sentence: The dog was presentient, acting nervous and hiding just before the big storm began.
origin: Latin praesentient-, praesentiens, present participle of praesentire

definition: located in front of a spine or the spinal column.
sentence: The doctor checked the prespinous area of the patient's back, which is the part just in front of the spine.

definition: the quality or state of being prevalent
sentence: The prevalence of smartphones means that you can see people using them almost everywhere you go.

definition: antecedent, anticipatory
sentence: The prevenient rules were put in place to keep the students safe before any accidents could happen.
origin: Latin praevenient-, praeveniens, present participle of praevenire

definition: a principal female singer in an opera or concert organization
sentence: The lead singer acted like a prima donna, insisting that everything be exactly her way.
origin: Italian, literally, first lady

definition: of or relating to the earliest ages (as of the world or human history) : ancient, primitive
sentence: The explorers walked through a primeval forest that looked like it hadn't changed since the time of dinosaurs.
origin: primeve, in same sense, or its source, Late Latin prīmaevus "earliest, original, principal" (going back to Latin, "young, youthful," from prīmus "first, foremost, earliest" + -aevus, adjective derivative of aevum "age, lifetime") +  ,

definition: the state of being the firstborn of the children of the same parents
sentence: In the old kingdom, the law of primogeniture meant that the oldest child became the next king.
origin: borrowed from Middle French & Late Latin; Middle French, borrowed from Late Latin prīmogenitūra, from prīmogenitus "firstborn" (from Latin prīmus "first, earliest" + -o-  —for expected -i-  — + genitus, past participle of gignere "to bring into being, beget, give birth to") + Latin -ūra  ,

definition: the first printed edition especially of a work that circulated in manuscript before printing became common
sentence: The word 'princeps' was a title used by the first emperors of Rome to mean 'first citizen.'
origin: New Latin, literally, first edition

definition: a religious house under a prior or prioress
sentence: A priory is a quiet place where a group of monks or nuns live and work together.
origin: Middle English priorie, from Anglo-French, from Medieval Latin prioria, from prior

definition: in private; privately.
sentence: The two friends spoke privatim so that no one else in the room could hear their secret.

definition: a Eurasian deciduous shrub (Ligustrum vulgare) of the olive family with semievergreen leaves and small white flowers that is widely used for hedges; broadly : any of various shrubs of the same genus
sentence: The gardener trimmed the privet hedge to keep it looking neat and tidy around the yard.
origin: origin unknown

definition: serving to test or try : exploratory
sentence: The muddy footprints provided probative evidence that someone had walked through the garden.

definition: of, relating to, or typical of Procrustes
sentence: The school had a procrustean rule that every student had to wear exactly the same color socks.

definition: the act or process of procuring; especially : the obtaining of military supplies by a government
sentence: The procurement of all the supplies for the science fair took several weeks of planning.

definition: causing amazement or wonder
sentence: The giant had a prodigious appetite and could eat a whole loaf of bread in just one bite.
origin: see

definition: preliminary comment : preface
sentence: The author wrote a short proem at the beginning of the book to introduce the main characters.
origin: Middle English proheme, from Anglo-French proeme, from Latin prooemium, from Greek prooimion, from pro- + oimē song; probably akin to Hittite išamai- song, Sanskrit syati he binds

definition: the quality or state of being profligate
sentence: The king's profligacy led him to spend all the kingdom's money on giant statues of himself.

definition: intellectual depth
sentence: The profundity of the ocean is amazing, as some parts are miles and miles deep.
origin: Middle English profundite, from Latin profunditat-, profunditas depth, from profundus

definition: a member of the proletariat
sentence: A proletarian worker is someone who works hard in a factory or on a farm to earn a living.
origin: Latin proletarius, from proles progeny, from pro- forth + -oles (akin to alere to nourish)

definition: to grow by rapid production of new parts, cells, buds, or offspring
sentence: Rabbits can proliferate very quickly, which is why there are so many of them in the field.
origin: back-formation from proliferation, from French prolifération, from proliférer to proliferate, from prolifère reproducing freely, from Latin proles + -fer -ferous

definition: unduly prolonged or drawn out : too long
sentence: The speech was so prolix and long that some of the people in the audience started to fall asleep.
origin: Middle English, from Anglo-French & Latin; Anglo-French prolix, from Latin prolixus extended, from pro- forward + liquēre to be fluid

definition: a preliminary trial or exercise : prelude
sentence: Before the main race started, the runners did some prolusory stretches to warm up their muscles.
origin: Latin prolusion-, prolusio, from proludere to play beforehand, from pro- before + ludere to play

definition: a high point of land or rock projecting into a body of water
sentence: We stood on a promontory of rock that stuck out over the ocean to watch the sunset.
origin: Latin promunturium, promonturium; probably akin to prominēre to jut forth

definition: of, relating to, or characteristic of an owner or title holder
sentence: The company has a proprietary recipe for their cookies, so no one else knows the secret ingredients.
origin: Middle English proprietarye "possessing worldly goods beyond one's needs," borrowed from Medieval Latin propriētārius, going back to Late Latin, "of an owner or proprietor," adjective derivative of propriētārius "owner"

definition: of, relating to, or being stimuli arising within the organism
sentence: Your proprioceptive sense helps you know where your arms and legs are even when your eyes are closed.
origin: Latin proprius "one's own" +  + English -ceptive (in )

definition: defer, postpone
sentence: The leaders decided to prorogue the meeting and continue their discussion next month.
origin: Middle English prorogen, from Anglo-French proroger, from Latin prorogare, from pro- before + rogare to ask ,

definition: the study of versification; especially : the systematic study of metrical structure
sentence: In English class, we studied prosody to learn about the rhythm and sounds used in poetry.
origin: Middle English, from Latin prosodia accent of a syllable, from Greek prosōidia song sung to instrumental music, accent, from pros in addition to + ōidē song ,

definition: of or resembling Proteus in having a varied nature or ability to assume different forms
sentence: The actor was very protean, able to change his voice and look to play many different characters.

definition: government by a protector
sentence: The small island was a protectorate, meaning it was protected by a larger and stronger country.

definition: thrusting out from a surrounding or adjacent surface often as a rounded mass : prominent
sentence: The frog had large, protuberant eyes that stuck out from the top of its head.
origin: Late Latin protuberant-, protuberans, present participle of protuberare to bulge out, from Latin pro- forward + tuber excrescence, swelling; perhaps akin to Latin tumēre to swell

definition: origin, source
sentence: The museum checked the provenance of the painting to make sure it was a real antique.
origin: French, from provenir to come forth, originate, from Latin provenire, from pro- forth + venire to come ,

definition: provisions or food supplies, especially for an army.
sentence: The explorers packed plenty of proviant, like dried meat and fruit, for their long journey.

definition: the superior of a province of a Roman Catholic religious order
sentence: The girl lived in a provincial town that was far away from the busy streets of the big city.
origin: in sense 1, from Middle English, from Anglo-French or Medieval Latin; Anglo-French, from Medieval Latin provincialis, from provincia ecclesiastical province; in other senses, from Latin provincialis, from provincia province

definition: an article or clause (as in a contract) that introduces a condition
sentence: My dad said I could go to the park with the proviso that I finish all my homework first.
origin: Middle English, from Medieval Latin proviso quod provided that

definition: a Latin American stew made of meat and various vegetables.
sentence: Puchero is a delicious stew made with meat and vegetables that is popular in South America.

definition: a village of Indigenous peoples of the southwestern U.S.
sentence: While traveling in the Southwest, we saw an ancient pueblo made of stone and clay.
origin: Spanish, village, literally, people, from Latin populus

definition: fighter; especially : a professional boxer
sentence: A pugilist is a person who is trained in the sport of boxing.

definition: having a quarrelsome or combative nature : truculent
sentence: The pugnacious little puppy was always trying to start a play-fight with the big dogs.
origin: Latin pugnac-, pugnax, from pugnare to fight

definition: physical comeliness
sentence: The pulchritude of the garden was amazing, with colorful flowers blooming in every corner.
origin: Middle English, from Latin pulchritudin-, pulchritudo, from pulchr-, pulcher beautiful

definition: a one-person sled used in Lapland, typically drawn by a reindeer.
sentence: In the snowy north, travelers use a pulka, which is a small sled pulled by a person or a reindeer.

definition: a violent, cold snowstorm or blizzard of the Siberian tundras.
sentence: A purga is a very strong and cold snowstorm that happens on the flat plains of Russia.

definition: to supply (something, such as provisions) usually as a matter of business
sentence: The local farm helps to purvey fresh vegetables to all the grocery stores in our town.
origin: Middle English purveien, from Anglo-French purveier, purveer to look at, foresee, provide, from Latin providēre to provide

definition: a common mineral that consists of iron disulfide, has a pale brass-yellow color and metallic luster, and is burned in making sulfur dioxide and sulfuric acid
sentence: Pyrite is a shiny yellow mineral that looks so much like gold that people call it 'fool's gold.'
origin: Latin pyrites

definition: a magnesium-aluminum garnet that is deep red in color and is frequently used as a gem
sentence: A pyrope is a beautiful, deep red gemstone that is a type of garnet.
origin: Middle English pirope, a red gem, from Middle French, from Latin pyropus, a red bronze, from Greek pyrōpos, literally, fiery-eyed, from pyr- + ōp-, ōps eye

definition: the art of making or the manufacture and use of fireworks
sentence: The Fourth of July celebration featured amazing pyrotechnics that lit up the whole night sky.

definition: the greater extensor muscle of the front of the thigh that is divided into four parts
sentence: Your quadriceps are the large muscles on the front of your thighs that help you kick a ball.
origin: New Latin quadricipit-, quadriceps, from quadri- + -cipit-, -ceps (as in bicipit-, biceps biceps)

definition: a polygon of four sides
sentence: A square is a type of quadrilateral because it is a shape that has exactly four sides.
origin: Latin quadrilaterus four-sided, from quadri- + later-, latus side

definition: a number equal to 1 followed by 15 zeros; also, British : a number equal to 1 followed by 24 zeros
sentence: A quadrillion is a giant number that is equal to one thousand trillion!
origin: French, from Middle French, from quadri- + -illion (as in million)

definition: a feeling of uneasiness about a point especially of conscience or propriety
sentence: I had some qualms about climbing the tall ladder because I am a little bit afraid of heights.
origin: origin unknown

definition: apt or disposed to quarrel in an often petty manner : contentious
sentence: The quarrelsome brothers were always arguing over whose turn it was to play the video game.

definition: a person who asks a question, especially one seeking a horoscope or supernatural insight.
sentence: In the story, the querent visited the wise woman to ask a question about his future.

definition: a tortilla filled with cheese and often a savory mixture (as of meat and vegetables), folded, and usually fried
sentence: For a snack, I made a cheesy quesadilla by melting cheese between two warm tortillas.
origin: Mexican Spanish, from Spanish, cheese pastry, diminutive of quesada, from queso cheese, from Latin caseus

definition: a set of questions for obtaining statistically useful or personal information from individuals
sentence: The teacher gave us a questionnaire to find out which books we enjoyed reading the most.
origin: French, from questionner to question, from Middle French, from question, noun

definition: something given or received for something else; also : a deal arranging a quid pro quo
sentence: The two friends had a quid pro quo: if Leo helped with math, Sarah would help with science.
origin: New Latin, something for something

definition: whatever makes something the type that it is : essence
sentence: The quiddity of a lemon is its sour taste; that is what makes it a lemon!
origin: Middle English quidite, from Medieval Latin quidditat-, quidditas essence, from Latin quid what, neuter of quis who

definition: consisting of five; based on the number five.
sentence: A quinary system is a way of counting that is based on the number five.

definition: the fruit of a central Asian tree (Cydonia oblonga) of the rose family that resembles a hard-fleshed yellow apple and is used especially in preserves
sentence: A quince is a yellow fruit that looks like a pear but is usually used to make sweet jam.
origin: Middle English quynce quinces, plural of coyn, quyn quince, from Anglo-French coign, from Latin cotoneum, alteration cydonium, from Greek kydōnion

definition: a riding whip with a short handle and a rawhide lash
sentence: A quirt is a short whip that riders sometimes use to encourage their horses to go faster.
origin: Mexican Spanish cuarta

definition: discharge from a debt or an obligation
sentence: The man received a quittance, which was a paper showing that he had paid back all the money he owed.

definition: foolishly impractical especially in the pursuit of ideals; especially : marked by rash lofty romantic ideas or extravagantly chivalrous action doomed to fail
sentence: Trying to build a castle out of sand right before the tide came in was a quixotic idea.
origin: Don Quixote

definition: occurring every day
sentence: Brushing your teeth is a quotidian task, meaning it is something you do every single day.
origin: Middle English cotidian, from Anglo-French, from Latin quotidianus, cotidianus, from quotidie every day, from quot (as) many as + dies day

definition: a standard layout for English-language typewriters and computer keyboards in which the first six letters of the second row are q, w, e, r, t, and y —often used before another noun
sentence: Most computer keyboards use the QWERTY layout, named after the first six letters on the top row.
origin: from the first six letters in the second row of the keyboard

definition: a wide, wired-frame collar used to support a ruff or lace collar.
sentence: In old paintings, we saw people wearing a rabato, which is a wide, stiff collar around their neck.

definition: of or relating to rabbis or their writings
sentence: The students studied rabbinic writings to learn about the history and laws of their culture.

definition: a fixed radar beacon used as a navigational aid to show a steady line of bearing.
sentence: A ramark is a type of radio beacon that helps ships find their way when it is foggy.

definition: a dry ravine that serves as a watercourse during heavy rain; also a wide boulevard.
sentence: In Spain, a rambla is a wide street with trees and shops where people like to walk and talk.

definition: marked by uncontrollable exuberance : unruly
sentence: The rambunctious puppies were jumping and barking all over the living room.
origin: probably alteration of rumbustious

definition: a wild garlic plant with broad leaves and white flowers.
sentence: A ramson is a type of wild garlic that has white flowers and smells very strong in the woods.

definition: to cause anger, irritation, or deep bitterness
sentence: It still rankles me that I lost my favorite pen at school last week.
origin: Middle English ranclen to fester, from Anglo-French rancler, from Old French draoncler, raoncler, from draoncle, raoncle festering sore, from Medieval Latin dracunculus, from Latin, diminutive of draco serpent

definition: a person who causes trouble : rascal, ne'er-do-well
sentence: The story was about a mischievous rapscallion who liked to play pranks on the villagers.
origin: alteration of earlier rascallion, irregular from rascal

definition: adapted for seizing or snatching prey, like the talons of a hawk.
sentence: An eagle has raptatorial claws that are perfectly designed for catching and holding onto its prey.

definition: an expression or manifestation of ecstasy or passion
sentence: The crowd gave a rapturous cheer when the home team scored the winning goal.
origin: + ; (sense 3) probably after the use of rapere in the Vulgate (1 Thessalonians 4:17) to translate Greek harpázein "to take hold of, seize, snatch up"

definition: rare items or unusual collector's objects.
sentence: The museum's collection of rariora included very rare books that were hundreds of years old.

definition: scratching the ground for food, as do chickens and other gallinaceous birds.
sentence: Chickens are rasorial birds because they spend a lot of time scratching the ground to find seeds.

definition: disagreeably harsh or strident : hoarse
sentence: The party became very raucous as everyone started singing and laughing loudly.
origin: Latin raucus hoarse; akin to Latin ravis hoarseness

definition: pasta in the form of little cases of dough containing a savory filling (as of meat or cheese)
sentence: For dinner, we had ravioli, which are square pasta pockets filled with delicious cheese.
origin: Italian, from Italian dialect, plural of raviolo, literally, little turnip, diminutive of rava turnip, from Latin rapa

definition: a substance used (as in detecting or measuring a component, in preparing a product, or in developing photographs) because of its chemical or biological activity
sentence: In science class, we added a special reagent to the liquid to see if it would change color.
origin: New Latin reagent-, reagens, present participle of reagere to react

definition: an orange-red mineral consisting of arsenic sulfide and having a resinous luster
sentence: Realgar is a bright red mineral that was used a long time ago to make colorful paints.
origin: Middle English, from Medieval Latin, from Catalan, from Arabic rahj al-ghār powder of the mine

definition: kingdom
sentence: The fairy tale took place in a magical realm where dragons flew through the clouds.
origin: Middle English realme, from Anglo-French, alteration of Old French reiame, from Latin regimen control

definition: —used for a real estate agent who is a member of the National Association of Realtors
sentence: The Realtor showed my parents three different houses to see which one we liked the best.

definition: a stringed instrument, usually with one or two strings, played with a bow; common in Islamic countries.
sentence: A rebab is a traditional stringed instrument that is played with a bow in many different countries.

definition: repellent, irritating
sentence: The giant had a rebarbative personality, making it very hard for the heroes to talk to him.
origin: French rébarbatif, from Middle French, from rebarber to be repellent, from re- + barbe beard, from Latin barba

definition: a loud, reverberating sound or echo.
sentence: The reboation of the thunder was so loud that it made the windows in our house rattle.

definition: obstinately defiant of authority or restraint : stubbornly uncooperative or disobedient
sentence: The recalcitrant mule refused to move, no matter how much the farmer pulled on the rope.
origin: Late Latin recalcitrant-, recalcitrans, present participle of recalcitrare to be stubbornly disobedient, from Latin, to kick back, from re- + calcitrare to kick, from calc-, calx heel

definition: the quality or state of being reciprocal : mutual dependence, action, or influence
sentence: Friendship is based on reciprocity, which means helping each other and being kind in return.

definition: to restore to friendship or harmony
sentence: The two friends realized their argument was reconcilable, so they said sorry and played together again.
origin: Middle English, from Anglo-French or Latin; Anglo-French reconciler, from Latin reconciliare, from re- + conciliare to conciliate

definition: to make a reconnaissance of
sentence: The scouts went ahead to reconnoiter the trail and make sure it was safe for the rest of the group.
origin: obsolete French reconnoître, literally, to recognize, from Old French reconoistre

definition: crying for mercy : cowardly
sentence: The recreant knight ran away from the battle instead of staying to protect the castle.
origin: Middle English, from Anglo-French, from present participle of (se) recreire to give up, yield, from Medieval Latin (se) recredere to resign oneself (to a judgment), from Latin re- + credere to believe

definition: consisting of waste or dross; of the nature of a secretion that is reabsorbed.
sentence: The scientist studied the recrementitious waste to see what the animal had been eating.

definition: a retaliatory accusation; also : the making of such accusations
sentence: After the vase broke, the siblings exchanged recriminatory looks, each blaming the other.
origin: Medieval Latin recrimination-, recriminatio, from recriminare to make a retaliatory charge, from Latin re- + criminari to accuse

definition: breaking out again : renewing
sentence: The cold weather caused a recrudescent itch on my skin that had almost gone away.

definition: suggestive of repose : leaning, resting
sentence: I saw a person riding a recumbent bicycle, where they sit back and peddle with their feet in front.
origin: Latin recumbent-, recumbens, present participle of recumbere to lie down, from re- + -cumbere to lie down; akin to Latin cubare to lie

definition: the act or state of being a recusant
sentence: In history, recusancy was when people refused to attend the services of the official church.

definition: exuding fragrance : aromatic
sentence: The kitchen was redolent with the wonderful smell of fresh cinnamon rolls.
origin: Middle English, from Middle French, from Latin redolent-, redolens, present participle of redolēre to emit a scent, from re-, red- + olēre to smell

definition: allaying heat or fever
sentence: A refrigerant is a special liquid inside the fridge that helps keep all of our food cold.

definition: an area of relatively unaltered climate that is inhabited by plants and animals during a period of continental climatic change (such as a glaciation) and remains as a center of relict forms from which a new dispersion and speciation may take place after climatic readjustment
sentence: The deep valley acted as a refugium for rare plants that couldn't grow anywhere else.
origin: New Latin, from Latin, refuge

definition: royal rights or prerogatives
sentence: The king was dressed in his full royal regalia, including a shiny crown and a purple robe.
origin: Medieval Latin, from Latin, neuter plural of regalis

definition: a rowing, speedboat, or sailing race or a series of such races
sentence: We went to the lake to watch the regatta, which is a big race for many different types of boats.
origin: Italian regata

definition: popular music of Jamaican origin that combines native styles with elements of rock and soul music and is performed at moderate tempos with the accent on the offbeat
sentence: The band played a happy reggae song with a steady beat that made everyone want to dance.
origin: origin unknown

definition: of or relating to a king or his reign; specifically : calculated from a monarch's accession to the throne
sentence: The historian studied the regnal years of the queen to see how long she had ruled the country.
origin: Medieval Latin regnalis, from Latin regnum reign

definition: to become thrown or poured back
sentence: Mother birds sometimes regurgitate food to feed their tiny chicks in the nest.
origin: Medieval Latin regurgitatus, past participle of regurgitare, from Latin re- + Late Latin gurgitare to engulf, from Latin gurgit-, gurges whirlpool

definition: to pay back to someone : repay
sentence: My mom said the money I spent on school supplies was reimbursable, so she gave it back to me.
origin: re- + obsolete English imburse to put in the pocket, pay, from Medieval Latin imbursare, from Latin in- in- + Medieval Latin bursa purse

definition: of the character of or relating to reminiscence
sentence: The taste of the apple pie was reminiscent of the ones my grandmother used to bake.
origin: Latin reminiscent-, reminiscens, present participle of reminisci to remember, from re- + -minisci (akin to Latin ment-, mens mind)

definition: an earnest presentation of reasons for opposition or grievance; especially : a document formally stating such points
sentence: The students signed a letter of remonstrance to ask the principal not to cancel the field trip.

definition: the herd of horses from which those to be used for the day are chosen
sentence: On the ranch, the cowboys chose fresh horses from the remuda to begin their day of work.
origin: American Spanish, relay of horses, from Spanish, exchange, from remudar to exchange, from re- + mudar to change, from Latin mutare

definition: something that remunerates : recompense, pay
sentence: The boy received a small remuneration for his hard work of mowing the neighbor's lawn.

definition: to negotiate again (as to adjust interest rates or repayments or to get more money)
sentence: The two teams had to renegotiate the rules of the game to make it fair for everyone.

definition: resistance, opposition
sentence: The toddler showed great renitency when it was time for his nap, refusing to lie down.

definition: one who gives up or resigns a right, title, or belief; an ascetic.
sentence: The renunciant decided to give up all his fancy toys and live a very simple and quiet life.

definition: a repairing or keeping in repair
sentence: The company had to pay reparations to fix the park after their trucks damaged the grass.
origin: Middle English reparacion, from Anglo-French, from Late Latin reparation-, reparatio, from Latin reparare

definition: experiencing repentance : penitent
sentence: Leo felt very repentant after he accidentally broke his sister's toy and tried to fix it.

definition: reflection, reverberation
sentence: Breaking the school rules can have a serious repercussion, like losing your recess time.
origin: Latin repercussion-, repercussio, from repercutere to drive back, from re- + percutere to beat

definition: an action originating in common law and now largely codified by which a plaintiff having a right in personal property which is claimed to be wrongfully taken or detained by the defendant seeks to recover possession of the property and sometimes to obtain damages for the wrongful detention; also : a procedure allowing the plaintiff as a provisional remedy to take possession of the property prior to a judgment on the action
sentence: The man used a legal rule called replevin to get his bicycle back from someone who took it.
origin: Middle English, borrowed from Anglo-French replevyn, replevyne, from replevir "to vow, pledge, release by giving surety" (from re-  + plevir "to give as surety, promise, swear," going back, with conjugation change, to early Medieval Latin plebere "to give surety") + -yn, -yne, going back to Latin -īna, deverbal suffix, noun derivative from feminine of -īnus

definition: duplicate, repeat
sentence: We tried to replicate the science experiment at home to see if we got the same result.
origin: Middle English replecaten "to repeat," borrowed from Latin replicātus, past participle of replicō, replicāre "to turn back on itself, bend back, unroll (a papyrus book), go over (a thought, topic) repeatedly, make a replication" (Late Latin also "to restore, repeat, reply"), from re-  + -plicāre "to fold, bend"

definition: a place, room, or container where something is deposited or stored : depository
sentence: The library is a repository of information where you can find books about almost anything.

definition: to delay the punishment of (someone, such as a condemned prisoner)
sentence: The rain gave us a short reprieve from the heat, making the afternoon much cooler.
origin: probably blend of obsolete repreve to reprove (from Middle English) and obsolete repry to remand, postpone, from Anglo-French repri-, past stem of reprendre to take back

definition: a retaliatory act
sentence: In the story, the dragon attacked the village as a reprisal for the knights stealing its egg.
origin: Middle English reprisail, from Anglo-French reprisaile, from Medieval Latin represalia, from Old Italian rappresaglia, ultimately from ripreso, past participle of riprendere to take back, from ri- re- (from Latin re-) + prendere to take, from Latin prehendere

definition: a mass for the dead
sentence: A Requiem is a special piece of music that is played to honor someone who has passed away.
origin: Middle English, from Latin (first word of the introit of the requiem mass), accusative of requies rest, from re- + quies quiet, rest

definition: the act of formally requiring or calling upon someone to perform an action
sentence: The teacher had to fill out a requisition to get more art supplies for the classroom.
origin: Middle English requisicion, from Middle French or Medieval Latin; Middle French requisition, from Medieval Latin requisition-, requisitio, from Latin, act of searching, from requirere

definition: a usually ornamental wood or stone screen or partition wall behind an altar
sentence: The wall behind the altar in the old church was a beautiful reredos with many carvings.
origin: Middle English, from Anglo-French reredors, areredos, from arere behind + dos back, from Latin dorsum

definition: the capability of a body to recover its size and shape after deformation caused especially by compressive stress
sentence: Plants show great resilience by growing back even after a very cold and snowy winter.
origin: see

definition: tending to restore or make amends.
sentence: The judge ordered a restitutory payment to help the woman buy a new window for her shop.

definition: a short account of one's career and qualifications prepared by an applicant for a job.
sentence: My older sister wrote a résumé to show all the things she is good at for her first job.

definition: to raise from the dead
sentence: The old town tradition was resurrected after many years of not being celebrated.
origin: back-formation from resurrection

definition: to revive from apparent death or from unconsciousness; also : revitalize
sentence: The lifeguard learned how to resuscitate people to help them breathe if they fall in the water.
origin: Latin resuscitatus, past participle of resuscitare to reawaken, from re- + suscitare to rouse, from sub-, sus- up + citare to put in motion, stir ,

definition: inclined to be silent or uncommunicative in speech : reserved
sentence: The new student was a bit reticent at first and didn't talk much until he made friends.
origin: Latin reticent-, reticens, present participle of reticēre to keep silent, from re- + tacēre to be silent

definition: the sensory membrane that lines the eye, is composed of several layers including one containing the rods and cones, and functions as the immediate instrument of vision by receiving the image formed by the lens and converting it into chemical and nervous signals which reach the brain by way of the optic nerve
sentence: The retina is the part at the back of your eye that catches the light so you can see.
origin: Middle English rethina, from Medieval Latin retina, probably from Latin rete net

definition: the chief and typical vitamin A C20H29OH that is a highly unsaturated alicyclic alcohol used in various forms in medicine and nutrition
sentence: Retinol is an ingredient in some skin creams that helps keep the skin healthy.
origin: retin- + ; from its being the source of retinal

definition: observation of the retina of the eye especially to determine the state of refraction
sentence: The eye doctor used retinoscopy to see exactly how well the boy's eyes could focus.

definition: the act of ceding or giving something back.
sentence: The retrocedence of the water after the flood meant that people could finally return home.

definition: to utilize present information or ideas to infer or explain (a past event or state of affairs)
sentence: Scientists try to retrodict what the weather was like during the time of the dinosaurs.
origin: retro- + predict

definition: having or being motion in a direction contrary to that of the general motion of similar bodies and especially east to west among the stars
sentence: Sometimes a planet looks like it is moving in retrograde, or backward, in the night sky.
origin: Middle English, from Latin retrogradus, from retrogradi

definition: one that returns after death or a long absence
sentence: In the spooky story, a revenant returned to the old house where it used to live.
origin: French, from present participle of revenir to return

definition: tending to reverberate
sentence: The empty hallway was very reverberant, making our footsteps sound much louder.

definition: a portion of an epic poem adapted for recitation
sentence: The pianist performed a beautiful rhapsody that moved from very slow to very fast.
origin: Latin rhapsodia, from Greek rhapsōidia recitation of selections from epic poetry, rhapsody, from rhapsōidos rhapsodist, from rhaptein to sew, stitch together + aidein to sing

definition: a somewhat elongated usually horizontal subterranean plant stem that is often thickened by deposits of reserve food material, produces shoots above and roots below, and is distinguished from a true root in possessing buds, nodes, and usually scalelike leaves
sentence: Ginger is a type of rhizome, which is an underground stem that grows roots and shoots.
origin: New Latin rhizomat-, rhizoma, from Greek rhizōmat-, rhizōma mass of roots, from rhizoun to cause to take root, from rhiza root

definition: a glancing rebound (as of a projectile off a flat surface); also : an object that ricochets
sentence: The rubber ball hit the wall and began to ricochet around the room.
origin: French

definition: the opening or gape of a mouth; especially : the gape of a bird's mouth
sentence: The scary mask had a wide rictus that made it look like it was laughing in a creepy way.
origin: New Latin, from Latin, open mouth, from ringi to open the mouth; akin to Old Church Slavic rǫgŭ mockery

definition: pasta made in short wide fluted tubes
sentence: Rigatoni is a type of tube-shaped pasta that is great for holding lots of sauce.
origin: Italian, plural, from rigato furrowed, fluted, from past participle of rigare to furrow, flute, from riga line, of Germanic origin; akin to Old High German rīga line

definition: impressively or ostentatiously fancy or stylish : fashionable, posh
sentence: The ritziness of the hotel was clear from the golden statues and the velvet carpets.
origin: Ritz hotels, noted for their opulence

definition: boisterously carefree, joyful, or high-spirited
sentence: We had a rollicking good time playing tag and running around the park all afternoon.

definition: a hard sharp cheese of Italian origin that is often served grated
sentence: Romano is a salty, hard cheese that tastes great when grated over a bowl of soup.
origin: Italian, Roman, from Latin Romanus

definition: a mineral consisting of an antimonite of calcium.
sentence: Romeite is a yellow mineral that collectors sometimes look for in old mines.

definition: a translucent amber-colored to almost black brittle friable resin that is obtained from the oleoresin or deadwood of pine trees or from tall oil and used especially in making varnish
sentence: I rub rosin on my violin bow to help it grip the strings and make a beautiful sound.
origin: Middle English, from Anglo-French reisine, rosine resin

definition: an ancient Roman platform for public orators
sentence: The student stood at the rostrum to give her speech to the rest of the school.
origin: Latin, beak, ship's beak, from rodere to gnaw

definition: the use of memory usually with little intelligence
sentence: Learning by rote means repeating something over and over until you remember it by heart.
origin: Middle English

definition: photogravure
sentence: Rotogravure is a type of printing process used to make many copies of magazines and pictures.
origin: German Rotogravur, blend of Latin rota wheel and German Photogravur photogravure

definition: a small scroll or roll of parchment.
sentence: A rotulet is a small scroll of paper that was used a long time ago for short messages.

definition: deckhand
sentence: A roustabout is a worker who does many different jobs to help set up a circus or a fair.

definition: a bounding or limiting line; especially : one that when crossed commits a person irrevocably
sentence: Once you cross the Rubicon and make a big decision, there is usually no going back.
origin: Latin Rubicon-, Rubico, river of northern Italy forming part of the boundary between Cisalpine Gaul and Italy whose crossing by Julius Caesar in 49 b.c. was regarded by the Senate as an act of war

definition: a basic principle or element or a fundamental skill —usually used in plural
sentence: In our first lesson, we learned the rudiments, or the basic rules, of how to play soccer.
origin: Latin rudimentum beginning, from rudis raw, rude

definition: full of wrinkles
sentence: The leaf of the plant was rugose, which means it had a very wrinkled and bumpy surface.
origin: Latin rugosus, from ruga

definition: to go over in the mind repeatedly and often casually or slowly
sentence: Cows like to ruminate, which means they chew their food once, swallow it, and then chew it again.
origin: Latin ruminatus, past participle of ruminari to chew the cud, muse upon, from rumin-, rumen rumen; perhaps akin to Sanskrit romantha act of chewing the cud

definition: to go into or reside in the country : follow a rustic life
sentence: The rustication of the stone walls gave the cottage a very charming and old-fashioned look.
