definition: of or relating to a sabbatical year
sentence: The teacher took a sabbatical for a year to travel and learn new ways to help his students.
origin: Late Latin sabbaticus, from Greek sabbatikos, from sabbaton

definition: detailed statistical analysis of baseball data (as for the purposes of evaluating player performance and developing playing strategies)
sentence: People who love baseball use sabermetrics to study all the statistics of the players.
origin: saber- (from Society for American Baseball Research) + -metrics (as in econometrics)

definition: a Christian rite (such as baptism or the Eucharist) that is believed to have been ordained by Christ and that is held to be a means of divine grace or to be a sign or symbol of a spiritual reality
sentence: A sacrament is a very special and holy ceremony that people perform in their church.
origin: Middle English sacrement, sacrament, from Anglo-French & Late Latin; Anglo-French, from Late Latin sacramentum, from Latin, oath of allegiance, obligation, from sacrare to consecrate

definition: most sacred or holy : inviolable
sentence: The rule about being kind to others is sacrosanct and should never be broken.
origin: Latin sacrosanctus, probably from sacro sanctus hallowed by a sacred rite

definition: the collective sails of a ship; also the act of sailing.

definition: the ritual prayer of Muslims, performed five times daily.
sentence: Salat is the name for the daily prayers that people of the Muslim faith say five times a day.

definition: the quality or state of being salient

definition: of or relating to dancing
sentence: Grasshoppers move in a saltatory way, which means they are built for jumping very high.

definition: a set of pools or pans where salt is produced by evaporating seawater.

definition: a heraldic charge consisting of a cross formed by a bend and a bend sinister crossing in the center

definition: showing disrespect or scorn for someone or something : disdainfully or skeptically humorous : derisively mocking
sentence: The villain gave a sardonic smile when he thought his sneaky plan was going to work.
origin: re-formation, with the suffix , of earlier sardonian, from Greek sardónios, alteration (after Sardónios "Sardinian") of earlier sardánios "(of laughter or smiling) bitter, scornful" (of obscure origin) +

definition: a prostrate, reclining stem or runner of a plant.

definition: of or relating to a tailor or tailored clothes; broadly : of or relating to clothes

definition: to strut or move about in an ostentatious or conspicuous manner

definition: the governor of a province in ancient Persia

definition: cabbage cut fine and fermented in a brine made of its own juice with salt

definition: any of a family (Scarabaeidae) of stout-bodied beetles (such as a dung beetle) with lamellate or fan-shaped antennae

definition: scarlet fever

definition: the art of perspective representation especially as applied to the design and painting of stage scenery

definition: a sprightly humorous instrumental musical composition or movement commonly in quick triple time

definition: division, separation; also : discord, disharmony

definition: fast or quick (German origin).

definition: a typically 2-masted fore-and-aft rigged vessel with a foremast and a mainmast stepped nearly amidships

definition: having a tendency or addiction to scribbling or writing.

definition: delightful, excellent; especially : delicious

definition: to move or run swiftly especially as if driven forward

definition: to make (something, such as color or a painting) less brilliant by covering with a thin coat of opaque or semiopaque color applied with a nearly dry brush
sentence: To scumble is an art technique where you put a thin layer of paint over another color to make it softer.
origin: perhaps frequentative of

definition: to defeat or put an end to : do in

origin: origin unknown

definition: an implement used for mowing grass, grain, or other crops and composed of a long curving blade fastened at an angle to a long handle

definition: a straight line cutting a curve at two or more points

definition: withdrawal into privacy or solitude : retirement

definition: not migratory : settled

definition: any of a genus (Sedum) of widely distributed fleshy herbs of the orpine family

origin: borrowed from New Latin Senecio, genus name, going back to Latin seneciōn-, seneciō "old man, groundsel," from senec-, variant stem of sen-, senex "old, aged, old man" + -iōn-, -iō, suffix forming appellatives from adjectives

definition: an agent or steward in charge of a lord's estate in feudal times

definition: any of a genus (Senna synonym Cassia) of leguminous herbs, shrubs, and trees native to warm regions; especially : one used medicinally

definition: a teacher or instructor usually of Japanese martial arts (such as karate or judo)

definition: of or relating to a sepulchre

definition: a widely cultivated chiefly tropical or subtropical annual erect herb (Sesamum indicum of the family Pedaliaceae); also : its small seeds used especially as a source of oil and a flavoring agent

definition: a long seat with a back

definition: the act or process of severing : the state of being severed

definition: Yitzhak 1915—2012 originally surname Yizernitzky prime minister of Israel (1983—84; 1986—92)

definition: a traditional Irish storyteller.

definition: a sandwich especially of sliced lamb or chicken, vegetables, and often tahini wrapped in pita bread

definition: used to introduce a sudden or magical transformation or occurrence.

definition: everything involved in what is under consideration —usually used in the phrase the whole shebang

definition: shelduck
sentence: A sheldrake is a large, colorful duck that often lives near the coast.

definition: river 55 miles (88 kilometers) long in northern Virginia flowing northeast between the Allegheny and Blue Ridge Mountains across the northeastern tip of West Virginia and into the Potomac River and forming the Shenandoah Valley
sentence: We visited the Shenandoah Valley, which is a beautiful place with mountains and a long river.

definition: activity or behavior that is not honest or proper : deceptive or questionable practices or conduct —usually used in plural
sentence: The kittens were up to their usual shenanigans, chasing each other and hiding in boxes.
origin: origin unknown

sentence: A Shetland pony is a small and very strong horse that originally came from islands near Scotland.

definition: to go stealthily : sneak

definition: a device with meshes or perforations through which finer particles of a mixture (as of ashes, flour, or sand) of various sizes may be passed to separate them from coarser ones, through which the liquid may be drained from liquid-containing material, or through which soft materials may be forced for reduction to fine particles

definition: existing or occurring at the same time : exactly coincident

definition: one who practices divination by drawing lots.

definition: of or relating to salvation.

definition: of or relating to Sirius, the Dog Star.

definition: marked by settled sedateness and often prim self-restraint : sober, grave

definition: marked by outstanding strength and vigor of body, mind, or spirit

definition: shaped like a small star.
sentence: The scientist studied the stellar system and described it as having a complex, stellular structure.

definition: extremely loud
sentence: The principal used a stentorian voice that could be heard all the way across the noisy cafeteria.

definition: one of the vast usually level and treeless tracts in southeastern Europe or Asia

definition: any of a genus (Stevia) of composite herbs and shrubs of tropical and subtropical America; especially : a white-flowered tender perennial (S. rebaudiana) native to Paraguay
sentence: My dad uses stevia to sweeten his tea because it comes from a plant and has no sugar.

definition: something that rouses or incites to activity: such as

definition: to make an agreement or covenant to do or forbear something : contract

definition: a form of government in which the military has control.

definition: the part of the earth's atmosphere which extends from the top of the troposphere to about 30 miles (50 kilometers) above the surface and in which temperature increases gradually to about 32°F (0°C) and clouds rarely form

definition: the fact or state of being striated

definition: an abnormal narrowing of a bodily passage; also : the narrowed part

definition: the quality or state of being strident

definition: —used for an expanded rigid polystyrene plastic
sentence: We used Styrofoam cups for the party because they are lightweight and keep the drinks cool.

definition: to bring under control and governance as a subject : conquer

definition: inadequate to produce a sensation or a perception

definition: partially dislocated, as a joint.

definition: capable of being submerged
sentence: The scientists used a small submersible to dive deep into the ocean and look at strange fish.

definition: wearing a slight or quiet smile.

definition: following in time, order, or place

definition: real being : existence

definition: substratum

definition: deception by artifice or stratagem in order to conceal, escape, or evade

origin: Late Latin subterfugium, from Latin subterfugere to escape, evade, from subter- secretly (from subter underneath; akin to Latin sub under) + fugere to flee ,

origin: Latin subterraneus, from sub- + terra earth

definition: the quality or state of being subtle

definition: a short intercessory prayer usually in a series

origin: Middle English, "help, aid, intercessory prayer, indulgence," borrowed from Middle French & Medieval Latin; Middle French, borrowed from Medieval Latin suffrāgium "vote, selection, aid, support, intercessory prayer," going back to Latin, "vote cast in an assembly, right to vote, decision reached by a vote, influence exerted in support of a candidate or policy," from suffrāgor, suffrāgārī "to express public support (for a candidate, measure, etc.), be favorable (toward)" (from suf-, assimilated form of sub-  + -frāg-, probably from the base of frangere, past participle frāctus, "to break, shatter") + -ium, deverbal suffix of function or state

definition: island of western Indonesia south of the Malay Peninsula area 182,542 square miles (472,784 square kilometers)

definition: to issue a call to convene : convoke

origin: Middle English somnen, somonen, from Anglo-French somondre, from Vulgar Latin *summonere, alteration of Latin summonēre to remind secretly, from sub- secretly + monēre to warn ,

definition: extremely costly, rich, luxurious, or magnificent; also : magnificent
sentence: The royal banquet featured a sumptuous feast with every kind of food you can imagine.

definition: the quality or state of being superficial

definition: the quality or state of being supreme; especially : a position of unquestioned authority, dominance, or influence

definition: to desist from action; also : to come to an end : cease

definition: the principles, ideals, or practice of producing fantastic or incongruous imagery or effects in art, literature, film, or theater by means of unnatural or irrational juxtapositions and combinations

definition: a low-lying or depressed and often wet stretch of land; also : a shallow depression on a golf course

origin: Late Latin, alteration of Latin sillybus label for a book, from Greek sillybos

definition: an elemental being in the theory of Paracelsus that inhabits air

origin: probably borrowed from German tektonisch "pertaining to broader structural features of the earth's crust," earlier "of building or construction," borrowed from Late Latin tectonicus "of a builder or architect," borrowed from Greek tektonikós "of a carpenter, skilled in carpentry or building," from tekton-, téktōn "woodworker, carpenter, craftsman" + -ikos ; téktōn going back to Indo-European *tetḱ-on- (whence also Sanskrit takṣan-, tákṣā "carpenter," Avestan tašan-, tašā "builder, creator"), n-stem derivative from a verbal base *tetḱ- "fashion, produce," whence Sanskrit tákṣati "(s/he) fashions, builds from wood," Avestan tāšt "(s/he) forms," Latvian tešu, tèst "to hew," Old Church Slavic tešǫ, tesati "to hew, fell," (with o-grade) Lithuanian tašýti "to hew"

definition: hollywood

definition: the cutting edge of a bird's beak.

definition: of or relating to toponyms or toponymy

definition: a quadrilateral having only two sides parallel
sentence: In geometry, a trapezoid is a four-sided shape where only two of the sides are parallel.
origin: New Latin trapezoïdes, from Greek trapezoeidēs trapezium-shaped, from trapeza table

definition: the growth or movement of a plant in response to a wound.
sentence: Traumatropism is when a plant begins to grow in a different direction because it was hurt or touched.

definition: to labor hard : toil
sentence: The book described the travails of the pioneers as they traveled across the rough and rocky land.

definition: a swiveling or lever device pressed by the foot to drive a machine
sentence: My grandmother used her foot to push the treadle on her old sewing machine to make it go.
origin: Middle English tredel step of a stair, from Old English, from tredan

definition: clover; broadly : any of several leguminous herbs (such as bird's-foot trefoil) with leaves that have or appear to have three leaflets
sentence: A trefoil is a design or a leaf that has three distinct parts, like a clover.
origin: Middle English, from Anglo-French, from Latin trifolium, from tri- + folium leaf

definition: a frame of latticework used as a screen or as a support for climbing plants
sentence: We built a wooden trellis so the grapevines would have something to climb up as they grew.
origin: Middle English trelis, from Anglo-French treleis, from Old French treille arbor, from Latin trichila summerhouse

definition: to use a trephine on (the skull)
sentence: A long time ago, some people used trepanation, which meant making a small hole in the skull to help with headaches.
origin: Middle English trepanen "to bore holes into the skull," borrowed from Medieval Latin trapanāre, trepanāre, derivative of trepanum

definition: a nervous or fearful feeling of uncertain agitation : apprehension
sentence: I felt a little bit of trepidation before I had to stand up and give my speech in front of the whole school.
origin: Latin trepidation-, trepidatio, from trepidare to tremble, from trepidus agitated; probably akin to Old English thrafian to urge, push, Greek trapein to press grapes

definition: the sorting of and allocation of treatment to patients and especially battle and disaster victims according to a system of priorities designed to maximize the number of survivors
sentence: At the hospital, the nurses use triage to decide which patients need to see the doctor first.
origin: French, sorting, sifting, from trier to sort, from Old French

definition: a stream feeding a larger stream or a lake
sentence: A tributary is a smaller river or stream that flows into a much larger river.

definition: a brief space of time : instant —used chiefly in the phrase in a trice
sentence: I told my mom I would have my room cleaned in a trice, and I was finished in just a few minutes.
origin: Middle English trise, literally, pull, from trisen

definition: consisting of or relating to thirty.
sentence: A tricenary event is something that marks a period of exactly thirty years.

definition: any of a genus (Triceratops) of large herbivorous quadrupedal ceratopsian dinosaurs of the Late Cretaceous with three horns, a bony hood or crest on the neck, and hoofed toes
sentence: The triceratops was a dinosaur with three sharp horns on its face and a large bony frill.
origin: New Latin, from tri- + Greek kerat-, keras horn + ōps face ,

definition: a gallery forming an upper story to the aisle of a church and typically an arcaded story between the nave arches and clerestory
sentence: In the big cathedral, the triforium is a gallery or a walkway located high above the floor.
origin: Medieval Latin

definition: of or relating to the trigeminal nerve
sentence: The trigeminal nerve is a very important nerve in your face that helps you feel and chew.
origin: New Latin trigeminus trigeminal nerve, from Latin, threefold, from tri- + geminus twin

definition: any of a group of lipids that are esters formed from one molecule of glycerol and three molecules of one or more fatty acids, are widespread in adipose tissue, and commonly circulate in the blood in the form of lipoproteins
sentence: Triglycerides are a type of fat found in your blood that your body uses for energy.
origin: International Scientific Vocabulary

definition: any of a genus (Trillium of the family Melanthiaceae) of herbs with an erect stem bearing a whorl of three leaves and a solitary typically spring-blooming flower
sentence: A trillium is a beautiful forest flower that is easy to spot because it has three leaves and three petals.
origin: New Latin, from Swedish trilling triplet; from its three leaves

definition: sad, mournful; also : wistful
sentence: The music sounded very triste, which is the French word for sad or gloomy.
origin: French, from Old French, from Latin tristis

definition: the act or process of triturating : the state of being triturated : comminution
sentence: The scientist used a mortar and pestle for the trituration of the hard rock into a fine powder.

definition: of or relating to nutrition : nutritional
sentence: In science, the trophic level of an animal shows where it fits in the food chain.
origin: French trophique, from Greek trophikos, from trophē nourishment, from trephein to nourish

definition: one of a class of lyric poets often of knightly rank who flourished from the 11th to the 13th century in France and Italy and whose major theme was courtly love
sentence: A troubadour was a traveling musician who went from town to town singing songs and telling stories.
origin: French, from Old Occitan trobador, from trobar to compose, from Vulgar Latin *tropare, from Latin tropus trope

definition: river 120 miles (193 kilometers) long in eastern California and western Nevada flowing from Lake Tahoe into Pyramid Lake
sentence: We went on a camping trip near the Truckee River, which flows through California and Nevada.

definition: a stingray.
sentence: The trygon, also known as a stingray, has a flat body and a long tail with a sharp stinger.

definition: to express disapproval of by or as if by uttering tsk
sentence: My grandmother tsk-tsked when she saw that I had tracked muddy footprints onto her clean floor.

definition: having the form of or consisting of a tube
sentence: The slide at the playground was tubular, looking like a giant, long pipe that I could crawl through.

definition: a sling formed by a strap slung over the forehead or chest and used for carrying or helping to support a pack on the back or in hauling loads
sentence: A tumpline is a strap that goes across your forehead to help you carry a heavy pack on your back.
origin: tump, of Algonquian origin; akin to Eastern Abenaki mádûmbí pack strap

definition: a gray-white heavy high-melting ductile hard polyvalent metallic element that resembles chromium and molybdenum in many of its properties and is used especially in carbide materials and electrical components (such as lamp filaments) and in hardening alloys (such as steel)
sentence: Tungsten is a very strong metal that is used to make the tiny wire inside many light bulbs.
origin: Swedish, from tung heavy + sten stone

definition: thick or opaque with or as if with roiled sediment
sentence: The turbidity of the pond meant the water was cloudy and it was hard to see the fish at the bottom.
origin: Latin turbidus confused, turbid, from turba confusion, crowd, probably from Greek tyrbē confusion

definition: partially refined light brown sugar with large crystals.
sentence: I like to sprinkle crunchy turbinado sugar on top of my oatmeal because it tastes like caramel.

definition: a boneless chicken stuffed into a boneless duck stuffed into a boneless turkey
sentence: A turducken is a funny dish made by putting a chicken inside a duck, which is then put inside a turkey.
origin: turkey +  +

definition: the normal state of turgidity and tension in living cells; especially : the distension of the protoplasmic layer and wall of a plant cell by the fluid contents
sentence: Plants need water to maintain turgor, which is the pressure that keeps their stems standing up straight.
origin: Late Latin, turgidity, swelling, from Latin turgēre

definition: a breed of domestic chicken that has a naturally featherless neck.
sentence: A turken is a type of chicken that looks a bit like a turkey because it has no feathers on its neck.

definition: a connoisseur of cheese : a cheese fancier
sentence: If you love cheese more than any other food, you might be called a turophile.
origin: irregular from Greek tyros cheese + English -phile

definition: a yellow to brown semifluid oleoresin obtained as an exudate from the terebinth
sentence: The painter used turpentine to clean the thick oil paint off his brushes.
origin: Middle English terbentyne, turpentyne, from Anglo-French & Medieval Latin; Anglo-French terebentine, from Medieval Latin terbentina, from Latin terebinthina, feminine of terebinthinus of terebinth, from terebinthus terebinth, from Greek terebinthos

definition: a compact tuft especially of grass or sedge; also : an area of raised solid ground in a marsh or bog that is bound together by roots of low vegetation
sentence: A tussock is a thick clump of grass that grows higher than the ground around it.
origin: origin unknown

definition: instruction especially of an individual
sentence: Under the tutelage of her piano teacher, Maya learned how to play a very difficult song.
origin: Latin tutela protection, guardian (from tutari to protect, frequentative of tueri to look at, guard) + English -age

definition: a confection or ice cream containing chopped usually candied fruits
sentence: I chose the tutti-frutti ice cream because it has many different kinds of fruit mixed inside.
origin: Italian tutti frutti all fruits

definition: two
sentence: Mark Twain was a famous author who wrote many exciting stories about the Mississippi River.

definition: nasal speech or resonance
sentence: The guitar made a loud twang sound when my brother pulled on the string too hard.
origin: imitative

definition: tympanic membrane
sentence: The tympanum is the thin layer of skin inside your ear that vibrates so you can hear sounds.
origin: Medieval Latin & Latin; Medieval Latin, eardrum, from Latin, drum, architectural panel, from Greek tympanon drum, kettledrum; perhaps akin to Greek typtein to beat

definition: the scientific study of blindness, its causes, and its treatment.
sentence: Typhlology is the scientific study of blindness and the ways to help people who cannot see.

definition: presence everywhere or in many places especially simultaneously : omnipresence
sentence: The ubiquity of cars means that you can see them on almost every street in the city.
origin: Latin ubique everywhere, from ubi where + -que, enclitic generalizing particle; akin to Latin quis who and to Latin -que and ,

definition: the study of unidentified flying objects
sentence: If you are interested in stories about aliens and spaceships, you might enjoy ufology.
origin: UFO + -logy

definition: a native or inhabitant of Ukraine
sentence: My friend brought some delicious Ukrainian bread to share with the class during our food festival.

definition: the bone on the little-finger side of the human forearm; also : a corresponding part of the forelimb of vertebrates above fishes
sentence: The ulna is one of the two bones in your lower arm, located on the side of your pinky finger.
origin: New Latin, from Latin, elbow

definition: relating to biological cycles that occur more than once a day.
sentence: An ultradian rhythm is a cycle in your body that happens several times in a single day.

definition: of or relating to the carrot family
sentence: An umbelliferous plant, like a carrot or parsley, has flowers that grow in the shape of an umbrella.

definition: of, relating to, or used at the navel
sentence: The umbilical cord is what connects a baby to its mother before the baby is born.
origin: borrowed from New Latin umbilīcālis, from Latin umbilīcus "navel, central point" + -ālis

definition: a feeling of pique or resentment at some often fancied slight or insult —usually used in the phrase take umbrage; often used with at
sentence: I took umbrage when my brother said my drawing looked like a giant scribble.
origin: Middle English, from Anglo-French, from Latin umbraticum, neuter of umbraticus of shade, from umbratus, past participle of umbrare to shade, from umbra shade, shadow; akin to Lithuanian unksmė shadow

definition: with soft pedal depressed —used as a direction in piano music
sentence: The piano teacher showed me how to use the una corda pedal to make the music sound much softer.
origin: Italian, literally, one string

definition: not christened
sentence: The new ship was still unchristened because the ceremony to give it a name hadn't happened yet.

definition: having, revealing, or marked by a smug, ingratiating, and false earnestness or spirituality
sentence: The man was so unctuous and overly polite that it felt like he wasn't being very honest.
origin: Middle English, from Middle French or Medieval Latin; Middle French unctueus, from Medieval Latin unctuosus, from Latin unctus act of anointing, from unguere to anoint

definition: having hooves
sentence: An ungulate is an animal with hooves, like a horse, a cow, or a deer.
origin: Late Latin ungulatus, from Latin ungula hoof, from unguis nail, hoof

definition: done or undertaken by one person or party
sentence: The captain decided unilaterally to turn the ship around without asking any of the other sailors.

definition: containing a single cavity
sentence: The scientist looked at a unilocular plant part, which means it had only one small compartment inside.

definition: having one meaning only
sentence: The class gave a univocal 'yes' when the teacher asked if they wanted to go to the park.
origin: Late Latin univocus, from Latin uni- + voc-, vox voice

definition: to loosen from or as if from moorings
sentence: The boat became unmoored during the storm and began to float away from the dock.

definition: to disengage or separate the threads of : disentangle
sentence: Be careful not to pull on the loose thread, or your whole sweater might start to unravel.

definition: not remitting : constant, incessant
sentence: The unremitting rain meant that we had to stay inside for three whole days.

definition: not exceeded by anything else : not surpassed
sentence: The view from the top of the mountain was unsurpassed, meaning nothing else was as beautiful.

definition: not able to be defended
sentence: The plan to build a house out of paper was untenable because it would fall over in the wind.

definition: to criticize severely : find fault with
sentence: My dad had to upbraid me for forgetting to lock the front door when I came home.
origin: Middle English upbreyden, from Old English ūpbregdan, probably from ūp up + bregdan to snatch, move suddenly

definition: the 20th letter of the Greek alphabet
sentence: Upsilon is the twentieth letter of the Greek alphabet and looks like the letter 'Y.'
origin: Middle Greek y psilon, literally, simple y; from the desire to distinguish it from oi, which was pronounced the same in later Greek

definition: of or relating to a bear or the bear family (Ursidae)
sentence: The giant bear moved with an ursine waddle as it walked through the forest.
origin: Latin ursinus, from ursus bear

definition: one who usurps something: such as
sentence: In the story, the usurper tried to take the crown and become king even though he wasn't the rightful heir.

definition: an advocate or adherent of utilitarianism
sentence: The boots were very utilitarian; they weren't fancy, but they kept my feet perfectly dry.

definition: the pigmented middle layer of the eye consisting of the iris and ciliary body together with the choroid
sentence: The doctor checked the uveal part of the eye to make sure it was healthy and working right.
origin: Medieval Latin, from Latin uva grape

definition: the pendent fleshy lobe in the middle of the posterior border of the soft palate
sentence: The uvula is the small piece of flesh that hangs down at the very back of your throat.
origin: Middle English, from Medieval Latin, diminutive of Latin uva cluster of grapes, uvula; probably akin to Greek oa service tree, Old English īw yew

definition: the act of vaccinating
sentence: I had to get a vaccination at the doctor's office to help my body stay safe from the flu.
origin: earlier, "inoculation with fluid from cowpox pustules," from vaccine "of cowpox" (in the phrases vaccine matter, vaccine virus) +

definition: to wander in the manner of a vagabond : roam about
sentence: The story was about a group of vagabonds who traveled from town to town with everything they owned.

definition: not clearly expressed : stated in indefinite terms
sentence: The directions were so vague that we weren't sure if we should turn left or right at the tree.
origin: borrowed from French, going back to Middle French, going back to Old French, "wandering, vagabond," borrowed from Latin vagus "moving freely, wandering," perhaps akin to Old High German wankōn "to totter, stagger," winkan "to waver, stagger, wink," Old English wincian "to close the eyes"

definition: marked by vainglory : boastful
sentence: The vainglorious prince spent all day looking at himself in the mirror and admiring his crown.
origin: Middle English vaynegloryous, from vaynglorie  + -ous , after Middle French vaneglorious and Medieval Latin vāniglōrius

definition: any of a genus (Valeriana of the family Caprifoliaceae, the honeysuckle family) of perennial herbs and shrubs many of which possess medicinal properties
sentence: Valerian is a plant with pretty flowers that some people use to help them feel calm and sleepy.
origin: Middle English, borrowed from Anglo-French or Medieval Latin; Anglo-French valeriane, borrowed from Medieval Latin valeriana, of obscure origin

definition: possessing or acting with bravery or boldness : courageous
sentence: The valiant knight rode his horse toward the dragon to save the people of the village.
origin: Middle English vailant, valiant, borrowed from Anglo-French vaillant "worthy, strong, courageous," from present participle of valer "to be of worth," going back to Latin valēre "to have strength, be well"

definition: an anatomical groove, channel, or depression; especially : one between the base of the tongue and the epiglottis
sentence: In biology, a vallecula is a small groove or a valley-like part between two structures in the body.
origin: borrowed from New Latin vallēcula, going back to Latin, "small valley," from vallēs, vallis "valley" (of uncertain origin) + -cula, diminutive suffix

definition: one that valuates; specifically : one that appraises
sentence: The valuator looked at the old coin and told us exactly how much money it was worth.

definition: to subject to vandalism : damage
sentence: You should never vandalize a park or a building by drawing on the walls or breaking things.

definition: the forefront of an action or movement
sentence: The vanguard of the army was the group of soldiers that marched at the very front.
origin: Middle English vauntgard, borrowed from Anglo-French vantgarde, avantgarde, from avant- "fore-" (from avant "before," going back to Late Latin abante) + garde

definition: to overcome in battle : subdue completely
sentence: In the video game, I had to vanquish the giant robot to reach the next level.
origin: Middle English venquishen, borrowed from Anglo-French venquis-, extended stem of veintre, vaincre "to defeat, conquer," going back to Latin vincere

definition: a motorboat serving as a canal bus in Venice, Italy
sentence: In the city of Venice, people ride a vaporetto, which is a type of boat used like a bus on the water.
origin: borrowed from Italian, diminutive of vapore "steamboat," short for battello a vapore, borrowed from French bateau à vapeur "steamboat"

definition: an electronic component whose capacitance varies with the applied voltage.
sentence: A varactor is a small electronic part used in radios to help tune into different stations.

definition: abnormally swollen or dilated
sentence: The nurse explained that varicose veins are swollen veins that sometimes show up on a person's legs.
origin: borrowed from Latin varicōsus "suffering from dilated veins," from varic-, varix "dilated vein, " + -ōsus

definition: having discrete markings of different colors
sentence: The plant in our classroom has variegated leaves, which means they are green with pretty white stripes.
origin: from past participle of

definition: the rainy season in India.
sentence: In India, the varsha is the rainy season when the monsoon brings lots of water for the crops.

definition: the papal headquarters in Rome
sentence: The Vatican is a tiny independent country located right in the middle of the city of Rome.
origin: borrowed from Latin (mons) Vāticānus, hill on the west bank of the Tiber, the traditional site of the apostle Peter's tomb, on which a basilica was built in the 4th century

definition: a light often comic theatrical piece frequently combining pantomime, dialogue, dancing, and song
sentence: Long ago, people went to vaudeville shows to see many different acts like singers, dancers, and magicians.
origin: borrowed from French, "satirical song, comic theatrical piece," going back to Middle French (chançons de) vaul de ville "topical satirical songs," earlier vau de vire, named (according to 16th-century French authors) after the val de Vire, valley of the Vire River in Normandy, where such songs were allegedly composed

definition: a strict vegetarian who consumes no food (such as meat, eggs, or dairy products) that comes from animals; also : one who abstains from using animal products (such as leather)
sentence: Choosing veganism means eating only plant-based foods like fruits, vegetables, and grains.
origin: by contraction from

definition: a person who does not eat meat : someone whose diet consists wholly of vegetables, fruits, grains, nuts, and sometimes eggs or dairy products
sentence: My friend is a vegetarian, so she eats cheese and eggs but does not eat any meat.

definition: the quality or state of being vehement : intensity
sentence: Leo spoke with great vehemence because he really wanted to convince everyone to help clean up the park.
origin: Middle English vemance, vehemens, borrowed from Middle French vehemence, borrowed from Latin vehementia "violent movement, intensity," from vehement-, vehemens "violent, " + -ia

definition: of, relating to, or designed for vehicles and especially motor vehicles
sentence: The bridge was closed to all vehicular traffic, so no cars or trucks could cross over the river.
origin: borrowed from Late Latin vehiculāris, from Latin vehiculum  + -āris

definition: a local twitching of a muscle; also the act of twitching.
sentence: A vellication is a tiny, sudden twitch of a muscle, like when your eyelid jumps for a second.

definition: any of various fabrics with a pile or napped surface resembling velvet used in heavy weights for upholstery and curtains and in lighter weights for clothing; also : the article of clothing itself
sentence: My favorite pajamas are made of soft velours that feels just like velvet against my skin.
origin: borrowed from French velours "velvet, velour," going back to Middle French velours, velour, altered (after loss of final consonants and reintroduction of r) from Old French velous, probably (through a northern dialectal outcome) going back to a nominal derivative of Latin villōsus "shaggy, hairy," from villus "shaggy hair, cloth nap" + -ōsus

definition: the harvesting of grapes; the grape crop of a season.
sentence: The farmers were very busy during the vendage, which is the time of year when they harvest the grapes.

definition: a thin sheet of a material: such as
sentence: The table looks like solid oak, but it actually has a thin veneer of expensive wood over a cheaper board.
origin: noun derivative of , or borrowed directly from German (17th-century) furner, fornier (modern Furnier), noun derivative of fourniren, furniren "to apply thin strips of wood or other material (to cabinetwork, etc.)"

definition: punishment inflicted in retaliation for an injury or offense : retribution
sentence: In the story, the hero did not seek vengeance; instead, he chose to forgive the person who was mean to him.
origin: Middle English vengeaunce, borrowed from Anglo-French, from venger "to exact satisfaction for" (going back to Latin vindicāre "to lay claim to, exact retribution for") + -aunce

definition: of a kind that can be remitted : forgivable, pardonable; also : meriting no particular censure or notice : excusable
sentence: The teacher said that forgetting to put a date on the paper was a venial mistake that didn't need a punishment.
origin: Middle English, borrowed from Anglo-French & Late Latin; Anglo-French, borrowed from Late Latin veniālis, from Latin venia "favor, kindness, indulgence, pardon" (derivative of a verbal base *wen- "desire," whence also vener-, venus "sexual desire") + -ālis

definition: producing venom in a specialized gland and capable of inflicting injury or death
sentence: The hikers were careful to avoid the venomous snake hiding under the rock in the desert.
origin: Middle English venimous, borrowed from Anglo-French venimus, venimous, from venim  + -us, -ous

definition: the lower movable front of a medieval helmet
sentence: A knight could lift the ventail on his helmet so he could breathe more easily and see his friends.
origin: Middle English ventaile, borrowed from Anglo-French ventaille, from venter "to blow, fan" (derivative of vent "wind," going back to Latin ventus) + -aille, deverbal and denominal suffix, originally collective (going back to Latin -ālia )

definition: a stone worn, polished, or faceted by windblown sand
sentence: A ventifact is a rock that has been shaped and polished by the wind blowing sand against it for many years.
origin: Latin ventus "wind" +

definition: a cavity of a bodily part or organ: such as
sentence: A ventricle is one of the two large chambers at the bottom of your heart that pumps blood to your body.
origin: Middle English, borrowed from Latin ventriculus "belly, stomach, cavity in an organ," from ventr-, venter "belly, womb" + -culus, diminutive suffix (variant of -ulus  with nouns of the 3rd, 4th and 5th declensions)

definition: ventriloquism
sentence: The entertainer used ventriloquy to make it look like his wooden puppet was actually talking to the audience.
origin: borrowed from New Latin ventriloquium, from Late Latin ventriloquus "person who appears to produce speech sounds from within the body (as during spirit possession or under control of a deity)" + Latin -ium

definition: conformity with truth or fact : accuracy
sentence: The judge checked the veracity of the story to make sure the witness was telling the absolute truth.
origin: borrowed from New Latin vērācitāt-, vērācitās, from Latin vērāc-, vērāx "truthful" + -itāt-, -itās

definition: vervain; especially : any of numerous garden vervains of hybrid origin widely grown for their showy spikes of white, pink, red, or blue flowers which are borne in profusion over a long season
sentence: The garden was filled with purple verbena flowers that have a very sweet and fresh scent.
origin: borrowed from New Latin Verbena, a plant genus, going back to Medieval Latin verbēna "the plant Verbena officinalis," going back to Latin, "leafy branch used ceremonially or medicinally"

definition: not permitted or allowed : forbidden or prohibited by or as if by authority
sentence: Running in the hallway is verboten because the school rules say we must walk safely.
origin: borrowed from German, going back to Old High German farboten, past participle of farbiotan "to forbid," (parallel to Old English forbēodan "to "), from far-, fur-  + biotan "to offer"

definition: artistic use of contemporary everyday material in preference to the heroic or legendary especially in grand opera
sentence: The artist used verism in his sculpture, making sure to include every little wrinkle and detail to make it look real.
origin: borrowed from Italian verismo, from vero "true" (going back to Latin vērus) + -ismo

definition: being in fact the thing named and not false, unreal, or imaginary —often used to stress the aptness of a metaphor
sentence: The ice cream shop was a veritable paradise for kids, with over fifty different flavors to choose from.
origin: Middle English, "reliable, honest, true, factual," borrowed from Anglo-French (continental Old French, "real, true"), from verité "truth, " + -able

definition: an agent that destroys worms
sentence: The gardener used a safe vermicide to get rid of the tiny worms that were eating his tomato plants.
origin: borrowed from French, from vermi-  + -cide

definition: of, relating to, or occurring in the spring
sentence: The vernal equinox marks the first day of spring when the flowers begin to bloom again.
origin: borrowed from Latin vernālis, from vernus "of spring" (going back to pre-Latin *u̯esri-no-, adjective derivative from the base of Latin vēr "spring") + -ālis ; vēr "spring," going back to Indo-European *u̯ḗs-r̥-, *u̯es-n̥-s, whence also Old Norse vár "spring," Old Frisian wars, wērs, Welsh gwanwyn (Old Welsh guiannuin, from British Celtic *u̯esantēno-), Middle Irish errach (probably from *u̯esrāko-, with generalization of the lenited initial consonant), Old Church Slavic vesna, Russian vesná, Lithuanian vãsara "summer," Greek éar "spring" (from *u̯ehar, from *u̯esr̥), Armenian garun (gar- from *gehar-, from *u̯esr̥- + a suffix), Sanskrit vasantá-, Avestan vaŋri (locative) "in the spring"

definition: of, relating to, or occurring in the evening
sentence: Bats are vespertine creatures because they only come out to fly and hunt in the evening.
origin: Latin vespertinus, from vesper

definition: a passage, hall, or room between the outer door and the interior of a building : lobby
sentence: We left our wet umbrellas in the vestibule before walking into the main part of the house.
origin: Latin vestibulum forecourt

definition: a tall perennial grass (Chrysopogon zizanioides) of southeastern Asia cultivated in warm regions especially for its fragrant roots which are used especially in woven goods (such as mats) and in perfumes; also : its root
sentence: Vetiver is a type of grass with roots that smell very nice and are used to make perfumes.
origin: French vétiver, from Tamil veṭṭivēr

definition: to refuse to admit or approve : prohibit; also : to refuse assent to (a legislative bill) so as to prevent enactment or cause reconsideration
sentence: The principal vetoed the idea of having a pizza party every day because it wasn't very healthy.

definition: the benefice of a vicar
sentence: The vicarage is the house where the minister of the local church lives with his family.

definition: experienced or realized through imaginative or sympathetic participation in the experience of another
sentence: I felt a vicarious excitement for my friend when she told me she won the grand prize in the art contest.
origin: Latin vicarius, from vicis change, alternation, stead

definition: with the order changed : with the relations reversed : conversely
sentence: My sister helps me with my math and vice versa, which means I help her with her reading.
origin: Latin

definition: relating to or based on the number twenty.
sentence: A vicenary system of counting is based on the number twenty instead of the number ten.

definition: the governor of a country or province who rules as the representative of a king or sovereign
sentence: A viceroy was a person chosen by a king to rule over a distant land in the king's name.
origin: Middle French vice-roi, from vice- + roi king, from Old French rei, roi, from Latin reg-, rex

definition: the scientific study of crime victims including the study of the relationship between victim and offender and of the consequences and effects of being victimized; also : characteristics of a particular criminal's victim or victims
sentence: Scientists who study victimology want to learn how to better help and protect people who have been hurt.

definition: the act of keeping awake at times when sleep is customary; also : a period of wakefulness
sentence: The family kept a quiet vigil by the bedside of their sick dog until he started to feel better.
origin: Middle English vigile, from Anglo-French, from Late Latin & Latin; Late Latin vigilia watch on the eve of a feast, from Latin, wakefulness, watch, from vigil awake, watchful; akin to Latin vigēre to be vigorous, vegēre to enliven

definition: capable of being overcome or subdued
sentence: In the story, the giant seemed scary, but the hero discovered that he was actually vincible and could be defeated.
origin: Latin vincibilis, from vincere to conquer

definition: wisps of precipitation evaporating before reaching the ground
sentence: We saw virga in the sky, which is rain that begins to fall from a cloud but evaporates before it hits the ground.
origin: New Latin, from Latin, branch, rod, streak in the sky suggesting rain

definition: one who excels in the technique of an art; especially : a highly skilled musical performer
sentence: The young girl is a piano virtuoso who can play very difficult songs without even looking at the music.
origin: Italian, from virtuoso, adjective, virtuous, skilled, from Late Latin virtuosus virtuous, from Latin virtus

definition: the quality or state of being virulent: such as
sentence: The doctor studied the virulence of the germs to see how quickly they could make a person feel sick.
origin: borrowed from French & Latin; borrowed from French, going back to Middle French, borrowed from Late Latin vīrulentia "poisonous odor, infection," from Latin vīrulentus "full of poison, venomous" + -ia

definition: in relation to; compared with; or face-to-face.
sentence: We need to talk about our plan vis-à-vis the school project to make sure we both know what to do.

definition: having an adhesive quality : sticky
sentence: The viscidity of the maple syrup made it stick to the plate and move very slowly.
origin: Late Latin viscidus, from Latin viscum birdlime

definition: bitterly harsh or caustic language or criticism
sentence: The bully's vitriolic comments were very mean and hurt the feelings of the other students.
origin: Middle English, from Anglo-French vitriole, from Medieval Latin vitriolum, alteration of Late Latin vitreolum, neuter of vitreolus glassy, from Latin vitreus vitreous

definition: of, relating to, or resembling a calf or veal.
sentence: The word vituline is a fancy way to describe things that are related to a calf or a young cow.

definition: a large birdcage or aviary.
sentence: A volary is a large birdcage or an aviary where many birds can fly around together.

definition: characterized by or subject to rapid or unexpected change
sentence: The weather was very volatile today, changing from bright sunshine to a thunderstorm in just a few minutes.
origin: French, from Latin volatilis, from volare to fly

definition: the power of choosing or determining : will
sentence: Leo decided to clean his room of his own volition, without his parents even having to ask him.
origin: French, from Medieval Latin volition-, volitio, from Latin vol- (stem of velle to will, wish) + -ition-, -itio (as in Latin position-, positio position)

definition: of, relating to, or involving the measurement of volume
sentence: A volumetric flask is a special glass container used by scientists to measure an exact amount of liquid.

definition: the Roman god of fire and metalworking
sentence: In ancient Roman myths, Vulcan was the god of fire and the person who made armor for the other gods.
origin: Latin Volcanus, Vulcanus

definition: a maker and repairer of wagons
sentence: A long time ago, a wainwright was a person whose job was to build and repair wooden wagons.

definition: any of various small or medium-sized kangaroos (especially genus Notamacropus)
sentence: A wallaby looks like a small kangaroo and uses its strong back legs to hop quickly across the grass.
origin: Dharuk (Australian aboriginal language of the Port Jackson area) walabi, waliba

definition: a commonplace unadventurous person who seeks escape from reality through daydreaming
sentence: My brother is a bit of a Walter Mitty because he spends a lot of time daydreaming about being a superhero.
origin: Walter Mitty, daydreaming hero of a story by James Thurber

definition: a condiment that is prepared from the ground thick pungent greenish rhizome of an Asian herb (Eutrema japonicum synonym Wasabia japonica) of the mustard family and is similar in flavor and use to horseradish; also : the rhizome
sentence: I tried a tiny bit of wasabi with my sushi, but the spicy green paste made my nose tingle.
origin: Japanese

definition: to ski by means of wedeln
sentence: The skier had to wedel down the slope, which means she moved her skis quickly from side to side.
origin: German Wedeln

definition: any of a breed of large light gray usually short-haired pointers of German origin
sentence: A Weimaraner is a large, sleek dog with short gray fur and very pretty light-colored eyes.
origin: German, from Weimar, Germany

definition: the fisher (a North American marten).
sentence: A wejack is another name for a fisher, which is a furry animal that lives in the forests of North America.

definition: the fenced-in area around a farmhouse in southern Africa.
sentence: In some countries, a werf is the name for the open space or the yard around a farmhouse.

definition: any of various light boats: such as
sentence: A wherry is a light, narrow rowboat that was used to carry passengers across a river.
origin: Middle English whery

definition: a religion influenced by pre-Christian beliefs and practices of western Europe that affirms the existence of supernatural power (such as magic) and of both male and female deities who inhere in nature and that emphasizes ritual observance of seasonal and life cycles
sentence: The book explained that a Wiccan is a person who follows a modern religion based on ancient nature traditions.
origin: probably from Old English wicca wizard

definition: in a left-handed, wrong, or contrary direction : counterclockwise
sentence: In the game, we had to walk widdershins, which means walking in a circle in the opposite direction of a clock.
origin: Middle Low German weddersinnes, from Middle High German widersinnes, from widersinnen to go against, from wider back against (from Old High German widar) + sinnen to travel, go; akin to Old High German sendan to send ,

definition: —used especially in radio and signaling to indicate that a message received will be complied with
sentence: The pilot said 'wilco' over the radio to show that he understood the message and would follow the instructions.
origin: will comply

definition: lake 30 miles (48 kilometers) long in eastern Wisconsin
sentence: The Winnebago are a group of Native American people who originally lived in the area around Wisconsin.

definition: any of a genus (Wisteria) of mostly woody leguminous vines of China, Japan, and the southeastern U.S. that have pinnately compound leaves and long racemes of showy blue, white, purple, or rose papilionaceous flowers and that include several (such as W. sinensis and W. floribunda) grown as ornamentals
sentence: The front of the house was covered in beautiful wisteria vines with hanging clusters of purple flowers.
origin: New Latin Wisteria, from Caspar Wistar †1818 American physician

definition: in law, the act of taking other goods in place of those that were unlawfully taken.
sentence: In an old law, withernam was the act of taking someone's property because they had taken yours first.

definition: a signal generator used to test radio and television receivers by varying the frequency.
sentence: An engineer uses a wobbulator to test how well a radio or a television can receive signals.

definition: strongly affected with woe : woeful
sentence: The puppy had a woebegone look on its face as it sat outside in the rain waiting to come in.
origin: Middle English wo begon, from wo, noun + begon, past participle of begon to go about, beset, from Old English begān, from be- + gān to go

definition: any of several monkshoods (especially Aconitum napellus or A. lycoctonum)
sentence: In many stories about werewolves, people use a purple flower called wolfsbane to protect themselves.

definition: a type of high-carbon steel originally produced in India.
sentence: Wootz is a special kind of steel from India that was used long ago to make very strong and sharp swords.

definition: any of various burrowing Australian crayfishes (genus Cherax, especially C. destructor) that are used for food
sentence: While visiting Australia, we went to the creek to look for yabbies, which are small freshwater crawfish.
origin: Wemba-Wemba (Australian aboriginal language of Victoria) yabij

definition: a mound or pyramid, usually made of stone, found in ancient Mexican sites.
sentence: A yacata is an ancient stone platform or pyramid found in Mexico that was used for ceremonies.

definition: a sharp-crested ridge carved by wind erosion in arid regions.
sentence: A yardang is a long ridge of rock in the desert that has been carved into a strange shape by the wind.

definition: an instrument for measuring the angle of yaw (side-to-side deviation) of an aircraft.
sentence: The pilots used a yawmeter to see if the airplane was pointed straight or if it was tilting to the side.

definition: a white swine of any of several breeds or strains originated in Yorkshire, England
sentence: My aunt has a tiny Yorkshire terrier with long, silky hair and a very brave personality.

definition: a Niger-Congo language of southwestern Nigeria and parts of Benin and Togo; also : a member of any of the Yoruba-speaking peoples of this region
sentence: The Yoruba people have a very rich culture and speak a beautiful language used in West Africa.
origin: Yoruba Yorùbá

definition: the general intellectual, moral, and cultural climate of an era
sentence: The teacher explained that the zeitgeist of a time is the general set of ideas and feelings that everyone shares.
origin: German, from Zeit + Geist spirit

definition: a rigid airship consisting of a cylindrical trussed and covered frame supported by internal gas cells; broadly : airship
sentence: A zeppelin is a giant, football-shaped airship that floats in the sky using light gases.
origin: Count Ferdinand von Zeppelin

definition: a steel-gray hard ductile metallic element with a high melting point that occurs widely in combined form (as in zircon), is highly resistant to corrosion, and is used especially in alloys and in refractories and ceramics
sentence: Zirconium is a strong metal that is often used to make shiny jewelry that looks like diamonds.
origin: New Latin, from International Scientific Vocabulary zircon

definition: of or relating to life; vital or living.
sentence: The forest was full of zoetic energy, with birds singing and animals moving through the trees.

definition: animal worship
sentence: In some ancient cultures, people practiced zoolatry, which means they treated animals as if they were gods.
origin: borrowed from French & New Latin; French zoolâtrie, borrowed from New Latin zoolatria, from zoo-  + -latria

definition: an early device for exhibiting moving pictures by means of a revolving disk of images.
sentence: Long ago, a zoopraxiscope was used to show moving pictures of animals by spinning a glass disk.

definition: the dissection of animals; animal anatomy.
sentence: In science class, we learned that zootomy is the study of the internal structure of animals, like how a frog's heart works.

definition: typical of a zoot-suiter : flashy in manner or style
sentence: The jazz musician looked very zooty in his bright purple suit and matching hat.

definition: a flat thonged sandal usually made of straw, cloth, leather, or rubber
sentence: Before stepping onto the beach, Maya kicked off her zori and ran toward the waves in her bare feet.
origin: Japanese zōri

definition: —used to express astonishment or admiration especially in response to something sudden or speedy
sentence: Holy zowie! shouted Leo when he saw the massive three-layer cake his mom made for his birthday.
origin: imitative of the sound of a speeding vehicle

definition: a double-reed woodwind instrument of Turkish origin.
sentence: During the festival, we heard the loud, shrill sound of the zurna playing traditional music from Turkey.

definition: a cell formed by the union of two gametes; broadly : the developing individual produced from such a cell
sentence: The teacher explained that every living thing starts out as a zygote, which is the very first cell formed when life begins.
origin: Greek zygōtos yoked, from zygoun to join
